This is the only assassin's creed game I have played. I got it because i love the pirate motif in general. The story is great, gameplay is your standard assassin's creed fare. However, the naval combat was a standout for me at the time. I'm sure other newer games offer a better naval combat experience but its pretty good in this game as well. The multiplayer game modes were also a lot of fun. It's a unique experience that I haven't seen in other games even today. The main theme is awesome as well. Highly recommend this one.

The game itself is a masterpiece. In fact, it's the best game I've ever played. However, I've had nothing but trouble ever since I bought this game on Steam (I've played it a lot on PS4 and it's a flawless experience over there). 

First of all, to even get it to start without crashing I had to set the compatibility to Windows 95. Secondly, the first thing I notice is my FPS capping at 5 - It's unplayable. I look into it and realize that it's because only one CPU core is used to run the game. I have to manually change this in the task manager everytime I run the game.
Thirdly, I still suffer from consistent FPS drops (The FPS seems to be capped at 60) to about 20-40. At first I thought I'd get used to it, but 5 minutes pass by and I've had enough. The solution for this was a third party program called D3DOverrider. I still suffer from FPS drops occasionally, but it is at least playable now.
The fourth issue I encountered was that the Kenway Fleet wouldn't open. I had to replace the .exe file with one downloaded from Nexusmods.com to get that to work. I start up the game and everything works perfectly, until the next time I try to play the game. The game wouldn't start so I had to validate the files and replace the modified .exe file with the original one; And I can no longer open the Kenway Fleet. 

My experience with this game has been a disaster since I bought it on Steam. However, bugs aside, the game is - as previously stated - a masterpiece. It's up there with the Ezio-triology and I definitely recommend everyone to play it, just not on Steam.

[h1]ASSASSIN'S CREED IV: BLACK FLAG[/h1]
------------------------
[list][b]What Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag has that Skull and Bones doesn't:[/b]
    [*]amazing and emotional story that will make you cry at the end
    [*]memorable characters that you won't forget
    [*]great facial animation that don't look like emotionless robots when they talk
    [*]epic cutscenes
    [*]beautiful atmosphere/lighting with better graphics & textures
    [*]open world that doesn't feel empty
    [*]freedom of movement. you can leave your ship to explore
    [*]beautiful islands and places that don't look identical to each other
    [*]beautiful and colorful water textures. And water effects, like for example: water droplets on wet clothes. [strike]Skull and Bones devs forgot about this insignificant detail after 10+ years of development[/strike]
    [*]board the ships. [strike]Skull and Bones doesn't have main features of a pirate game. Accident?[/strike]
    [*]replayability. I am playing for 5th time now and having a blast.
    [*]don't need a RTX 2070 and i7-8700K to play it
[/list]
------------------------
[list][b]What Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag doesn't have that Skull and Bones have:[/b]
    [*]microtransactions
    [*]10+ years of development
    [*]AAAA quadruple title
[/list]

[code][b]RATING: 10/10[/b][/code]

Still the best pirate game?

Black Flag is mostly remembered for its naval combat and gorgeous world. And that's because it kinda doesn't do the rest so well. The combat is mediocre, and the free-running is imprecise and stripped back. The story is also fairly forgettable, but then that's never been the greatest strength of the franchise. 

Still, you'll forget about pretty much all of it when you're at the helm trying to line up a broadside during a storm. Sailing and exploring is excellent as ever, and the side activities like whaling and diving on shipwrecks are a fun change of pace. Still a recommend if you want a pirate game and Skull and Bones didn't scratch that itch.

Also, unlike a lot of older ubi titles, this one did survive the transition from Uplay to Ubi Connect with all its features still intact, although logging in is slow and multiplayer is apparently awkward to get working.
YES. Old is Gold.

Ubisoft has aroused some controversies in its life time, particularly in the last few years through accusations on their company and questions on the quality of their recent publishes. I have never been a die-hard fan of their games, let alone the Assassin's Creed installments. I cannot speak on behalf of the companies behavior, and I also cannot elaborate on how some fans have been disenchanted as of late.

And although I cannot draw draw strong comparisons to other Assassin's Creed games in the series either, I affirm that Black Flag is to me, a standalone masterpiece. No doubt the best pirate game I've ever got involved with.

The best part about Black Flag might just be the naval combat system, which I contribute to my praise for the game. It is exciting and challenging, and really made me feel like I was in the Golden Age of Piracy. Ship shanties and natural disasters enhance said sailing more-so, and boarding ships is also a feature in the game, and probably my favorite thing to do while playing (and I bet others can agree!). Apart from ship sailing, the game offers an abundance of other activities such as exploring its awe-inspiring visuals, hoarding collectibles across the map, pursuing assassination contracts, and crafting/upgrading the player and ships load-out.

I did not care for the segments of the game that the player in a real-time office expanding on the Assassin's Creed lore as a whole, but I did fall in love with the primarily plot, which was simply a thrilling pirate adventure with a lovable cast of characters.

Black Flag is a grand game, and guarantees a positive experience in my book.

Played through every single Assassin's Creed game recently, not played Odyssey or Valhalla just yet but they are on my list. Assassin's Creed 4 to me stands out as arguably one of the best ones, if not the best. You could argue that this isn't a "true" Assassin's Creed game and I could definitely agree with you but the gameplay is peak, the themes are great, the characters are loveable, the story is excellent and it really felt like every system that was slowly getting better since the first game culminated into this masterpiece. 

This is the best pirate game of all time and it's often on sale for $20, you cannot spend a better $20 imo. Its a shame how poor Skull and Bones is when they had the blueprint for the perfect pirate game with this game. Exploration, great ship combat, great on foot combat, great music, shanties, aesthetically this is amazing. Truly one of the best games of all time.

I've first played this game in like 2015 and at the time, I loved it. The pirate-assassin combo was amazing, the world was large and the ship aspect was just so much fun. 
Don't know what happened since then, but I guess my standards got higher, because despite the nostalgy that I feel playing this game, I just cannot start liking it. 
Why?
The controls are unresponsive, sometimes delayed and overall wonky as hell, the game is capped at 60 fps, the sensitivity is inconsistent in 3rd person, 1st person and the menu, and after about 60 mins of gameplay, I've had enough of this game, which is a real shame, because I remember this game fondly, especially the sea combat and sailing, though I did not get to that while playing now, just the "tutorial" where you sink a few ships.
Overall, I cannot imagine spending 50+ hours in a game that I already dislike playing after 1 hour, even though I loved it years ago.

Never a fan of Assassin Creed franchise, but after watching comparison between Black Flag and Skull and Bones, I am a little intrigue with Black Flag's Open World Pirate Simulator. 

After downloading and installing the game, I was caught by surprised with a CD-Key, I was bewildered because almost every old games I bought from Steam recently never asked me for a CD key. I did not notice any instruction from the game or from the store page where to get the CDKey, so I used search engine to do some research, it turns out you have to get the CD Key from Game's property, it is silly, but that the way it is. 

The game is nearly 10 years old, runs very well at 2160p at max settings with Ryzen 5900 and RTX 3080, I did not noticed any "windows compatibility" issues plaguing older games so far. I was greeted with a postage stamp screen size, so I went to graphics settings and crank up the resolution matches my windows resolution and voila a full screen!

The graphics is a little dated mainly on shaders and lighting reminding me of Fallout 3 or GTAIV, but with higher quality models and textures, but it can improved with some ENB reshade mod. You started with a tutorial with basic ship combat and player character movements.

Though, made under a corporate publisher, but you can see the passion put into the game by the talented developers, the corporate culture was much different 10 years ago. Overall the game is fairly impressive that was made to make it run on PS3/Xbox 360. Black Flag definitely aged like a fine wine.

BEWARE BEFORE BUY: Thought people should know full screen no longer works on pc, only way to fix it is through nexus mods. If its a deluxe version nexus mods wont work either and it cant go full screen, it will stay as a small window.

Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag" Review:

"Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag" is an action-adventure game developed by Ubisoft Montreal and released in 2013. Set in the early 18th century during the Golden Age of Piracy, the game follows Edward Kenway, a charismatic and ambitious pirate who becomes embroiled in the conflict between Assassins and Templars. Here's a review highlighting the positives and negatives of "Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag":

Positives:

1. **Open-World Exploration**: "Black Flag" offers a vast and immersive open world set across the Caribbean Sea and its numerous islands. Players can explore bustling ports, hidden coves, and expansive wilderness areas, encountering a variety of wildlife, landscapes, and historical landmarks along the way.

2. **Naval Gameplay**: A standout feature of "Black Flag" is its highly acclaimed naval gameplay mechanics. Players command their own ship, the Jackdaw, engaging in thrilling naval battles, exploring uncharted islands, and plundering enemy vessels. The naval combat is intuitive and exhilarating, with dynamic weather conditions and realistic ship physics adding depth to the experience.

3. **Engaging Story and Characters**: The narrative of "Black Flag" is rich and compelling, weaving together themes of adventure, betrayal, and redemption against the backdrop of the Golden Age of Piracy. Edward Kenway is a charismatic and complex protagonist, surrounded by a diverse cast of memorable characters, including famous pirates like Blackbeard and Anne Bonny.

4. **Freedom and Exploration**: "Black Flag" emphasizes player freedom and exploration, allowing players to chart their own course through the Caribbean and pursue a variety of activities and side quests. From hunting elusive animals to uncovering buried treasure, the game offers countless opportunities for discovery and adventure.

Negatives:

1. **Repetitive Mission Structure**: Despite its open-world freedom, "Black Flag" suffers from a somewhat repetitive mission structure, particularly in its land-based missions and side quests. Many missions follow a formulaic pattern of eavesdropping, tailing targets, or engaging in combat, leading to a sense of monotony over time.

2. **Lackluster Modern-Day Storyline**: While the historical narrative of "Black Flag" is engaging, the modern-day storyline set in the present day is often criticized for its lackluster execution and disconnect from the main plot. The modern-day segments feel tacked on and fail to resonate with players as strongly as the historical storyline.

3. **Technical Issues and Performance**: Like many open-world games, "Black Flag" is not without its technical issues, including occasional framerate drops, graphical glitches, and AI inconsistencies. While these issues are relatively minor, they can detract from the overall immersion and polish of the game.

4. **Limited Stealth Mechanics**: While "Black Flag" offers a variety of gameplay options, including stealth, the stealth mechanics are relatively simplistic compared to other entries in the series. Stealth encounters often lack depth and complexity, limiting the strategic options available to players during infiltration missions.

In conclusion, "Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag" offers a captivating and immersive pirate experience set against the backdrop of the Caribbean during the Golden Age of Piracy. With its expansive open world, engaging naval gameplay, and compelling narrative, "Black Flag" stands as one of the most beloved entries in the "Assassin's Creed" series, despite its occasional technical issues and repetitive mission structure.

The absolute epitome of how to make a good video game. Absolute peak and what Sea of Thieves and all pirate games should strive to be. Easily in my top 5 favorite games purely due to the sailing alone, with the boarding and looting making it an epic experience. The multiplayer back in the early days was so much fun; despite being utterly dead now and full of bots or max level players that steam roll, it has a lot to offer and is my personal favorite when it comes to AC multiplayer modes. While the story for most AC games are either a mixed bag or downright awful, this one holds up and portrays a selfish man becoming more, and realizing that life is more than just rum, money, and women, (don't call me turbo cringe plz). Altogether, this is a package that is well worth the money and the days upon days you'll pour into it.

Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag takes players on a thrilling journey through the Golden Age of Piracy, offering a unique blend of open-world exploration, naval combat, and stealthy assassination missions. Set in the Caribbean during the early 18th century, the game immerses players in a richly detailed world filled with colorful characters, treacherous pirates, and sprawling landscapes. Developed by Ubisoft, Black Flag stands out as one of the most ambitious entries in the Assassin's Creed series, offering both the familiar elements of the franchise along with refreshing new gameplay mechanics. Here's a detailed look at the pros and cons of this pirate-themed adventure:

Pros:

Captivating Setting: The Caribbean setting of Black Flag is beautifully realized, with lush tropical islands, bustling ports, and vast stretches of open sea to explore. From the vibrant streets of Havana to the remote coves of Nassau, the game offers a diverse range of environments to discover, each filled with its own secrets and challenges.

Dynamic Naval Combat: One of the standout features of Black Flag is its thrilling naval combat system. Players take command of their own pirate ship, engaging in epic battles against enemy vessels, hunting for treasure, and embarking on daring raids. The naval mechanics are well-executed, offering a satisfying blend of strategy and action as players navigate the high seas.

Freedom of Exploration: Black Flag encourages players to explore its open-world environment at their own pace, with plenty of side activities and hidden treasures to discover. Whether hunting for buried treasure, hunting elusive sea creatures, or engaging in naval skirmishes, there's always something new to see and do in the game's vast world.

Engaging Storyline: The narrative of Black Flag follows the journey of Edward Kenway, a charismatic pirate captain caught in the conflict between the Assassin Brotherhood and the Templar Order. The story is filled with twists and turns, as Edward navigates the murky waters of piracy while uncovering secrets that could change the course of history.

Cons:

Repetitive Mission Structure: While Black Flag offers a wealth of content, some players may find the mission structure to be somewhat repetitive. Many of the side missions and activities follow a similar formula, which can lead to a sense of monotony over time.

Technical Issues: Like many open-world games, Black Flag is not without its technical issues. Some players have reported encountering bugs, glitches, and performance issues, particularly on older hardware or less powerful gaming systems.

Steep Learning Curve: The game's naval combat mechanics and open-world gameplay can be daunting for newcomers to the series. While the game does offer tutorials and guidance, some players may find it difficult to master the intricacies of sailing, combat, and exploration.

Overall, Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag is a swashbuckling adventure that offers a compelling mix of action, exploration, and storytelling. Despite its occasional flaws, the game remains a standout entry in the Assassin's Creed series, offering hours of entertainment for fans of historical fiction and open-world gaming alike. Whether sailing the high seas, engaging in epic naval battles, or unraveling the mysteries of the Caribbean, Black Flag delivers an unforgettable gaming experience that will leave players craving more.

I had a weird reaction to Black Flag.

It is both my absolute favorite of the Assassin Creed games, and the reason I lost interest in the Assassin Creed games.

The reason is simple. Everything I loved about this game was the pirate stuff: sailing the seas, finding buried treasure and the dynamic ship battles. Everything I hated was the assassin's stuff: the frustrating stealth missions and the whole meta narrative.

This game make me realize I no longer enjoyed the Assassin Creed game staples.  Since future titles wouldn't have pirates to compensate, there was no reason to bother with them.

But hey, at least I got to play a great pirate game!

The good: the mechanics are closer to OG games in the series than the newer releases, it's not the grind fest the series turned into later on. If you want to try a stealthy play style you've got options. Once you get familiar with the game you can get fluid parkour mechanics. 

The bad:  you need to deal with Ubisoft connect launcher which is problematic at best, also may mean if Ubi drops support the game may break forever. Some of the cut scene graphics are showing some age. The gameplay isn't too bad but modern cut scenes are certainly better than these. 

The YMMV: The game is autosave based so if you wanted to rerun a section, there is a way to do it via "cheats menu" once unlocked but it doesnt feel the same as having a quicksave/reload option. the Ubi launcher usually crashes on me but once I get the game itself launched everything is fine. annoying to deal with the extra sign-ins

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag is the sixth main installment in the Assassin's Creed franchise. Set during the golden age of piracy, you play as Edward Kenway, father of Haytham Kenway and grandfather of Connor Kenway, a Welsh privateer-turned-pirate in search of gold, glory and fame.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*]Great graphics, although they're starting to show their age.
[*]Great story where you interact with the most notorious pirates in history, including Mary Read, Benjamin Hornigold and Blackbeard.
[*]Awesome naval combat that is expanded from AC III.
[*]Legendary ship battles.
[*]Good customization.
[*]Large, beautiful map to explore.
[*]Underwater sections.
[*]Great sea shanties.
[*]Fantastic soundtrack.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]Poor optimization.
[*]Present day story is meaningless.
[*]Too many tailing missions.
[*]Enemy shooting markers don't work properly. I got shot regularly even though the marker wasn't bright red yet. It also doesn't show up at certain angles.
[*]Optional objectives.
[*]Too many collectibles, as is the case with most Ubisfot games.
[*]The ship will slowly drift away from the smaller islands, making picking up collectibles even more annoying.
[*]Ubisoft Connect keeps asking for my password every time, yet again...
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
If you're looking for the ultimate pirate fantasy, then Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag is for you. It's fun, it's got great naval combat and you get to meet some of the most notorious pirates in history.

Business as usual.

After suffering through Assassin's Creed III, Black Flag brings enjoyment back to the franchise. Edward Kenway is a big upgrade on the dreadfully boring Connor, with plenty of good side characters scattered around the West Indies.

The parkour has been given a solid makeover and feels very smooth, with a limited number of movement bugs.

The map is a brilliant size with lots of encounters and missions to complete 100% sync. You'll keep playing this one even after finishing the story!

As for the story, it's excellently done. The character development of the protagonist is very well thought through and doesn't feel rushed at all. You'll begin to notice that this game doesn't center around Assassin's as much as previous instalments, but be patient as there is lots more to see with this one.

Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag is a time capsule from a time when Assassin's Creed was a stealth-action franchise rather than an RPG focusing on gear and stats. In my opinion, this is the best one of the series, although I am biased - this game was an incredible part of my childhood. I found the seafaring, cutscenes, sea shanties, underwater environments and towns absolutely charming. Using real-world history with embellishment was absolutely an amazing design choice for an open-world pirate game from the Golden Age of Piracy. The main character also has a satisfying arc of development.

Ubisoft isn't the best, and the launcher sucks, but the game itself is worth it.

I would not recommend buying this game - as timeless as it may be - for more than about $20. Wait for a good sale before you dive in.

The game has some rough starts. First you get prompted for an activation code (r-click on the game, properties, show code) then it has to link with your Ubisoft account (download or update launcher). Then graphics freak out on 1140x3440 resolution on a 3080Ti, giving you a razor-thin ultra-wide view that keeps you from seeing anything. Had to reset graphics with the Nvidia app to optimized setting and restart a couple times to be able to see the game. Then it lost all my key re-binds.

BUT, after all that hassle, the game started working well enough, and is enjoyable enough for an older title. Ship combat is fun. Controls and reactions are a little wonky (sometimes the avatar jumps weird places, or wont grab a handhold, etc). Story is ok but a little repetitive and obvious plot lines/reveals. Definitely worth it on sale.

Do not buy this game on Steam. There is no reason for this game to even be on Steam.

Attempting to play it will launch BOTH steam and Uplay, each with their own overlay active during play. I can only speak for myself, but this game stutters like Porky Pig on even a decent modern PC, partly because each overlay f***s with the graphics and having both on makes it even worse. There are reams of threads where people talk about using Windows 7 compatibility and adjusting the number of active processor cores...

Screw that. The Steam implementation is buggy AF and not worth it. If you want to play it, buy direct from Uplay since you're going to have to use it anyway and you'll save yourself from the bugs related to at least one of the overlays.

Better yet - just get it on console and save yourself the hassle. Or just don't get it at all.

But yeah if you get past all the buggery and BS, you'll love it. AC4 is hands down the best in the series. Really the only one worth playing other than AC1.

The worst assassins creed I've played, most land missions are focused on stealth which is very badly implemented (e.g. trees hide you no more). It is like making splinter cell pirates of caribbean. Very similar and repetitive missions. It lacks fluid playability of previous games. I didn't enjoy it at all, the AC Rogue is much better.

Good news,

The AC: Black Flag server is up and Kenway's Fleet works again.

This game still holds the best ship handling and battle mechanics of any age-of-sail game to date. And the never-ending sailing option, with or without combat after the main story ends, turns it into a fully animated 1st/3rd person Combat Sailing simulator. This makes Black Flag re-playable all these years later, and I can't say that about most games released since that time. 

So now we wait and see what the AC:4 'remake' is all about and if it makes, or breaks the original game and its unique play style.

As for the new direction they have chosen:
I have watched countless play-through's of Skull & Bones, and can say without any doubt:
Skull & Bones doesn't even come close to what it could be, there is an immense hole in the game, like a best attempt to fix something very broken...
Kenway fleet doesnt work. As of 2024 game is still sadly unplayable.

Their are three cons in this game
1. Ship appearance options are limited
2. Combat is satisfying but lacks difficulty, though it would be difficult to feel like a powerhouse and have it be difficult
3. Something i hate dearly about the older assassins creed games is the designated "stealth" zones. Being able to sneak all the time would be awesome.

With these small caveats aside, Black Flag is one of the greatest games ever made in my opinion. I am bias but few worlds are as fun, interesting, and gigantic as the Caribbean. Overall 9.5/10 "im heavily biased"

I definitely hold it up there with AC III, some say this is the best AC game in the series but to me that sounds a bit too high a compliment. An excellent chapter in the series for sure, with skill based combat with counter kills and building up a kill streak that can blaze through enemies left and right as long as you know how to attack the enemy the right way. With ship battles on top of that complete with shanty singing and general piracy with ship boarding and capturing on top of the usual assassin tasks and side missions you'll have plenty to do. The weakest point of it all? In my opinion, is stealth segments with the ship. Yeah, sneaking around other vessels in your own massive ship can be a pain as you fixate your eyes mostly on the minimap just to evade those detection cones. Multiplayer still kicking, surprisingly, sorta. Ok, it's pretty dead, but more serviceable than AC III which is completely shut down. AC IV's multiplayer still works, it just has zero playerbase more often than not. If you can coordinate enough with a few people you might just get a round or two in, which is a fun time hunting and avoiding being hunted by other players tracking you; rewarding fast but covert action. Even if you're just exploring single player though, its a fun time.

Loved the various things you can do as a pirate, though they can all become a bit repetitive after a while.
I also loved exploring the seas with my ship, with your crew singing shanties you've found in cities. 
I really like collecting stuff in games but I must say despite that and loving the sea exploration, I found the non stop stopping at random tiny empty islands to pick up one collectible very quickly annoying. Especially when it wasn't a chest (which at least feels like a reward and sticks with the pirate theme), most of the time you would only find an animus fragment which brings absolutely nothing to the game except to count as one of those things you have to 100%.

[u][b]Lifespan :[/b][/u] 40-50 hours to 100%, probably around 20 hours if you just care about the main story.

[u][b]Story :[/b][/u] Like it's usual with Assassin's Creed games, you have two stories going on. The one in the animus (a machine that allows to experience the life of someone's ancestor) and the one in the real world.
In the animus, you play as Edward Kenway, a pirate that discovers the whole assassin-templar conspiracy when he gets into a fight with an assassin, kills him and then pretends to be him. You follow him as he tries to get rich, help his pirate friends and discover the truth around the Observatory, something the assassins and templars are looking for that could allow someone to control the world. For this you become a pirate captain and grow your power with your crew.
In the real world, you're en employee working at Abstergo Entertainment, a company ran by templars that makes games with the animus data. Your job is to research the life of Edward Kenway through the animus. Eventually you discover the conspiracy when assassins ask you to hack the various computers.

I really liked both stories which are somewhat linked.  I was invested in both and never felt like one was preventing me from enjoying the other one. It can be a bit confusing though when you're coming from the previous games, because you're thrown in there without knowing what happened to the usual characters and who you are. Hacking the computers actually allow you to find out more about what happened between the games.

[u][b]Gameplay :[/b][/u] 
In the real world, you get to hack computers. For this you have to do a mini game and there are 3 different ones. One where you have to move a dot on lines on a sphere to try and reach a specific line. One where you have to cross several lines which have red bars that make you start from the beginning (basically the game where a frog crosses a river on logs). And one where you have to match a frequency by choosing different numbers.
Mostly they're fine, I was very rarely annoyed by one of them because they don't last long. Most of the information you find in the hacked files is interesting and a nice dive into the lore of the games.

In the animus, you can do the usual assassin stuff: stealth, kill, eavesdrop. The optional objectives give you a reason to not always just run around killing everyone like a brute, making the gameplay less repetitive and more interesting; but at the same time they're optional so if one is too annoying you can just ignore it (unless you want to 100% the game).
You can do pirate stuff: you can pilot a ship, attack other ships and board them so you can get their cargo, and rescue pirates to add them to your crew. Everytime you board a ship, you need to follow several objectives that change depending on the ship and you have to finish them before all your crew members die.
You can collect shanties for your crew to sing. Find chests to get richer and find treasure maps to find burried chests. You can improve your ship by using materials you find by boarding other ships, making it stronger and deadlier. With your improved ship you can then fight the legendary ships (basically naval boss fights). Destroying ships will give you a bad reputation which will make hunter ships regularly come after you. The worst your reputation, the stronger the hunter ships. When you board a ship you can choose an option to reduce that reputation or you can just pay someone to do it.
You have several side quests (assassination contracts, naval contracts and templar contracts) and mayan stones you need to collect, both unlock a special outfit. You have underwater explorations where you need to avoid sharks and eels. You have sea forts you can attack (first from the sea, then on land) to then capture them and control this part of the sea.
You have a fleet you can control (it's only online though) where you send ships on mission to bring back money, decoration items for your hideout and treasure maps. When you board ships you can choose to send them to your fleet to use them there. The missions happen in the background without your input and can take up to 24 real life hours.
You can hunt on land (deers, monkeys...) and at sea (whales, sharks...) and use that to craft upgrades for your character.
When exploring the sea on your ship, you can stop anywhere and just leave your ship to explore around. There are a lot of mostly empty small islands but the ones with stuff to do have a landmark icon. The big cities or story places will usually be instanced though.

So basically, you have a lot of things that you can do. If some of them are not your cup of tea and you're not after the 100%, you can absolutely ignore them.
I really liked most of them even though they can get repetitive after a while (for example after some time I would just sink ships because I didn't want to go through the boarding objectives).
It's too bad some things seem pointless or not finished. For example the animus fragments which are just collectibles for the sake of being collectibles. They don't represent anything in the game and don't reward you anything when you find them all. Another example is your hideout; you get a cove at some point and you can pay to improve it. That was nice and you can get some bonus with it (free dancers or mercenaries) but I would have liked more things to do in the house or to see your wealth represented in the decor. Right now there's really no point in going there more than once to visit.

[u][b]Achievements :[/b][/u] There are no achievements on steam but you can unlock achievements on ubisoft connect. 
Beware that some of them require playing a lot of multiplayer (which will probably be difficult seeing how old the game is) and playing to 100% the DLC "Freedom Cry".

Black Flag is an iconic title within the Assassin's Creed franchise, and dare I say, within video games. It's one of the handful of games that I periodically return to just to play through the story again. It has memorable characters, classic AC gameplay, great narrative and storytelling, crucial lore to the franchise, and so much more going for it. So why don't I recommend it?

I've always thought it's ridiculous when people leave negative reviews because of Ubisoft's launcher. Yes, Ubisoft has pushed so hard for people to use this barely functional launcher. Yes, it's terrible. No, nobody is going to buy Ubisoft games through their launcher as opposed to Steam (looking at you, Valhalla). No, their launcher probably wouldn't work even if they allocated the same resources to developing it as they do their main titles. But it isn't fair for people to leave bad reviews solely because of their launcher... or so I thought. Because I recently came back to this game - which I never had any problems playing in the past - and I'm now finding that the game either works or it doesn't. Logging into Ubisoft's servers is a gamble; sometimes it works right away, other times I've walked away for 10 minutes and come back to see that nothing changed. Loading a save either crashes or doesn't, and there's no clear pattern to it. Sometimes the game crashes before you even load into the main menu. Sometimes it doesn't.

I really love this game. It's been a cherished title of mine since release. I sincerely want to encourage people to play this game, but I can't do that if the game is half playable. And what the hell happened there, Ubisoft? I haven't had this problem in the 10 years this game's been around. What went wrong?



Update: It's been a few days since I wrote this. In the span of about an hour, I have tried launching this game nearly 30 times. Not once has it managed to connect to Ubisoft's servers. I rest my case.

The best way I can say this:
I can't imagine a game I would want remastered more than this one.
I've never played the multiplayer.  I'm not really that into being a pirate, nor can I say it has a realistic sailing physics model.    BUT.

This game was made with attention to every detail.  Even though bugs can make funny things happen, you can see the work of talented artists EVERYWHERE.  Even some of the combat animations can bug out in funny ways simply because of how much distance they can cover, and how long the sequences are.  Twitchy gamers might find this maddening.  Someone who loves counter based choreographed animation sequences will get dopamine releases constantly when it works right.  (It looks beautiful but you have a very high chance of glitching on all the world detail LOL.)

Something I noticed that speaks of what we should expect of AAA titles:  You can slowly push your joystick forward to go from barely moving to walking, and then squeeze your trigger to transition from walking to sprinting.  This "Analog" speed control is something missing in many games.  To be able to choose exactly what speed you want to move is very nice, and far superior to other WALK/RUN/SPRINT combos.  Honestly any button mashing monkey is going to miss (or dislike) details like this in their pursuit of the speed run score.  But if you play with an audience this game showcases art and beauty in not only it's environment detail, but also in the realism visible in player movement.

I will say I've tried the game using HDR enabled, and tried AutoHDR through Windows, but this is a title that looked so much better with it turned off on my system.  (it did make it brighter, but the color wasn't right.)

My system struggles with the older Physx engine so that gets turned off.
My OLED doesn't struggle with shimmer so I turn off AntiAliasing as well.  (This makes the water look amazing, but introduces shimmer around ship ropes on slower screens.)
I don't use the soft shadows, and instead go for highest sharp shadow setting I can get. (preference.)

I hope to revisit this game the rest of my life.  (I still have a NOHUD playthrough scheduled, as well as a pacifist playthrough.)

This is not the "best ever" AC title in the series, it's not even close. There are several reasons:

1. You play a savage, a primitive mercenary who goes over dead bodies, just to get rich. Edward Kennedy is a parasite, a scrupulous scoundrel. The fact that he ends up doing (debatable) "good" in the end, is an accident since the money led him that way. The often touted character development is very shallow. 

I much prefer the AC titles in which one liberates people against oppressors, revenges injustice, makes one an advocate for honest and innocent people. It is much more fun to eliminate evil people rather than killing random people that are in one's path to a financial fortune. 

2. While other AC titles create an experience, this remains a game. The difference is that one does not forget the controls and is awed by visuals and sound, but rather is constantly reminded which key to press for what and needs to figure out what the game wants one to do. It is not enough to understand in principle what needs to be done and have one's own game plan, rather one needs to figure out how the game requires one to do something.
 
3. The best part of the story is the modern day development; there is at least some suspense and some of the recordings are very well done. My favourite one is that from Desmond Miles where he talks about his memory of his father. The pirate story is pretty boring. Get this McGuffin to chase another McGuffin. There is no real intrigue or mystery (apart from the "observatory").

4. The story is told in "sequences", which are subdivided in "missions". The game is very busy to tell you what to do next, and particular how to do it, which I found to be very immersion breaking. Sometimes, however, it fails to disclose requirements and then presents you after the mission how you failed to completely master it in every which way. At other times, the game is also unnecessarily specific how you have to complete a challenge (e.g., you must not stray too far from an end boss once the fight is triggered, even when it would be advantages to gain some distance to first strategically eliminate other NPCs first). Why not let a player use their own strategies? 
Sometimes it is not clear what the next objective is, e.g., I cannot be the only one who was stumped about what to do when sailing to a target island. There is no harbour and one is supposed to figure out that the ship will not need to moored or anchored and one is just expected [spoiler]to stop the ship somewhere and swim to the island[/spoiler]. Furthermore, despite the frequent, immersion-breaking tutorials, the naval combat controls are not explained that well. There is a reason why there are respective YouTube tutorials for them. Most of them are clear, but the fire bombs were not explained at all, IIRC. 

5. While the graphics are overall surprisingly good for a game of this vintage, faces look really bad. It is tough relating to characters that looks so much like cartoon figures. I did not have this issue with AC Unity, perhaps the graphics were already better or the story drew me in. 

6.  Many cut scenes play repeatedly and cannot be skipped, even though one has seen them many times before. These cut scenes are not context-sensitive either, e.g., after defeating a ship, the same laid back attitude resumes, regardless of whether one is actually in a battle with other ships or a fortress. 

7. The controls are extremely clunky. They frequently leads to silly actions being performed that at best look stupid and at worst cost one one's life. The reason is that one does not actually move the character but rather triggers predefined action sequences (similar to an arcade game like "Streetfighter"). If it works, it looks cool but a) is boring as one essentially retrieves canned moves, and b) very, very frequently, it does not work. The character then clings to a fence instead of jumping over it, jumps away from a wall in a completely unpredictable manner, etc. This can be very frustrating if these control fits occur in some difficult to reach location since one then has to go through the rigmarole of getting to the spot time and again until one figures out how to make the character behave properly in a challenging spot. FWIW, I had to get used to the controls in AC Unity but then rarely had issues with them. 

The frequent failures of the game to guess the right action is aggravated by the fact that a very low number of keys are highly overloaded. Shift is not only used to for sprinting but also to scale objects which leads one to frequently climb objects unintentionally. The function of "E", for instance, depends on the context. Sometimes you wan to whistle but you cannot because either you are hanging of a ledge (where "E" drops you) or you are hidden in a hideout with a killed enemy and would loot them by pressing "E". There a number of keys that are not used which could have been used to reduce this overloading issue which not only reduces one's actions in a specific situation but also requires one to watch the dynamic mapping in the top right of the screen that explains which key does what currently. This is not my idea of fun; neither is it my preference to always see either a grey or white WiFi symbol that tells me whether the game has a connection to the server on the screen. There is no option to hide this entirely superfluous indicator.

8, There is quite a bit of farming necessary to get one's ship into a useful state and develop the character. I have no idea why many complain about an "RPG-style" for AC Orgins/Odyssey when Black Flag essentially has an implicit level system as well and forces one to complete a number of side missions in order to stand a chance in the main missions. I normally don't have a problem with some farming and grinding being required but when the story is as lame as it is in Black Flag, these requirements become a frustrating chore.

While the game has some good bits and shows glimpses of what made AC Origins great, for instance, and I occasionally even had fun, any such streaks where abruptly ended by the character doing their thing instead of me having agency over their actions (due to the clunky controls). There are simply better AC games and it would be a shame if someone played this -- touted by some as the "best ever" -- and came to the conclusion AC games are not worth it.  I can see how Black Flag must have been impressive at the time it was released but since then controls have been become much more intuitive, AFAIC, and there are much better ways to get a taste of the AC franchise. 

For context: I hugely enjoyed AC Unity, and absolutely loved AC Origins and AC Odyssey. My preferred gaming style is using a stealth approach and my favourite weapon is bow and arrow (even when playing as Lara Croft, I almost never use guns, let alone machine guns). I also like open-world games where the character can scale pretty much every obstacle. Theoretically, therefore, I should like Black Flag but it simply is not fun to constantly lose agency over the character because it decides to trigger some unproductive move/action. I was often forced to go into battles even though I would have preferred a 100% stealth approach because of the clunky controls. Also, I could never relate to the base motives of the main character (Edward) and the story failed to grip me 95% o the time.  I finished the game because a) I thought maybe I'll start liking it more at some point, and b) I had the ambition to finish it, no matter what. It wasn't fun most of the time, though and a wiser person would have abandoned it about a third of the way in.  

If you are a huge pirate fan, don't care about questionable character traits, don't need a captivating story, and are very tolerant towards complete behavioural failures due to the clunky controls then Black Flag may be a good choice for you. For anyone trying to get a taste of the AC franchise, I recommend to avoid this game.

Keep in mind that this is the only AC game I've ever played, and my hour count is wrong because i usually just left the game running overnight or while I was at work. Overall, I would recommend this. One of the best naval games I've ever played, and the story kept me invested. The graphics hold up spectacular for an older game, and run smooth at high settings on my system, and my hardware is far from good. The worst aspects of this game I only discovered when I set my sights on 100%ing it. The optional objectives were rough and had me screaming at my monitor at times, frustrating for sure. The uncharted island quests were also tedious and took forever, very mundane. Movement was also rough, Edward always decided to jump the wrong way and kill himself, as much as i tried to talk him out of it. This strikes me as weird for a game so focused on this aspect, but have no reference for the rest of the series. In reality my save is stuck at 99%, as some quests are locked behind ubisoft connect, which is super bugged out for me right now. I may come back later to fix it, but for now I'm ready to play something else. I know this sounds super critical, but it is a very good game all said and done. Some players I spoke to said the ships moved too slow; and that destroying other ships was too hard because of this. However, I find that the ships moving slow to turn is realistic. The ships in those years would not have turned on a dime and would have taken time to turn and fire cannons. I like this. And then there are also the exotic islands which are colorful with jungle and villages. And there are islands with ancient ruins which is really interesting. So, yeah, I really like this game for these reasons. And there is Cuba and Havana and being able to run around in those ancient towns. As far as I am concerned, this is a most satisfactory game because it moves slow --- you don't have to get nervous playing it. Yeah, yeah, there is hand-to-hand combat but, come on, every game has this. And the pirate songs are great to hear as you are sailing. And the ocean sequences are really fine --- the swells look and feel realistic. C'mon, gang, get behind this game. It actually has a lot going for it. I have played it before and I am playing it again.

I don't know how I missed this game. This has now become my all time favorite assassins creed game. It has all of the elements from 2 that I loved but expanded upon so much more. The movement is for sure old school assassins creed. A little clunky at first but once you master it, its so damn fun. The stealth combat is amazing.  The naval combat is amazing as well. I played odyssey a few years ago and thought it was fun and the naval combat was decent, but this is on a whole different level. You have to actually combat weather and large waves that come at your boat. The wind can push you in any which direction. For being a game from ( I just found out that its not 2015) 2013..... the graphics are still amazing. I highly recommend this game to any oldschool assassins creed OGs and newcomers alike.

[h1] One Of The Best Pirate Games Out There! [/h1]

[b] The Positive's [/b]
+ Large Open World
+ Lots Of Customizations 
+ Awesome Sea Shanties 

[b] The Negative's [/b]
- COLLECTIABLES E V E R Y W H E R E 
- Game Crashes After 5 Hours In
- Standard Ubisoft Bugs

[b] The Aspect Of The Game [/b]
[i] You are a new employee for Abstergo Industries tasked with going through the animus and reliving the event's of the assassin Edward Kenway. [/i]

[b] My Two Cent Review [/b]
[i] As a pirate game this is one of the best out there. As an Assassins Creed game it's alright. The assassin you play is an alright character but he's nothing special really. [spoiler] Guy acts like a douche first half of the game and only redeems himself when everybody he's friends with is dead around him.[/spoiler] The story is alright but it isn't what kept me going till the end it was really the ship combat and exploration that kept me going. I don't know I told myself I would 100% this game. I spent over 50+ hours getting every collectable in the game and let me tell you it was not worth it. I got some cool armor out of it sure but that's about it really. Really loved the ship shanties throughout my play through I was often singing along with my pirate crew as I was traveling on the open waters which I do fairly often in that game. The one thing I really hated was how I Kept crashing always around the 5 hour mark. Didn't matter where I was or what I was doing when it got around that time it would shut down on me with a fatal error which pissed me off unbelievably so because I often doing a mission and would have to restart because of it. [/i]

[b] The Value Of The Game [/b]
[i] If you really want a fun pirate experience this is the game for you when it goes on sale for dirt cheap. [/i]

[h1] Final Score 88/100 Ranking B+ Tier  [/h1]

I remember as a kid I would constantly watch the cinematic trailer for this game, over and over again, and I would think it was so incredibly cool and that I would just LOVE to play a game like this.
So it felt really weird to me that when I played this game, it didn't sit well with me at all. In fact, I really don't like it.
I really hate to say that, because I hear people say such good things about this game, and even I myself used to get excited over possibly playing this one day. But it's the truth - I just couldn't bring myself to finish this game.
I think it was the ship parts, the gameplay involving sailing your pirate ship to different islands and then doing some mission on there (I could never make sense of the story on this first playthrough), that made me not like this game. It felt slow and tedious, and I found myself constantly just wanting to get to the next thing.
It was also a massive switch from Assassin's Creed Syndicate, which I played immediately before this (the mission with the "Lowlands Away" piano puzzle reignited my interest in the game). The rapid switch from a sprawling industrial city to many small scattered islands with not many buildings on them was a bit much for me.
I'm sure the game is still as amazing as everyone says, and maybe one day in the future I'll give it another go. But for now..... 4/10.

really bad port that you're better off playing on consoles. it will stutter and be crap no matter what your specs are. but you have you to play it here, heres some tips.

nvidia control panel settings >manage 3D> program settings>assassin's creed iv: black flag (sp) (ac4bfsp.exe)
max frame rate 60 - power management mode maximum - texture filering negative lod bais clamp - threaded optimization on - triple buffering on - vertical sync on - virtual reality pre rendered frames 2

game settings max out but tass x2, vertical sync off, phyx off 

EVERYTIME you launch the game and load into your save
ctrl+alt+delete task manager>details>ac4bfsp.exe>right click set affinity>uncheck first and last cpu.>ok>undo what you just did. and go back to the game. 
now log out of windows. windows key+L and log back in. should be mostly smooth 60fps

Ubisoft recently announced they were ending support and taking all of the servers offline for "The Crew." This game was advertised as having single player content. But it requires you to connect to their servers even if you are not playing online. 

What does this have to do with this game? Well it means that all of their games moving forward are potentially just long term rentals that are not advertised as such. This is a very anti-consumer practice. And I cannot in good conscience recommend any games from this publisher when that has the potential to happen to any buyer. Ubisoft could patch these games to remove the online requirement. But they're choosing not to. So that makes their products a very poor value proposition in my opinion.

"Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag" stands out as a gem within the Assassin's Creed series, offering a captivating blend of historical exploration, naval combat, and immersive storytelling. As a dedicated fan of the franchise, diving into the pirate-infested Caribbean during the Golden Age of Piracy was an exhilarating departure from the traditional Assassin's Creed settings.

Compared to its predecessors, "Black Flag" distinguishes itself by focusing more on the swashbuckling adventures of pirates rather than the traditional Assassin versus Templar conflict. However, it cleverly intertwines this pirate tale with the overarching Assassin's Creed narrative, exploring the origins of key elements like the First Civilization artifacts (Pieces of Eden) and the ongoing struggle between the Assassins and Templars.

The game brilliantly connects to the larger Assassin's Creed lore through its modern-day segments, where players assume the role of a research analyst exploring the memories of Edward Kenway, the protagonist. These segments serve as a bridge between Kenway's story and the modern-day conflict, tying the narrative threads together and maintaining the series' continuity.

What makes "Black Flag" particularly praiseworthy is its seamless integration of naval exploration and combat. The open-world sailing, plundering ships, and engaging in naval battles were a highlight, adding depth and variety to the gameplay. It's a testament to how the series evolved by embracing new gameplay mechanics while staying true to its core elements.

However, while the naval gameplay is exceptional, some fans of the series might feel that the focus on piracy overshadowed the traditional Assassin's Creed stealth and parkour mechanics. The balance between land-based exploration and naval gameplay might not resonate equally with all fans, especially those who prefer a stronger emphasis on the Assassin Brotherhood's activities.

Overall, "Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag" is a standout title that successfully expands the series' horizons while staying rooted in its lore. It expertly connects to the broader Assassin's Creed universe through its narrative ties and modern-day segments. I highly recommend this game, especially for fans of open-world exploration, naval combat, and those intrigued by a fresh take on the Assassin's Creed formula. Its thrilling gameplay, rich storytelling, and immersive world make it a must-play for both dedicated fans and newcomers to the series.

Thanks to steam cloud saves, I like to play games on my PC and then continue where I left off on my Steam Deck and vice versa. But this game I had to beat entirely on my deck because I started playing it on the deck and for whatever reason this game doesn't support steam cloud saves, so I couldn't continue on my pc. 

But wait, there's more! You need to install ubisoft piece of shit launcher if you want you play it, ubisoft launcher has its own version of cloud saves for ubisoft titles but for whatever reason, they disabled it for AC Black Flag, so no cloud saves of any kind, you have to finish the game on the device you started playing on. The launcher is utterly useless piece of garbage that requires an internet connection to play A SINGLE PLAYER GAME!

Then there's an entire game mechanic, Kenway's fleet, that is no longer working because for some reason it was tied to online and it looks like ubisoft just shutdown the servers, in my entire 29 hours play through, I haven't been able to access Kenway's fleet even once.

The game itself is good, if you sail the high seas you can find a version without the garbage launcher.

The game as is crashes after 1 second of launch. Configuring it to launch in compatibility with Windows 95 has solved it for me, but it should work out of the box, without trying countless workarounds from the internet.

I'd argue this is one of the best AC games. It strays from the "classical" feeling of the Altair/Ezio era, but I think it does so in a way that benefits the story. The whole arc that Edward goes through really ties in the "Creed" of what makes Assassin's Creed, something I can't say a lot of AC games do. Gameplay also holds up extremely well compared to the other pre-RPG games. Ship sailing feels great and parkouring around settlements and islands is fun. The fighting is pretty alright, gets very same-y but combo'ing between swords and guns is still fun, especially when swashbuckling on enemy ships.

Overall would greatly recommend.

In my opinion this was the last great assassin's creed game and also the best one in the entire series. It is also without a doubt THE BEST pirate video game ever made. The only thing that would make it better is if the assassin's creed part of the story was removed. When you are playing as Edward the world just feels so full of life and adventure. Everything you would want from a pirate game is in here. Treasure maps, bounties, sword and gun fighting, stealing, discovering ancient treasures, ship combat, etc. 

Speaking of ship combat, the ship combat in this game is highly addictive and has a great loop. You start with a pretty average Jackdaw, slowly upgrading it by sacking ships across the Caribbean. You can decide to simply sink ships and recover half of the cargo that floats up, or you can disable the ship and board so you and your crew can engage the enemy crew and take over the ship. This lets you take all the cargo and decide if you want to recruit the survivors, take the ship into your fleet, or sink it. I don't know how this has not been done effectively since this game came out, but the ship combat alone makes this a fun game to play.

Exploration is done extremely well in this game. You can travel all across the Caribbean stopping at pretty much every island there is. Granted, the landscapes aren't 1:1 with reality, but that should't really matter when making a fun pirate game. Every location has so much to find from treasure, relics, shanties, bar fights, gambling, contracts, treasure maps, plantations and their warehouses, and so on. There are also underwater sections that, while they aren't perfect, are pretty engaging and enjoyable. 

A final personal note I would like to add. My favorite part of the game definitely ends up being just sailing the Jackdaw through the waves while listening to my crew sing sea shanties. Can't get enough of that even after years of playing.

TLDR: This is the greatest pirate game ever made to date, that is hiding as an Assassin's Creed game. 10/10

Best Assassin's Creed game up to Syndicate (I have not played any newer than that).

I have never played a naval game like this one. The sailing and ocean battle mechanics are perfect. The sea shanties stay with you for life. The hunt for booty is addictive. The outfits and upgrades are awesome.

The rest of the game? When you're on land, I suppose the gameplay is about as good as any other AC game if not a little better. They finally introduced an option to crouch in this game. It is MIND BOGGLING that you cannot SNEAK in a STEALTH GAME but that's how the previous entries were. There seem to be more places to hide but you're screwed if you use a controller that has any amount of drift.

The insistence on tying the fun pirate gameplay to boring, nonsensical futuristic plot is unfortunate. I groaned every time I had to get out of the animus. I find the overarching plot of this series to be trite and nihilistic, but to each their own. All in all, great game, I still play after I finished when I get the itch for good sailing gameplay, because I don't know of any other game that does it quite as well.

During Black Friday I saw this game (along with a lot of other assassin creed games) on sale for like 5-10$, bought this game because I heard that it was considered to be one of the best assassin creed games and my only experience with assassins creed was playing the first game on the PS3 as a kid (and understanding absolutely nothing), so I wanted to give this series a try as an adult. And after beating the games story, I definitely agree that this game is top tier. The only thing that has aged about this game is it's graphics, and even then, it still holds up decently well considering this game is a decade old. Will probably be one of the few games I 100% complete. Would have payed the full price if I knew what I know now about this game.

Black flag was a master piece. So much to do so much to see. A pirates fantasy. The game was epic, sad, funny, it had it all. My one and only complaint with black flag is all the tailing missions they did get quite repeitive there was a looooot of them. But that's minimal compared to how great this game was. You can tell ubisoft dumped some love into this game. There's so much to do like boarding enemy ships, fighting off tons of guards, shark, whale, and other animal hunting. There's just so much dang stuff to do. The Avenline and Freedom Cry dlcs are definitely worth checking out too. Just a solid entry from ubisoft I would highly reccomend picking this up if you haven't experienced this game yet.

[h1] [b] [i] Wonderful pirate game, lacking Assassin's Creed entry [/i] [/b] [/h1]

[h1] [b] [i] ★★★★★★★☆☆☆ [/i] [/b] [/h1]

Assassin’s Creed® IV Black Flag™ is often hailed is THE BEST Assassin's Creed game to date. That is a pretty daring claim, considering that as of writing this review, there are whopping TWELVE main series entries and SEVENTEEN spin-offs. That's a lot of competition, yet even in 2023, Black Flag supposedly still outclasses both the games that came before it and the ones that came after. I can't help but disagree.

[h1] [i] “Caution's nothing without charisma. If a man plays the fool, then it's only fools he'll persuade. But appear to be the devil... and all men will submit.” [/i] [/h1]

My main contention with the notion of Black Flag being the best AC game is that it is not that great at being one. Black Flag is a pirate game first, Assassin's Creed title second. Now, that is not necessarily a bad thing. The developers decided to work on a fresh take on a series that has, up until this point, felt very samey, often lacking in innovation, even if it was amazing at what it was trying to portray. After the legendary Ezio trilogy and AC 3 serving as a conclusion of Desmond's saga, the base formula had to have been re-worked. Cue Black Flag, where the titular "assassinating" plays second fiddle to being a pirate. Honestly though? It's incredible amount of fun and is one of the best takes of historical pirate characters I have ever seen in entertainment media.

Since the pirating is the main attraction of BF, I may as well start here. Even today, we don't have pirate-themed games focusing on naval combat that do it in as entertaining and intuitive of a way that Black Flag does. Everything from controlling your ship to skirmishes on sea to in-fighting between the British and the Spanish all the way to man-on-man combat when boarding creates immensely satisfying and addictive gameplay loop where you can easily spend dozens of hours just on defeating the opposing ships and seizing their cargo, then using that to improve your own vessel, which is surprisingly expensive and lengthy process, albeit no less satisfying. Everything happening on sea is handled perfectly, 'nuff said.

When you move onto land and land-based activities, you will understand why I mentioned that as a AC game, Black Flag is a little lacking. There is less of everything here than in the previous games - less parkour, less verticality, less gear purchasing and upgrading and less focus on narrative and character development. Now, I know this may be a bit controversial as the story here is often cited as fan favorite but those who played it all the way back, tell me honestly - how much can you really remember about it? It is not that the story is straight up forgettable, it is just not nearly as memorable as the previous entries. Additionally, characters themselves seem less developed. Although I liked Edward better than Connor in AC3, he's got nothing on Ezio or even Altair. Villains are also not as fleshed out as even those in AC3, lacking any outstanding ones like Haytham or Lee. It also has issues with pacing, stretching some parts unnecessarily while glossing over more critical events like Edward being stranded. Overall, though, it is a good story, just not nearly the best in the series.

I want to also point out the lack of attention that the present-timeline aspect got. Yeah, I know that the present was never really the primary focus but as much as I may be in the minority here, it was really important to me, and I really liked how it was handled in the Desmond saga. Unfortunately, in Black Flag, this aspect feels rushed and slightly uninspired. You play as an unnamed Abstergo game/program tester who is tasked with extracting specific data from Edward’s past while getting entangled with the modern Assassins and unwittingly helping them. While an intriguing concept, the execution is lacking and its clear that after Desmond, Ubisoft had no clear idea as to where the modern timeline should proceed.

If I were to sum up my thoughts on Black Flag it would be that it is, without a doubt, one of the best pirate games of all time and is definitely one of the better Assassin’s Creed games, even if it lacks some focus on the series core theme. I see no reason (apart from the current technical challenges) not to recommend giving this a shot no matter whether you are a long-time fan of the franchise as a whole or if this is your entry into it.

[h2] [b] [u] Positives & Negatives [/u] [/b] [/h2]

[table]
[tr]
	[th][b] [i] Positives [/i] [/b][/th]
	[th][b] [i] Negatives [/i] [/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]+ The focus on a pirate theme during the Golden Age of Piracy was a great choice and lends itself well to a combination of traditional AC gameplay combined with much more focus on naval battles than it was in AC 3[/td]
	[td]- Character design is lacking[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]+ The story, although a bit generic and uninspired give its predecessors still feels enjoyable and interesting enough[/td]
	[td]- Parkour, while still great, hasn’t really seen much improvement from AC 3[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]+ Voice-acting is, once again, great[/td]
	[td]- Very small weapon variety with very few new swords or pistols to buy[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]+ Beautiful, albeit a bit forgettable OST (except for shanties, those are legendary)[/td]
	[td]- The fact that the game blue-balls you by giving you the control of much larger type of ship like (Man O’ War type of ship) for a little bit only to never let you purchase and upgrade that type of ship for yourself is incredibly disappointing as using their weapon arsenal feels a thousand times better than even fully upgraded Jackdaw[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]+ Graphics and level design are stellar – the sea and water in general is absolutely stunning while the land-based sceneries can be breathtaking at (especially the Great Inagua) along with beautiful towns like Havana, even after a decade of game being out[/td]
	[td]- Legendary ships designer can very much go walk the plank. I get that they are meant to be the ultimate challenge and are meant to be difficult even with fully upgraded ship but what I do not get is how a ship that’s three times the size of Jackdaw have MUCH better speed and maneuverability than its much smaller counterpart while also enjoying the benefits the ULTIMATE firepower, ram impact or mortar damage… F*ck them and double-f*ck whoever surmised they were well thought-out[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]+ Naval gameplay/battles are the star of AC IV, even if the whole damage ship/defeat crew loop can get slightly repetitive over time. However, all of the activities you can do from actual battles, to upgrading your ship to amazing underwater treasure-hunting make it feel incredibly rewarding[/td]
	[td]- Way too many tailing misssions[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]+ Amazing ship design – from the adorable little Schooners to absolutely massive and menacing Man O’ Wars, they are all designed masterfully[/td]
	[td]- Present timeline is uninspired and does not feel like an improvement to Desmond saga[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]+ Combat and its improvements from 3 feel amazing[/td]
	[td]- For some reason, this is the first mainline Assassins Creed where it is impossible to circumvent the buil-in 60fps lock no matter how hard you try. You were able to unlock in all previous entries and the games worked fine (apart from few specific sections where you needed to re-lock it). It’s a shame[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

This game is incredible. I love the ship-to-ship combat, and it really captures the gameplay aesthetic of sailing the open seas and fighting the navies of the big empires that were racing to take control of the Caribbean. Nothing beats traveling around, listening to sea shanties, and tearing up some british ships for that sweet sweet rum.

I will say though that the weakest part of the game are the Assassin's Creed elements. Truly one of the movement systems in games. The Abstergo storyline gets in the way far too often. Some of the elements of "you're a modern person invading Desmond Miles' DNA Memories" really take you out of the core experience. It would've been better as a pure pirate game.

Overall though it's aged very well and is still quite fun to play.

This is still my top ranked Assassins Creed game. There are some bugs which will never get fixed. But it is a world I truely enjoyed traversing. Played through multiple times now.

Get past the bullcrap future cut scene thing, it's fun running jumping killing.
Once you get your pirate ship the fun really begins!

You'll be singing Drunken sailor and drinking rum while you sail the Caribean, plundering and adventuring. Controls get a bit of getting used to, but it's fairly easy to pick up and to recover from a mistake.

Sea battles take some getting used to skill wise, I prefer the 3rd person long range boat maneuvering of Sid Meiers Pirates because it's simplar and easier to see whats going on, but Black Flag makes you feel more that your in charge of your boat, and you can shout at your crew and make them sing songs.

On land it's fun trying to find treasure and many other things, he's a nimble fellow and running, jumping and climbing needs the minimum of practise, although you'll still keep trying to run up walls 2/3 times in a row before he stops.

Get your buckle and swash it!


*Only con, get rid of the future cut scene thing!*

The hell are the shit present day cut scene crap about in AC games?! They're bloody crap.
I want to pretend to be a pirate, not pretend to be a man at a computer pretending to be a pirate.

Just getting into the game and feeling all Sid Meiers Pirates Gold Amiga CD32 vibes then cuts to a long boring unskippable interactive cut scene with a stupid cow telling me stuff in a lobby, no woman I don't care about you blah blah me pirate you sod off!

I never completed the original AC because of the crap present day cut scene thing, just set the game in the era it starts in!

Every time I start these games the future cut scene Animus rubbish totally ruins the vibe! 
Imagine starting to watch a cool film, then someone runs in your house steals your controller, pauses the film then fucks off 10 minutes down the road to hide your controller so you can't enjoy the film till you find your controller to unpause the movie.

I couldn't give two figs about the future story line, I just watched tv or read while they were waffling their bullcrap about hacking, you can't even run in them, you just wander about slowly while some one talks, I'm litterally not listening! GET RID OF IT!

 I'm a pirate Aaaaaaaarrrrrrrrr I needs me plunder not ye yallygaggin ya future based land lubber!

Luckily I think ACBF has a minimal amount of future bull crappery (so far 4 interactive walk about slowly for no reason, while someone speaks) Scenes - Get past them the game is worth it!

Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag took me on a thrilling pirate adventure that I didn't want to end. Sailing the Caribbean seas as Captain Edward Kenway was an absolute blast. The game beautifully captures the essence of piracy, allowing me to navigate the open waters, engage in epic ship battles, and explore vibrant islands filled with treasures and secrets. The seamless blend of land and naval gameplay provided an exhilarating experience. The story, weaving the Assassin-Templar conflict into the golden age of piracy, kept me engaged throughout, with memorable characters and unexpected twists. Black Flag isn't just an Assassin's Creed game; it's a thrilling pirate saga that left me yearning for more high-seas adventures.

Unfortunately, I can't get it to run properly.

I'll only be able to play the game for a minute or two before it'll freeze up. I scoured various forums looking for troubleshooting techniques, but the dozen or so I tried were unsuccessful. It looks like this has been an outstanding issue since 2014.

When the game's not freezing, the frame times are atrocious.

Edit: I was able to play a few hours by setting the game to Windows 7 compatibility mode, but it started freezing up again during naval combat. Now, my solution is while the game is running, I'll open Task Manager, go into Details, right-click on Black Flag, and set my affinity so all odd cores are disabled. I've been able to play a few hours without any performance issues or freezing since discovering this fix.

"Assassin's Creed® IV Black Flag" is a game that takes players into the thrilling world of piracy and historical adventure. Here's a detailed review with star ratings in various categories:

**Overall Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐☆ (4/5 Stars)**

1. **Graphics: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5 Stars)**
   - **Pro:** The graphics are stunning, featuring beautiful sea landscapes, detailed character models, and vibrant environments.
   - **Contra:** On older systems or lower graphic settings, the graphic performance can suffer.

2. **Gameplay: ⭐⭐⭐⭐☆ (4/5 Stars)**
   - **Pro:** Varied gameplay that allows seamless transitions between sea battles, exploration, and stealth missions.
   - **Contra:** Some repetitive side missions can make the gameplay experience a bit monotonous.

3. **Control: ⭐⭐⭐⭐☆ (4/5 Stars)**
   - **Pro:** Intuitive and responsive controls, especially in combat and ship navigation.
   - **Contra:** Occasional inconsistencies and glitches in parkour control.

4. **Innovation: ⭐⭐⭐⭐☆ (4/5 Stars)**
   - **Pro:** The game introduces innovative elements like sea battles and piracy aspects that refresh the franchise.
   - **Contra:** Despite the innovations, the game remains true to some of the series' familiar formulas in certain aspects.

5. **Story and Atmosphere: ⭐⭐⭐⭐☆ (4/5 Stars)**
   - **Pro:** A captivating story with interesting characters and a convincing historical setting.
   - **Contra:** The main story can sometimes be overshadowed by the numerous side activities.

**Additional Pros and Cons:**

- **Pro:**
  - Impressive open world with many exploration opportunities.
  - Strong sound design and musical score.

- **Contra:**
  - Some players might find the modern segments less appealing.
  - Occasional technical issues and bugs.

Overall, "Assassin's Creed® IV Black Flag" offers a unique and engaging gaming experience that will appeal to both fans of the series and new players. With its strong combination of piracy, exploration, and action, the game sets standards in its genre.
