"Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag" is a title within the Assassin’s Creed franchise that stands out for its adventurous spirit and engaging gameplay. As a game that seamlessly combines the series' signature action and stealth mechanics with an expansive naval experience, it offers a host of compelling reasons why it should be played.

Set in the golden age of piracy, "Black Flag" introduces players to Edward Kenway, a charismatic privateer-turned-pirate who finds himself entangled in the ancient conflict between Assassins and Templars. The narrative is rich, filled with historical intrigue, and features a colorful cast of real-life pirates like Blackbeard and Charles Vane, making it a treasure trove for history buffs.

The game's open-world exploration is one of its most captivating aspects. The Caribbean setting is a sprawling maritime playground with dozens of islands to discover. The sense of freedom as you captain the Jackdaw, Kenway's ship, is exhilarating. Each island and coastal city is meticulously designed, brimming with life and opportunities for adventure.

Naval combat is a core element of "Black Flag" and is executed with thrilling precision. Engaging in ship battles is deeply satisfying, with a need for strategic maneuvering and resource management that adds a layer of depth to the gameplay. Upgrading the Jackdaw is both necessary and rewarding, as it allows players to take on more formidable enemy ships and fortresses.

When it comes to traditional Assassin’s Creed gameplay, "Black Flag" does not disappoint. The stealth and parkour mechanics are refined, allowing for fluid movement through the game's various environments, whether it's a bustling port town or a dense jungle. The combat system is robust, offering a variety of weapons and tactics to approach each encounter.

Graphically, "Black Flag" is a visual feast. The game beautifully captures the Caribbean's crystal-clear waters, lush landscapes, and stormy weather, creating an immersive and dynamic world. The attention to detail extends to the bustling towns and the historically accurate ships that ply the game’s seas.

The sound design is equally impressive, with an atmospheric soundtrack that features sea shanties sung by Kenway's crew, which adds to the authenticity of the seafaring experience. The voice acting is top-notch, with performances that bring depth and personality to each character.

"Black Flag" also delves into the lore of the Assassin’s Creed universe, expanding upon the series' mythos in interesting ways. The modern-day storyline continues, providing connections to the larger narrative of the franchise.

The game offers a vast array of activities beyond the main story, including hunting for treasure, harpooning, and taking on assassination contracts. This richness of content ensures that there is always something new to discover, making the game highly replayable.

In summary, "Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag" is an exceptional title that successfully marries the franchise's traditional elements with innovative naval mechanics. It's a game that captures the romance and brutality of piracy, offering an adventure that is as deep as the oceans it allows players to explore. For its compelling narrative, vibrant open world, and thrilling naval combat, "Black Flag" is a game that deserves to be experienced by any fan of the action-adventure genre.

For the fps, you can increase it to 144 in an ini file, but under no circumstances should someone have to access an ini file for 144hz for a AAA game on Steam. Yes, it's a AAA game. It was a AAA game when it came out, and it will remain that way. You can't tell me that Super Mario Bros on the NES isn't a AAA game.

Otherwise, it's one of the best AC games. Up there with the older games like 1, 2, etc.

Assassin's Creed 4: Black Flag is, as the title suggest, about being a pirate in 18th century Caribbean. You roam the high seas, board and ransack ships that come across your way. You explore for hidden treasures, purchase upgrade and gather your crew. Pretty straightforward. A huge map filled with many icons and collectibles, as is custom with any AC game. Although belongs to the Assassin's Creed franchise, it works perfectly as a pirate-themed game in itself.

This game's main quest is quite brilliant. The writing is best in any Assassin's Creed game, and in comparison to other games still quite good. Characters are well memorable, dialogue is exceptionally witty, clever, and accurate to the style and vocabulary of the time period it tries to portray. Rarely have I seen so engaging lines, pure pleasure to listen and read. As a nice detail, some words are even randomly capitalised in subtitles, as was custom during the time. One detail I loved was the sea shanties, that your ship's crew sings and really brings atmosphere to the game.

Setting the modern day story, in a quite-literally evil multinational corporation is a nice ironic jab at the corporate office culture. I didn't think playing around in a virtual office building could be fun would be so fun but here I am proven wrong.

However, you must still remember this is an Ubisoft game, with all of its negatives in mind. As the game says at one point:
"Have fun... pirating..."
This game is super fun there is a lot of action and adventure. 10/10 would recommend

I initially gave a negative appraisal of this game, which I'd like to reconsider.

It requires a lot of patience to get used to the AC franchise particularly if it's your first time and you're expecting similar combat/gunfight features to other games. I initially found this frustrating, particularly the naval battles in which you are being overrun by well resourced Spanish Navy vessels.

It took me 3 weeks to overcome those issues and I eventually found the game to my liking. In fact the very aspect that frustrated me before has now turned into what excites me the most: the conquest of enemy ships! It gives you a rush of adrenaline every time when you locate a ship to attack, incapacitate it and board it to plunder.

Game can be a bit repetitive at times but the landscapes and colours are gorgeous, the locations so well designed (Havana in particular). As someone who grew up on a tropical island those locales appeal greatly to me, with their plantation crops and beaches. A number of missions are not straightforward at all and require quite a level of brain-racking, which makes completion more satisfactory.

I don't know if I'll be purchasing another game from the AC franchise but considering how little I paid for this game which is a decade old and how well it holds up, I can't complain much.

7 sea shanties out of 10

Pros
+ Absolutely huge game. If you are into collectibles and exploration, this is your game. 
+ Memorable characters, especially Mary.
+ Diverse world environments compared to other AC games, taking you from jungles on the western coast of Africa to the tropical islands of the Caribbean to the swamps of early colonial US.
+ The feel of sailing, fighting other ships, boarding, harpooning, and all things water are exceptionally well done. 

Cons
- Lighthouses. Underwater movement is clunky.
- A high number of bugs experienced. Nothing a reset mission couldn't fix, with the exception of Conway's Fleet not loading which was a bummer. 
- Combat is very repetitive, as it always is in AC. Block + counter. Stagger + swing. That is about it, although at least this AC includes some diversity with different dart types. 
- The rope dart is way too cool to get 80% of the way through the story. I would have loved to have used it throughout the game.

Overall, it was my favorite AC game I have played and worth checking out, but not without its warts.

I bought AC 3 and Black Flag because I really loved AC2 and Brotherhood and I wanted to give these games a chance. So after I pulled myself through the walking simulator that is AC3 I didn´t come with the highest expectations and yet I got dissapointed.


The gameplay is really boring. You basically just need 2 buttons to win every battle. The guns and swords that you can buy for your character are just for estatics. Your character is unnecassarily overpowered and it is impossible to connect with him in any way, as the story is written so badly. You meet characters who are not even remotely interesting or charismatic and somehow you are supposed to feel some connection towards them. The death of one of them is supposed to be a game changer but i really couldn´t care less.
They could have made it in an interesting way, but they decided to roll with the "you remember when you pulled of that cool crazy thing? good that we don´t have to show it" move (example: Kennway reclaiming back his ship after being left for dead on an island).

So instead of writing an engaging story, Ubisoft decided to fill its map with islands with nothing but unnecessary collectables. Furthermore they make you buy unnecessary stuff in random locations like shops and other upgrades that don´t help you in any way, because you can basically Leeroy Jenkins every mission, except of the "stealth" missions, that make you just eavesdrop on random people. 

BTW. The AI doesn´t care the slightest about people that have been slaughtered around them. "Oh there were 3 corpses thrown from this roof. Mh must be the season of the year again."

Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag is a game that both thrilled and frustrated me. Let me begin by discussing the technical issues encountered, which you should be aware of before purchasing the game on Steam.

- Ubisoft Connect Compatibility: If you already own ACIVBF on Ubisoft Connect, avoid buying it on Steam or activating it on the same Ubisoft Account. Doing so may lead to having two copies of the game on your Ubisoft Connect account, causing conflicts that prevent the original copy from connecting to online servers. Despite efforts to resolve this through customer support, the issue persisted for me.

- Save File Incompatibility: ACIVBF save files are not transferable between Ubisoft Connect and Steam versions. If you have progress on one platform and plan to buy the game on another, be cautious, as the save file might be considered corrupted on the new platform.

Ubisoft's customer support was unsatisfactory in resolving these problems, causing a frustrating experience lasting several months.

Now, let's focus on the game itself, which truly is a masterpiece, appreciated for its naval combat and pirate theme. The standout aspect is Edward Kenway's character and his well-crafted narrative. With an engaging story, compelling supporting characters, memorable antagonists, and a stellar ending, the game shines in storytelling. Additionally, the gameplay is brilliant, combining both assassin and pirate elements seamlessly.

Initially, I was disappointed with the abundance of ship gameplay, not aligning with the traditional Assassin's Creed style. However, it fits perfectly within the pirate theme and offers enjoyable naval combat even for those who aren't typically drawn to such gameplay. The assassin elements blend harmoniously with the pirate gameplay, especially in the way Edward becomes entangled in the conflict between the assassins and templars. Witnessing Edward's growth throughout the story is highly satisfying.

Regarding the present-day storyline, the absence of Desmond and the altered gameplay was a letdown, but it eventually became engaging and intriguing on its own terms, even though it didn't match the level of Assassin's Creed III.

One aspect that falls short in ACIVBF is the parkour, but I don't mean the system. The gameplay and animation is an upgrade from Assassin's Creed III, the animations being better in my opinion. The lack of expansive cities found in previous games diminishes the parkour experience. Despite my initial skepticism about ship-centric gameplay, I found it to be well-suited for this title and fun to play. But the lack fluid parkour most of the gameplay does take from the Assassin's Creed experience, but I don't think there was anything they could have done better. That's the era, that's the places where the story takes place.

Combat, on the other hand, feels slightly downgraded compared to Assassin's Creed III, though other aspects like running and climbing show significant improvement.

For achievement hunters: ACIVBF has an extensive list of 60 achievements, but unfortunately, Steam doesn't implement them. This can be disappointing for completionists and achievement hunters. To view your achievements, you can check Ubisoft Connect, but even there, you can't share your achievements progress, only you can see it. To add to it, there's the lack of any in-game notifications for earning achievements.
I am planning to complete this game in the future. I will then come back and share my thoughts on the achievements.

In conclusion, Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag is an exceptional game that seamlessly combines the pirate theme with assassin gameplay. With captivating narrative, outstanding characters, and exciting gameplay, making it a memorable and unique experience.

"Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag" is not just a game; it's a swashbuckling adventure that immerses you in a rich, expansive world of piracy, espionage, and exploration. Set sail for the Caribbean in the golden age of piracy and prepare to be captivated by one of the finest entries in the Assassin's Creed series.

The first thing that strikes you about Black Flag is its breathtaking open world. The Caribbean is your oyster, and it's teeming with life. The crystal-clear waters, lush tropical islands, bustling cities, and treacherous jungles are all beautifully rendered. The attention to detail is nothing short of astounding, making every corner of the map a pleasure to explore. Whether you're hunting for buried treasure, engaging in naval battles, or infiltrating enemy strongholds, the world feels alive and immersive.

The star of the show is undoubtedly your ship, the Jackdaw. Sailing the high seas, upgrading your vessel, and engaging in epic naval battles is an absolute joy. The sensation of wind in your sails, the thunder of cannons, and the thrill of boarding enemy ships make every naval encounter a memorable experience. It's rare to see a game where the ship itself is a beloved character, but Black Flag pulls it off flawlessly.

The story, centered around the charismatic rogue assassin Edward Kenway, is engaging and full of twists and turns. Edward's character arc is a rollercoaster ride of personal growth and moral complexity. The game's blend of historical and fictional characters, including appearances by Blackbeard and Charles Vane, adds depth to the narrative and creates a sense of authenticity within the pirate-infested Caribbean.

Gameplay-wise, Black Flag shines on multiple fronts. The series' trademark parkour and assassination mechanics are seamlessly integrated into the open world, allowing for fluid and exhilarating rooftop chases and stealthy takedowns. The combat is fast-paced and satisfying, and Edward's dual-wielding of swords and pistols adds a unique flair to the proceedings.

The sea shanties sung by your crew as you sail add a layer of charm that's hard to resist. These tunes not only provide a soundtrack to your journey but also serve as a reminder of the camaraderie among your motley crew.

"Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag" is a triumph in storytelling, world-building, and gameplay. It strikes a perfect balance between the series' signature elements and the thrill of pirate life. With a vast, open world to explore, a captivating storyline, and unforgettable naval battles, this game is a treasure trove of gaming excellence. Raise the black flag, set sail, and prepare to be hooked on this unforgettable adventure on the high seas. It's a swashbuckling masterpiece that will leave you yearning for more, long after the credits roll.

Assassin’s Creed: Black Flag doesn’t feel as polished as the Ezio trilogy or the earlier games. The parkour feels like you have less control over it and is more focused on animations than good traversal. Combat is a mixed bag; it feels about as complex/simple as the earlier games with some added gadgets. I liked the addition of berserk and sleep darts.Ship combat feels like you spam rotate through all weapons. (My pc does slow when broadside cannons fire and a million smoke particles appear) Boarding ships becomes repetitive quite quickly.

Mission design is what ruined the game for me. There are memorable or good ones but they are pretty repetitive and they feel like lots of filler.

Gameplay wise the modern period is boring as hell, walk around and play some dumb hacking mini game while someone lore dumps you. I feel if they made the character you play as an actual character with voice lines instead of a self insert it would be better.

Story is fine, feels a bit lacklustre in the modern period but Edward Kenway is a compelling enough character.

The best Creed Game

Yarr, mateys, raise the Black Flag! There be only hardtack for rations but that won't stop us from plundering every ship we  see and relieving it of all it's valuables! Raise the sails and chart a course, a new adventure awaits! Blackbeard said to meet him in Tortuga!

Unfortunately, this is a Ubisoft game and comes with the caveats of such, and I also blame this game for kickstarting the trend of Assassin's Creed games completely forgetting about the Templars vs Assassins conflict and just plopping their core gameplay into any random historical setting they can think of. Nonetheless, gameplay-wise, this is a classic Assassin's Creed game through and through and with it's excellent worldbuilding, this has also become one of the definitive pirate adventure games out there. If you love pirates and seafaring, if you love AC, or both, then Assassin's Creed IV is a must play.

The core of an AC game is here. The parkour feels great, just like the old games. The level design is very well made, feeling natural, while providing plenty of paths to go through. Stealth and combat is gimmicky, but it's what we know and love. Graphics have that distinct mid-2010s look, but still hold up surprisingly well to this day, especially the water. The music is damn excellent too. There's plenty to do in the open world, without devolving into a full blown Ubish!t collectathon chore list. The story itself, while odd to be set in the Caribbean, still centers around Assassins and Templars, the writing is excellent and it doesn't go on any longer than it needs to. Plenty of real life history was also intertwined with the original lore and it's awesome to meet all these historical figures. The characters themselves are charming and engaging, there is real conflict that draws you in and Edward Kenway is an exciting morally grey protagonist. 

The greatest strength of Black Flag of course is the setting. The Caribbean and the Golden Age of Piracy are represented in an amazing way and it's just a joy to immerse yourself in this world, even well after finishing the main story. Beautiful exotic locations, ships of all colonial nations sailing around for you to rob, forts to raid, treasure maps to follow, sea shanties to sing, fish to catch and so much more. This game truly makes you feel like a pirate and provides a superbly fun experience that can be enjoyed at any time. Sailing around is very fun and the controls for both the sailing itself and naval combat are as simple and intuitive as possible. The AC mechanics like the parkour actually integrate surprisingly well into this context and all the systems enhance each other greatly. 

In conclusion, Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag is one of the last, if not THE last, truly good entry into the franchise. A fresh take on the classic formula, while also retaining the heart and soul that made AC games special and unique in the first place. It introduced enough new mechanics without compromising the core gameplay loop and turning into some weird Zelda clone. And best of all, this game really makes you feel like a badass pirate and let's you immerse yourself in this legendary time period. I mean, Black Flag single handedly kickstarted the rise in popularity of sea shanties. There's a good reason why even a decade after it's release, this game is still revered and remembered so fondly and why to this day, unlike so much other Ubitrash, people keep coming back to it again and again. It's definitely worth a play, so come on and set sail together with us! Cabin boy, start us off and let's sing the Drunken Sailor together! We got plenty of rum below the deck and we still got ways to go till Nassau!

As far as "modern", or at least more recent, single player games go Assassins Creed Black Flag is probably one of the best pirate setting games you will play. With the release of the One Piece live action at the time of this review this will be a game that will scratch that itch of playing pirate and having a great mix of sea and land adventures to keep things fresh. 

For a game that released in 2013, it honestly holds up well to this day, and probably one of the more solid contenders to the Assassins Creed lines. Certainly a core of the "classic" game play over the RPG grindy game play take of the modern titles. Believe it or not, there was a time where stealth and parkour mechanics are critical and icon to the Assassins Creed and Black flag gives you option to either be the pirate version of Rambo with swashbuckling boldness or play the game as a stealthy killer in the shadows. This symbiotic relationship between stealth and action is what really makes this game one of the peak of it's series.

This game has one of the weirdest/stupidest climbing and stealth mechanics in all of the Assassin's Creed games. 

First off. Whenever you're running in a town or forest, you'll randomly try to climb whatever is near you which makes it difficult when it comes to chasing or tailing as when they start running you either grab onto walls and get too far from the target or dare face the rooftop enemies that can ALWAYS SEE YOU and make you have to detour to killing them. 

Secondly. THERE'S NO CROUCH. Every time when I try to sneak up on enemies or try to sneak around them, I'm always spotted by them because i cant crouch and running make too much noise. This makes the game very annoying and difficult to play.

If you've read all of this before buying it. Just get a different game and save you're money.(I do recommend Assassin's Creed Origins, Odyssey, Valhalla or Unity)

Still the best AC game for me.
- gameplay is fabulous 
- setting is magical (colors of nature, sand, small islands, houses, settlements and major locations are really picturesque, and water... yeah, the color and shades of water here are something our of this world... -truely magnificent)
- ship battles are engaging and fun, underwater exploration with its half-horror wibes of being bitten and stung, works perfectly for me
- assassin stuff is beareable (tailing missions are just almost too much, but synchronizations, contracts, chases, assassins vs templars story in present - all evens out neatly)
- side quests and crafting are rewarding and fun, loved the mayan armor and pistol-swords (but all the abstergo fragments and chests God knows where... might be a little too much)
- main story... rarely that game makes me relate so much to characters and fills me with such deep sadness, when it is finished. It's a shame you can't save them all, but boy do I wish to...

It would be safe to say that for me Ubisoft "captured lightning in a bottle" with this one.

Being forced to use UbiSoft can cause issues. The issue I had here was that Steam is installed on my C drive and UbiSoft is installed on my D drive. How do I know this? I have Epic installed on the D drive, too. Some of us are hardcore gamers, and even 2TB isn't enough space for all of our games. I have 2 - 2TB SSDs. I use the exact same email address for Steam and UbiSoft. One of my Steam-UbiSoft games was registered while UbiSoft was still installed on the C drive.

The first Steam support rep was unaware that they have a CD key for you. That is unacceptable. I was told that they do not use the keys anymore. 

UbiSoft support is utterly incompetent. I had to provide proof-of-purchase 3 times, my Steam ID twice, then send logs, delete the cache file, re-install, and STILL it was asking me for a CD key. I was getting ready to uninstall the game on Steam and ask for a refund. I right-clicked the game, and saw "CD Key". The second Steam support rep had written at some point in-between to inform me of this, but I hadn't bothered reading the email, because the first one said I had to deal with UbiSoft.

So, customer support in Steam is hit-and-miss; customer support in UbiSoft is miss-miss-miss. Since Epic has sales on games in this franchise, and I do not have to deal with any stupidity, I've been buying the rest over there. I will keep an eye on them over here, BUT given that I just paid 17.99€ for Origins Gold in Epic Games, where Steam wants 89€, I don't know if I will be finding them on deep-sale over here.

I posted to try to make people aware of the insane price differences, 79PLN, $69, and 89€ (which is 16€, 62€, and 89€ when translated all into Euros), but Steam deleted my post and warned me not to bump posts just to get attention. It is not the first time that Steam has made some insane claim against me as an excuse to delete a comment or post that they do not like.

As to the game itself, I cannot yet say. I will update this later. However, Steam needs to make a deal so that other companies behave like Paradox. Paradox invites you to set-up an account and gives you benefits for using your Paradox account. You CAN launch your game from their platform, but you do not HAVE to, like you do with EA and UbiSoft.

Part 7 of my 2023 replay through the Assassin's Creed series. This is it. The big boi. The riskiest experiment in the series until Origins. One that paid off in spades! This game is an absolute masterpiece!

A common critique you'll hear is "Black Flag is a great pirate game, but not a great Assassin's Creed game" and I completely disagree. Everything you love (or maybe don't love) that makes an AC game is here: parkour, stealth, eagle vision, leaps of faith, hidden blades, collectibles, unlockable robes, and most importantly the Assassins vs Templar conflict being a central part to the story. Yes there are heavy pirate elements to it, but that is just due to the setting. This would be like saying "Assassin's Creed II is a great Italian Renaissance game, not a great Assassin's Creed game."

In my opinion, Edward's journey is the best of any of our main protagonist Assassins. To see him grow from a rotten scoundrel pirate fueled only by greed to a man far more reflective of his actions and finding more important things to fight for; it's one filled with many moments of heartbreak and triumph.

It's 2023 and this game still looks absolutely breathtaking. Bright, colorful, and immersive. The light blue-green of the water looks so inviting and makes me want to just dive in IRL for a swim. The forests, islands, and cities look great too. The character models, while unique and recognizable, are probably the one thing that may look a bit dated. But you'll be too busy being entranced by some of the best voice acting performances in gaming history to give a hoot.

Seriously, this game deserves more awards than it got for the acting alone. Blackbeard, [spoiler] Mary Read [/spoiler], Stede Bonnet, Calico Jack, and many other famous names from the golden age of piracy are brought to life in incredible fashion. Stacked on top of a S-tier performance of the star character Edward Kenway.

The land combat is similar to that of III with fewer weapons to select from. A trade-off for the expanded sea combat I'm sure. Both were tons of fun for me though. Every combo-kill or cannon-fire felt satisfying. Tools like the rope dart and smoke bomb are still a blast to use. Rocking four pistols felt elite. 

My biggest disappointment with this entry would have to be the modern day. Movement is slow. The mini games are more tedious than anything. The unlockable content ranges from witty videos to useless rants on notes. My favorite being the audio logs of the first Animus experiments, those I would say are worth seeking out. Ultimately, the stakes just don't feel like they're there like they did during the Desmond games. With how nuts and open to possibilities AC:III ended it's really unfortunate they couldn't find more to do.

This remains the only game (so far) that I have 100% completed. Often I get burned out on collectibles, or find certain optional objectives for missions to be not worth the headache. I loved playing Black Flag so much that I never felt like I wasted a second completing everything. That should speak to the fun of this entry.

Buy it. Play it. This should be on every person's gaming bucket list.

Good game.

Definitely the best game of the series, but Ubisoft manages to fuck everything up and make this unplayable. Only after messing around with you're Ubisoft account, steam settings, game settings, Ubisoft launcher settings and game files are you able to play, and it still crashes every now and then. No wonder you pulled this entirely out of Steam.

[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- Even after all this time, the game still has moments where it looks pretty good (particularly when you're firing off grapeshot in a hurricane). Outside of that, you can definitely see the age with the clunkiness of some character animations and dated textures. Still not too shabby for a decade old game
- The setting is refreshing. AC games are pretty good in choosing interesting points in (usually Western) history to explore, and this one is no different
- The music is pretty great. Everyone loves a good sea shanty
- Being a AAA game, the voice acting is what you'd expect. Good performances all around

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- I'll be frank, I stopped paying attention to the overarching AC story sometime midway through ACII: Revelations. It's mercifully shoved way in the background and mostly (outside of a few scenes) optional in this game
- Unfortunately, the in-Animus story is sort of a let down as well. You just kind of aimlessly sail around the Caribbean as Edward, being sent from waypoint to waypoint to sneak into a fort and kill a dude. Someone being conflicted about his relationship for a decade before deciding to raise his kid and become an assassin doesn't make for much of a story
- There a few worthwhile characters. Blackbeard is an interesting character study, Captain Kidd has the most motivating story arc in the game
- Despite the story being negligible in nearly every regard, sailing around can be relaxing if you're into that sort of thing

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- Refusing to change, enhance, iterate on, or improve both the stealth or combat gameplay in any noticeable regard was a bold choice. Not a good choice, but bold
- At least the sailing and naval combat are nice. Sailing felt clunky in AC3, but it's much more polished this time around given that it's a core component of Black Flag
- Despite all the ship upgrades, I found myself just relying on the regular cannons and the heavy shot. The other stuff like mortars and mines were situationally useful when I remembered that I installed them, but I never felt like they were actually necessary. Just by armor, crew, and heavy ammo
- This is a replay (played it around release in 2013 on the 360), and I think this is my last go-around in this game. Hey, at least they managed to finally get me to care about collectibles (gotta hear all the shanties)

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- A lot of people seem to remember this one fondly due to the sailing and naval combat, but neither of those really save it from feeling like just another AC game at heart
- Being a 10 year old game, it ran very well
- You will, of course, have to use Ubisoft's terrible, frivolous, and clunky launcher to play this game. Lécher le cul, Yves

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]7/10[/b]. Compared to the preceding AC games it's roughly on par with AC2: Brotherhood (story/characters are worse, but gameplay is better). Black Flag is a pretty good game, but I'll always feel like this series never reached its full potential

I LIEK IT

The gameplay is fantastic when you pilot and fight with the ship. The story however is trash. 

The story is linear and almost on rails as per usual and the characters are bland and very few people actually stand out as interesting. Even when writing a single linear experience they still manage to f*ck it up this badly. The story is so surreal and unpersonal, it's like they asked a computer to write it. I can't imagine a human writing something this out of touch with emotions and how normal humans function in situations.

some spoilers below

The main character is quite boring and his goals are left in some weird psydo state. He says he fights for money but even when he has a ship large enough to buy half an island he still refuses to do something for himself. The whole game is left in some wierd state where the main character despite being some bigshot is left pushed around by various people into all sorts of shitty "adventures" that has nothing with his own agenda. The whole game is like a fever dream were things happen without logic or sense. 

At the start of the game you get a showcase of the story and it's all downhill from there. 
Two people of opposing factions left injured on the beach, barely alive after a shipwreck, and then in the next second both start jumping like some ballerina dancers around the island chasing after one another. It's bizzare. What should have been a slow scene of two stranded injured people fighting instead turnes into a ballerina contest to showcase the game mechanics. That's how little thought was put into the story. 

Later the story shoehorns you into a assassin helper offcourse. The first thing the 
assassins leader does is to litterally complain about you defending yourself against them when you briefly helped deliver some info to the templars some time ago. It's such a stupid take that it mindboggling how dumb this questline is. They assume you somehow know that the masked assailants that attacked you randomly on the streets were assassins before you even met and learned about their organization and then what, you were supposed to drop dead and stop defending yourself? It so dumb I can't really know what to say.

The story is without any real choices and not player driven in any way. This along with the tedious assassin/termplar garbage makes it super unpersonal and uninteresting. 
I wish I could create my own character and perhaps make my own decisions about who I join and who I kill. But no, this is all written and decided for me by the wonderful team of people at Ubisoft.

The story in it's critical moments like the death of important characters plays out like fever dreams without any logic or sense. Blackbeard dying from fighting on an enemy ship, a ship you both for some reason decided to board to fight hand to hand outnumbered instead of from your own ship? It's like a soldier would jump out of his tank to fight and to hand with the enemy instead of using his arsenal? 
Mary and another woman saved from the cells by a fit assassin and you a mangled half corpse, just rescued from the cells yourself. The fit assassin helps the able woman and they walk out together and you are left alone with the the near unconcious one who's sickly and laying down? You are forced to drag her out while soldiers are after you, you drag and crawl back to the boat where they happily wait? 
What the f*ck is that cutscene? No one sees any problem with that? You can't convince me that a normal human wrote this and thought it made sense. 

Most of the story in the game is laughable without any logic or sense. It's like the writers were doing heavy drugs.

Don't get me wrong, AC4 is one of the best and strongest titles in the series. The problem here however is the terrible state in which you have to play the game.

Constant lags, stuttering, screen freezing for like 15 seconds every minute or so if unlucky, every 5 minutes if lucky.
Just for the sake of completionism I went through this absolute disaster all the way to the end, but couldn't bother with any side content or even Freedom Cry as the longer I played the worse the technical problems were. No amount of changes to the settings or files has fixed this issue. 
Considering that before this the game was not playable at all for about a month, I have very little hope that this game will technically get better/fixed past this point.

It's shameful what Ubisoft has done to this game and I wouldn't blame a single person for pirating it for the sake of getting a more stable version.

Black Flag was one of the first games I played other than Minecraft in 2014-ish (I wasn't on steam but on Xbox). Recently, I decided to play it again, to decided weather It was as good as I remember, or If I just didn't have experiences of actual good games. Fortunately my second experience of the game went incredibly well, and to get over the minor negatives first I must say enjoyed mostly everything about it other than the fact that it was made by U-play, and the combat was simplistic/un-challenging. BUT other than that, the feeling of progression in Equipment, Outfits, Ship upgrades, island progression, to scenery, story-line. And the special enjoyment of just simply sailing around listing to sea shanties, taking over other ships and forts (literally almost everything was good) it was amazing even for an old game going up against the latest "Triple-A Games". Overall the game is incredibly well put together and is 100% worth playing if you have the time. Playing it again is fun if it's been a long time but not that re-playable if that's what you are aiming for in this game (which is weird because this kind of game has not really been known for that play-style anyway). Anyways, I do recommend this game to everyone up for a good gaming experience and story but not so much if you are looking for a combat focused, challenging, and repayable game...                      peepoGlad :rose:

This is an all around fantastic game with a well thought out naval combat and an amazing step up in immersive graphics. The setting really helped sell the improved atmosphere within the game giving it a brighter, more appealing look. The combat is essentially unchanged from AC3, only with different weapons. Brings the modern feeling of AC3 with a landscape that actually favors parkour. There is so so much to explore with one of the biggest AC open worlds and makes you really feel like you can choose what you want to do at any time. With virtually endless play time it is a fun way to kill time. After the slight bore of the Conner storyline, Edwards character progression over the course of this game is a delight as he slowly drifts away from his money mindset to accommodate the brotherhood's creed, while still showing his pirate side in all of his actions. I am also impressed with the way they managed to keep the modern plot alive, choosing to include the player in the game rather than abstract us into controlling Desmond. Also a nice touch of including all the Desmond related content for all the players that understand his story from the previous games. All in all a wonderful package, amazing game, and a worthy continuation of the franchise.

While the game is good, Ubisoft's decision to hobble it with mandatory Ubisoft Connect login means that even getting into it is a painful slog each time. Even after syncing your Steam account with Uplay, you will STILL have to key in your password EACH time you login. A quick browse of steam support forums shows that Ubisoft is aware of it, but just don't care - it's a "security feature" for "older titles". I.e., screw you, we're not fixing or supporting this. 

Don't believe me? This is on Ubi's own website: https://www.ubisoft.com/en-us/help/purchases-and-rewards/article/recurring-log-in-requests-in-ubisoft-connect-pc/000098260#:~:text=To%20ensure%20a%20secure%20connection,will%20then%20launch%20as%20normal.

So yeah. Decent game locked behind terrible login methods, because Ubi just cannot abide buyers forking out hard-earned cash having a halfway decent experience on a "competing" platform.

[b] Revisiting the Past [/b]

Assassin's Creed Black Flag holds a unique place in my gaming journey. Back when I was younger, it was one of the titles that truly captured my imagination. Now, I've taken the opportunity to dive back into this game to relive those memories and experience the magic once again.

One of the standout features that I loved then and still do now is the sea shanties. Sailing on the open sea, with those tunes in the background, creates an atmosphere that's hard to match. It's like being transported to a different time, and it's something that I've missed in more recent games.

Returning to Assassin's Creed 4, I'm reminded of how it managed to create a compelling world of piracy and exploration. The attention to detail in the ships, the environment, and the overall setting is remarkable. Sailing through the waves, engaging in naval battles, and uncovering hidden treasures – it all adds up to an adventure that's both exciting and nostalgic.

Speaking of nostalgia, I can't help but compare the series' current direction to the days of Black Flag. After Assassin's Creed Syndicate, the franchise seemed to take a different path. While there have been good moments, the magic that made this game special appears to have faded a bit.

Revisiting Assassin's Creed 4 has been a journey of rediscovery for me. It's not just about playing a game; it's about connecting with a part of my gaming history and reliving the excitement that it brought me. If you're looking for a way to relive the past and experience a piece of gaming history, I'd definitely recommend setting sail with Edward Kenway once more.

Reliving memories, one virtual voyage at a time.

+ Awesome Pirate Feel

I am a pirate, born in Nassau. Of course, I was not born a pirate. My father was a shipbuilder, and my mother was a farmer. At the age of twelve, I lost them - a group of disloyal and unjust pirates changed my fate. I thought I would join the navy and pursue these pirates around the world, but I was wrong. I was born in Nassau, and even though my parents were ordinary people, I still shed the blood of pirates.

All of this is because I was born in Nassau.

I started stealing and used the stolen money to exchange for rum at Anne's tavern. This is pirate money, and it's not clean either. Let's use this money to help me, the poor man.

To this day, I still remember the first time I saw that man. His body was even bigger than a black beard, and the moment I reached into his waist bag, the tip of the knife was already on my neck.

But his double swords were clearly shining with a terrifying cold light on his waist.

Kid, this little money is making you crazy? "He took off his hood," It's a pirate material. Would you like to be a buddy for my Jackdaw

I just saw his outfit clearly. He didn't wear a captain's hat, but covered the upper half of his face with a hood. Although his beard was shaky, his blonde hair was meticulously combed, and his clothes were not as easy to move as other pirates, but more like a long robe. Leather armor protected his chest, wrists, and shoulders, and his wrists looked particularly thick. His chest was like the legendary pirate's black beard, hanging four handguns.

My name is Edward, "he continued." It's not Edward Teach, it's Edward Kenway. From now on, I'll be your captain

This may be my chance to avenge myself. I will follow him to the sea and find that group of disloyal and unjust pirates.

Captain Kenway is completely different from the pirates I have seen. He seems very indifferent to money, and the money and goods from the robbery are distributed to us. He is always staring at a map. He is even more terrifying than ordinary pirates. I have never seen more than a dozen pirates that the British people cannot deal with. Sometimes, with just a gentle punch, the British sailor falls down in pain and blood. He is no different from ordinary pirates, and he will not let go of the ships in his sight, whether navy, merchants, or bounty hunters. He is very different from other pirates, never passing by and always looking east.

He often talks about "the wealth that cannot be spent in a lifetime", listening to Chief Officer Advall saying that it is a place called the "Observatory", where Captain Kenway has been longing for the treasure since he set sail.

On a very ordinary day, the Jackdaw stayed near Cape Guarico, and the Caribbean sun was still scorching, mixed with the salty taste of the sea, making me feel dull and suffocating. I was dozing off on the deck of the Jackdaw when the first mate suddenly shouted, "Yang Fan, set sail

But I didn't see Captain Kenway.

So, the Jackdaw departed, and no one knew where Captain Kenway had gone except for Advall.

The Jackdaw set sail again, and in half a year, we sailed across the Caribbean Sea. I met legendary captains from all walks of life, snatched various gold and silver treasures, told women my adventure stories, used my fists to teach gangsters a lesson, and even found a group of disloyal and unjust pirates, personally cutting off their captains' heads.

But I still haven't seen Captain Kenway.

But he wouldn't just disappear on the sea like this. Even if Blackbeard died, he wouldn't die because it was real. So he appeared, and six months later, on another scorching day, I met him at Anne's tavern. I watched him and Anne walk from the tavern to the beach from a distance on the deck, and Chief Officer Advall walked towards them from the ship, hugging Captain Kenway, although I couldn't hear their conversation clearly, But there is a sentence that I am deeply impressed with and still cannot understand.

Everything is empty, all actions are allowed

From that day on, Advall left the Jackdaw and Anne became the new mate.

I still live the days of burning, killing, and looting, but the captain seems to have become less greedy. When he talks about the observation post, his eyes also change, no longer yearning for endless wealth. His eyes seem to see other things that have surpassed the understanding of pirates.

I have completed my revenge, but I want to know what he is longing for.

On this day, we arrived at Cape Guarico again, with the scorching sun shining on the deck of the Jackdaw. The salty taste of the sea became even stronger, as if it would reappear some day six months ago.

But this time, the captain came out, covered in blood and without treasure, but he revealed joy that I had never seen before.

Let's go home and invite everyone to drink

This is the coldest banquet we have ever had, and the big pirates are not here. Annie is singing, and Captain Kenway is toasting to the empty seats reserved for the captains, as if they are all there. He burst into tears, but he had never laughed so happily before.

This scene makes me feel very sad, but I don't understand whether the captain is crying or laughing.

A sailor rushed from the dock and whispered a few words in the captain's ear. The captain widened his eyes and looked at him. Even rum fell to the ground, the wind stopped, and Anne's singing stopped abruptly. The crew watched the captain as if the world had stopped moving forward.

After a while, the captain casually wiped his face and fumbled for something. He took off his pistol, took off his double knives, took off his never taken off wrist guard, pursed his golden hair, and quickly walked towards the dock. Annie also chased after him.

By the time we arrived at the dock, he had already squatted on the shore, holding a few fresh wild flowers in his hand, and a little girl stood in front of him.

I saw the captain so humble for the first time, and finally understood what the east he was looking at was.

Since that day, the Jackdaw has become a legend in the Caribbean, and no one has ever seen Edward Kenway and his beloved Jackdaw again.

This game is an absolute yes from me. Ubisoft hit the nail on the head with this one in what is commonly considered one of the best games in the Assassin's Creed franchise, and I'm inclined to agree. If you're a fan of AC, this game is a must play, and if you aren't, it's still worth a try.

I wanna talk about a few complaints first, but most are nitpicks. Probably the biggest issue I had with this game was bugs, in true Ubisoft fashion, and even then they weren't terrible. They've been updating the game recently, and as a result broke Kenway's Fleet, a sort of income generating minigame that is REQUIRED for some content in the game. However, someone on steam wrote a guide on how to fix it, so I was able to get it working. Even though the Fleet is pretty fun for what it is, the long times it takes to complete are frustrating, as I currently am at 99% completion and need to wait another day before I can wrap up the final few tasks remaining. Also, the carribean seems more mountainous than is natural, but that's to limit playable area, which was a good call. A few unimportant things are no longer available to players too, but overall these are really all the complaints I have.

Parkour and combat are the key staples of this franchise, and while not as good as some previous entries, they're both still good. Kenway has a nice sized kit, I always felt like I had the right tools to deal with the situation. Never too much or too little. Ship combat in this game is very fun but does get repetitive after some time. However, you're likely to beat the game before you get sick of it. The story in this game is actually very good for an AC game in my opinion, in both the past and real world sections, and collectibles give even more flavor to players willing to read a little. Where this game REALLY thrives though, is exploration. The open world is very large and gives you lots of interesting and vibrant places to explore. There are plenty of collectibles and activities to do, but not so much that I got exhausted doing them, it was a very nice amount. The mission design is generally good (though there are a lot of tailing missions), and the optional objectives were generally more fun and less annoying to complete than in previous entries. Overall, there's a lot to do and it's all very fun. It's not perfect, nothing is, but I found it very fun and my time was well spent in 100% completing the game.

It's also worth noting that this game comes with a few DLCs, one following Aveline from AC Liberation and another following Adewale, an important character from the main game. The Aveline DLC is short and mediocre, but I'd rather play it than play Liberation which was longer and still mediocre. Freedom Cry was a blast though, following Adewale as he fought against the slave trade in the Carribean. It's still not as good as the main game, but it was worth playing in my opinion.

TLDR; Get this game, it's worth it. Unlike most Ubisoft games, I would even suggest going for 100% completion. Freedom Cry is included and is also worth a quick playthrough.

My 2nd time playing this game (my first being on the Xbox one) and it feels good to play through this game again, while the tailing missions are a slog to play through (so bad that I forgot about them even after years of playing it on the Xbox one) and the story is at times forgettable. The pirate side of this game is what truly makes it shine. From swimming through ship wrecks, plundering and making enemy ships part of your fleet, to even facing off against the deadly legendary ships. Additionally, the dlcs are nothing to write home about. While the Freedom Cry dlc is a little fun as you play the hospitable Adewale the dlc story doesn't really go anywhere. And the Aveline dlc story feels like a random chunk of liberation they decided to squeeze in here for whatever reason. However, this games pirate essence is plentiful and here to stay. If you enjoy all things pirate themed than you might enjoy this game too. (Side-note: please bare in mind that I have had to patch this game thanks to community forums as the base of this game has you locked in windowed mode and unable to access the dlcs and the kenway fleet minigame.)

I should also state that this game is more of a pirate game than an Assassin's creed game. The game focuses more on being a Pirate, Ship to Ship combat and hunting whales or sharks. Playing Rogue after this and hoping it will be as fun or maybe even more!

DLC: The dlc is fun, but it really is just a dlc. Adewale's story is short, but fun! It also takes place after the main game. Aveline's story, is just not it. it's only 3 sequences and doesn't really add much to the AC4 game. 

I 100% cleared everything except the multiplayer, but I guess that's dead anyways. Really recommend if you like pirate games and a great story! 9.5/10

A Swashbuckling High-Seas Adventure for Aspiring Pirates

Rating: ★★★★★

Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag sails players into uncharted waters, delivering an exhilarating and swashbuckling experience set in the Golden Age of Piracy. Released in 2013, the game reimagines the Assassin's Creed formula by introducing an open-world pirate setting, stunning naval battles, and an engrossing narrative that takes players on an unforgettable high-seas adventure.

Set in the early 18th century, players assume the role of Edward Kenway, a charismatic and opportunistic pirate with a heart full of ambition. The narrative blends historical events with fictional elements, immersing players in the captivating world of pirates, privateers, and the fierce struggle between the Assassins and Templars.

Black Flag's strength lies in its immersive open-world exploration. The game invites players to navigate the vast Caribbean archipelago, discovering hidden coves, uncharted islands, and bustling ports. The seamless transition from land to sea adds a sense of freedom and adventure, making every voyage an opportunity for discovery and plunder.

The naval gameplay is a standout feature of Black Flag, offering exhilarating and visually stunning ship battles. Players command the Jackdaw, Edward's ship, in fierce naval engagements against enemy vessels and fortifications. The strategic use of cannons, mortars, and swivel guns creates a sense of tactical depth, and the feeling of the wind in your sails and the salty spray on your face makes you truly feel like a seasoned pirate captain.

As an Assassin's Creed title, Black Flag maintains the signature parkour and stealth mechanics of the franchise. However, it introduces new and dynamic gameplay elements such as underwater exploration and harpooning, which add variety and depth to the overall experience.

The game's portrayal of the Caribbean is breathtaking, with stunning graphics that capture the vibrant colors of the tropical setting. From lush jungles to sandy beaches, the world feels alive and teeming with life, offering a visually captivating and immersive experience.

The characters in Black Flag are well-developed and memorable, including historical figures like Blackbeard and Charles Vane. Edward's personal journey from a self-serving pirate to a man of purpose and principles adds depth to the narrative, making him a compelling protagonist.

Additionally, the game boasts an outstanding soundtrack that sets the tone for the adventure, with epic sea shanties and atmospheric music that enhance the immersion and the feeling of being part of a pirate crew.

One minor drawback is that some players may find the modern-day sequences featuring the present-day protagonist, a recurring aspect of the Assassin's Creed franchise, less engaging compared to the pirate adventure in the historical setting.

In conclusion, Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag stands as a true gem in the franchise, offering an enthralling high-seas adventure that appeals to fans of both pirates and Assassins. With its seamless blend of history and fiction, thrilling naval battles, and a rich open-world environment, Black Flag sets the standard for the pirate-themed genre in gaming.

Whether you're a longtime fan of the Assassin's Creed series or a newcomer seeking an epic pirate odyssey, Black Flag promises an unforgettable journey of piracy, exploration, and daring escapades on the high seas.

I'm struggling to finish this. I understand this game released in 2013, and I'm sure it was hot in it's time, but I'm not convinced it holds up to a new player. As someone who's spent ample time in Odyssey and Valhalla, going back to what people consider "the best Assassin's Creed game" has been nothing short of disappointment. I would not recommend this to anyone new to the series, enticed by big sales on older installments. I have no intention to pick up anything else 'in between', and will stick to waiting for new releases.

I'm often frustrated and irritated by the end of each session. I find the pacing of the gameplay to be so tiresome. Travelling by sea just seems to take unnecessarily long, and poses no significant gameplay experience if you aren't interested in battling at sea. Speaking of sea battles, annoying camera placement and lighting effects can make this unnecessarily difficult. Firing off cannons in fog and suddenly I can't see anything. The camera being so close to the ship also really inhibits my ability, personally, to effectively navigate in a fight. Boarding seems to take a calendar year that I end up swimming most of the time to the defeated ship.

In typical Assassin's Creed fashion, albeit not something I remember encountering heavily in Odyssey/Valhalla, the free-running is like navigating a minefield. They really needed to separate sprinting from free-running. There's no in-between currently; either you walk painfully slow or you initiate free-running. This is effectively your sprint - however Edward will launch himself up walls, or onto climbable objects, if you so much as graze them. This can easily result in enemies catching up, or losing sight of tailed enemies. The ability to sprint, without climbing, is sorely missing.

There's also mandatory story missions where you need to tail somebody. I'm sure to seasoned veterans of the franchise this is the bread and butter, but holy crap I found these needlessly time consuming and difficult. I think newer stealth games implement better systems for stealth sections, which I know is tough considering I'm criticizing a 10-year-old game, so take from that what you will. I can't ignore that these sections were frustrating, with minimal visual indicators for line-of-sight and proximity, and with abnormally frequent turn-arounds and height checks by the AI.

There's also annoying technical issues with the HUD. The resolution of the game can be increased but the HUD seems to mimic lower resolutions reminiscent of 2013 norms. Kind of minor, but also pretty ugly on screen. For such a popular game I wish they'd update this.

The amount of work I had to do just to get this game running without crashing every 10 minutes was staggering. This issue is felt by most players these days because Ubisoft doesn't support steam's launch platform. If you do have this issue, my fix was to run it in compatibility mode with windows 8 and turn all of the graphics down to low. Why a 4090 cant run it on anything but low, I'll never know but at least I can finish playing this game and then never bother with it or another AC game again.

Oh Black Flag - the Assassins Creed game most known by people that have no clue about the franchise in itself. And for good reason, too.

Assassins Creed: Black Flag is an extremely nice and fun game to play. The world is beautifully made, albeit a bit repetitive. At some point, it gets hard to really distinguish one island from another and you kind of start to get bored of looking at the same houses, plants and prostitutes. It doesn't take away from it's beauty though and the repetitive nature is likely what makes new scenes even better. 

Personally, I was not a fan of all the boating. It was to be expected, seeing as Black Flag is, in it's essence, a pirate-game. But still, not too fond. The controls felt iffy and, for some reason, extremely slow making it a hassle to drive from A to B all the damn time. I was really [i] really [/i] happy once fast travel was available. No such issues with all the walking, climbing and running though. Here, the controls felt really intuitive and Edward was extremely quick on his feet, so no complains there. 

The story itself was nice, albeit a bit cringy whenever Edward was being his usual idiotic self, and there was no point where it felt stagnant or drawn out. Edward definitely deserves to be placed high in the ranking of most-popular characters, the man likely a treasure to all the tall-dark-dangerous enthusiasts out there. His cocky way of dealing with things carries a lot of the weight and he is, in the end, a very likable character - despite his short comings.
Uplay is the worst, its a shame that this gem runs off it.

God damn this game runs like utter dog shite on modern machines! If it isn't the 60 fps cap (which is fine to be fair), or the stuttering, or the fps drops, it'll definitely be the seemingly random crashing that will get to you. The game will run fine for a while until at some point it just decides to stop responding at all.

Otherwise it's an overall great game. If you're somehow stuck on an old rig from 2013-2014 when the game was released, then yeah you should definitely buy this. Otherwise stay clear for your sanity's sake.

My first and my most favorite assassin's creed game.

BEFORE ANYTHING ELSE: I WHOLEHEARTEDLY recommend playing this game. That being said, I need to mention this, and because of my experience, I cannot recommend you purchasing this in the current way Ubisoft, the dumbasses they are, expect you to.

I was robbed by Ubisoft because of this. 
As with pretty much all of Ubisoft's games you need an activation key to play this game, because of their absolute dog ass Uplay app. I do not know how, I do not know why, there is no searches on any search engine that I could do to find anyone with a similar situation, but the game, after I had already played it for over two hours, requested to see my activation key again. So I found the key and activated the game again, but I got the message "This key was already used on another account."
Note: I got the game for like 20 bucks on sale or something.
You can imagine my confusion. I had only ever used one Uplay account and one Steam account in my entire life. 
So, my solution was to go to refund the game. I HAD NOT realized the price was raised since I had gotten it. So, I go to refund the game, I think that's going to be that and after I rebuy the game and get a new key that all will be well. I go to the store page just to double check reviews and what do I find? The game is DOUBLE what I got it for. This didn't irk me much though, I have twenty dollars to spend, personally I don't have money problems, but it was frustrating. 

Steam denies my refund because "You have surpassed the 48 hour refund time limit" or some bullshit excuse like that. 
In order to play this game that I would put in my top 10 of all time again, I had to remove the game instance from my account, not getting my money back at all. MIND YOU, THIS GAME AND IT'S CONTENT IS ABOUT A DECADE OLD, AND UBI HAS THE AUDACITY TO SELL IT FOR 40 FUCKING DOLLARS.

But as you saw above, Ubi isn't the only company with bullshit practices here. The game was rendered unplayable on my account and they didn't show an ounce of proper support when I tried to get it (including the refund).

I was robbed. Steam and Ubisoft had robbed me of forty dollars and all the progress I had made in the game. It may not be directly, but when a company is this negligent to it's users that it actively STRIPS the product it promised from you while KEEPING the money you spent for it, yeah, it's a mother fucking problem. To be honest, I don't care too much about the money I lost. What I give a shit about, is the principle. The fact that this kind of thing is what companies get away with is outrageous and the fact that we ALL agree that the modern corporate model is absolutely fucking torturous for the common man, and yet nothing has really been done to change that is sickening. Especially when it comes to the gaming industry, because it is rampant here.

I am going to buy the game again. This game is fucking amazing and Edward is hot. But unless you are confident that you wont run into this problem I have, don't buy it. Wait for Ubisoft to change their moronic ways. I'd use a much harsher word if it wasn't so offensive, because Ubi's business practices are nothing short of HARMFUL to the users. 

I'd say I expected better, but Ubisoft's awful reputation precedes them, and Steam support has been at most pretty terrible to downright malicious in my experience at times. Simultaneously, I'd say I'm not surprised, but, well, this has never happened to me before in this level of catastrophic negligence that I can't help but remain appalled. 

Grossly over-summarized conclusion: Steam and Ubisoft robbed me of sixty dollars because the former can't get a proper support system and the latter hires toddlers to program their shitty apps.

Wanted to share my experience with the game.
This is actually my first purchase of an ubisoft game. I was always worried if I would be able to play this game, would uplay cause issue, what if I can't connect my game to ubisoft account etc. So I am glad it worked out well in the end.

The reason why I wanted to play this game is cause of pirates. That was my point of interest. I love pirates of the caribbean movie and this game lived up to everything to what I imagined.
An amazing world, map, a likable main character, great music, detail. I loved this game from the beginning to the end. The details of the world is amazing. I didn't even imagine Marry Read & Anne were real. Made the end game sequences more emotional.

The naval combat is amazing. And the thing is you can add ships you capture to your fleet which you can then on sort of like send on trade mission to earn money. It's a simple mini game sort of thing to earn income which really worked well with this game. 
Even the normal mini games are really fun to play. Sailing the sea, hunting shark, whale, treasure maps, looting smuggler's den, going underwater, the rain, the weather, hunting, that's not even mentioning the regular assassin things.

I am already feeling nostalgic for a game I just finished. There are forts you can take over. On the higher difficulty forts, I am attacking the fort while there is huge thunderstorm on going with cyclone, you got huge tidal wave coming from different directions. It was like pirates of the caribbean at world's end movie scene.

The entire game I hardly ever considered myself as an assassin, always a pirate.
In one of the first movies, Will says,"In a fair fight, I'd kill you."
And then Jack is like "That's not much incentive for me to fight fair, then, is it?". And that's exactly how I played this game. Probably one of the best experience I had from a game.
The Aveline dlc was ok. Honestly not even a dlc. More like one side quest. The freedom cry was good. But compared to the base game, it is still lacking.

So now the problems. Funny thing is that the problems I faced was not in the game rather the launcher itself.
I have to type my password every time I want to play it. It is not that the launcher forgot it rather I need to "log in" to play the game. 
I also couldn't sync my achievements on uplay. Though honestly I could care less about this one.
And that's it. These two are the only problems I faced.

So all in all, I recommend this game 100%. There is no doubt about it in my mind.

Assassins Creed IV Black Flag

Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag, once hailed as a gem among games, now seems lackluster. While it might have had its appeal in the past, reflecting on it now brings disappointment. Maybe 10 years ago it was something but now is nothing but a turd. To be honest I never played it back in the day and having tried it now I do wonder how is this considered good?
The story is awful, if this game was made outside of AC universe it would have been so much better, the whole animus and the crap about some mysterious library is just holding it back - I don't care for how it all works, don't care for modern french offices, for old libraries. Only thing that is on my mind, when playing the pirate game is the pirating! Pirating that is not a stealth section or trailing section as those are the worst and also a majority of what you will do, especially annoying when you can't kill anyone or be detected. My goodness....... Gotta mention the extra crappy moments of when they pull you out of animus to do some bullshit like speak to Ceo or find your office or hack some orb to get data out... Ah yeah if game had James Kidd deleted it would be better for it - it's missions are the worst.
Okay story is trash, hows gameplay? The gameplay also falls short, particularly in combat, which feels repetitive and lacks depth.
No levels, no experience, no passive skills to unlock, just some crafting, but calling it basic would be an over statement. 
The sea combat is somewhat enjoyable, but it's far too easy, making encounters with ships and forts feel less challenging than they should be. 
I remember encounter with a 9 point fort and 5 enemy ships at the same time and I took them all out no problem. Can literally board a ship mid combat, repair your vessel and continue the engagement. 
Even the sea hurricanes fail to impress.
On a positive note, the shanties add a touch of charm, though they could have been more prominent. However, despite these few bright spots, the overall experience leaves much to be desired.

peak ac

I honestly feel like a crazy person when I hear people praise this game so much, especially when exactly those people are the same who will then mock the later games for having repetitive mission structure or not enough parkour.

Don't get me wrong, I've had a lot of fun with this game, and it certainly has amazing qualities, there are just some things that really bring it down and in my opinion, this was the game that sparked the downfall of Assassin's Creed. 

To get the obvious pros out of the way, this game is the best pirate game - ever. Naval combat is excellent. And if all you're doing is just messing around and doing pirate shit, you will have a great time. Close quarters combat is a bit of a less bombastic version of AC III's, and as long as you don't try to stealth your way through places (you know, like an ASSASSIN, for crying out loud), you should be fine. The game is gorgeous, and just existing in a raging storm out at sea, your ship buckling in the wind and rain, hearing the shanties, is quite an experience. Furthermore, Edward is probably my favorite protagonist in the series and definitely deserved more than just one game, and if he got them, he would have been even more loved than Ezio. His story is by far the best one in the series, being way more character-driven and down-to-earth...

But that amazing story is completely bogged down by this game's disastrous mission design. Seriously, Black Flag actually taught me about the importance of mission design in a game by showcasing exactly how NOT to do it. Every other mission is a god damn tailing mission, then there's the "walking missions", where all you fucking do is walk from point A to point B and listen to a guy talk. And the rest are forced stealth missions, and I don't need to tell you how garbage the stealth is in the Kenway saga. And if that wasn't enough, there's also an abundance of "ship stealth" missions, which is just so moronic. And it's such a shame because they completely ruin such a beautiful and unique story with all the best characters in the series in one game. So in a way, I'm honestly at least a little intrigued to see what they do with the remake.

So yeah, the missions in this game are by far the worst they've ever been in the entire series, in fact they're so infuriatingly bad that in my entire first time playthrough-marathon of these games, THIS is the first (and only) time I've actually took a break because it was becoming really taxing. I wondered why exactly it was Black Flag, the game everyone loved, that did it to me, and after a month or two, coming back and missing the pirating, and messing around a bit in the open world, I had a decent time with it and wondered, again, why I even left the game in the first place. And then I did a story mission. And I instantly knew why. What a damn shame.

Apart from that, the parkour is still subpar, owing mostly to the fact that you really have to go out of your way to even find a place where parkour is even possible, since it's mostly just open seas and jungles, and tree parkour is even more rubbish than it was in AC III.

And then there's the modern day sections, which used to be fun breaks from the actions, where you could catch up with Desmond and his crew, and which actually had an engaging plotline and gameplay. Yeah well, all of that is thrown right out the window beginning with this game. The modern day sections are now an absolute chore to get through and extremely intrusive, and should have been left out entirely. Sure, there are some interesting secret files to discover at Abstergo, but those could have easily just been put into some menu page, and then you wouldn't have to fucking walk around Abstergo in first person at a snail's pace and do some shitty mini-games.

So yeah, I enjoyed myself at times with Black Flag, but there's just so much bringing this game down that I simply can't ignore it.

Edit: Amazing score by the way though, every track is an absolute banger

It's 2021 and this game is still great.

The reasons why I love "Black Flag":

- The magnificent storyline with well-written characters and their development, including some really touching and memorable moments. And it is much more than just a cheesy pirate action-movie
- Despite the graphic quality, the game still has amazing in-game world design and it's unique style that makes you enjoy the exploration all along
- The big and fullfilled open world with many interesting side activities
- Quite a detailed pirate life representation, with it's joys and sorrows...
- Hey, you can board and capture 5 ships in a row here and then get blind drunk in a nearby tavern, what else a true pirate could possibly wish for? :D

A great work of art never gets old.

_____________________________________________

Даже в 2021 году это всё ещё отличная игра.

Причины, по которым это так:

- Великолепная история с отлично прописанными героями и их развитием в сюжете, в том числе присутствие трогательных и запоминающихся моментов в нём. И да, эта история есть нечто большее, чем обычный пиратский боевик
- Несмотря на графику, у игры сохраняется отличный и по-своему уникальный дизайн игрового мира, который позволяет неоднократно получить удовольствие от его исследования
- Большой и наполненный открытый мир с множеством интересных активностей
- Детальное изображение пиратской жизни, со всеми её прелестями и горестями...
- Тут можно захватить 5 кораблей подряд а потом пойти и напиться в дрова в ближайшей таверне, что ещё от жизни нужно настоящему пирату? :D

this game is one of the best pirate / assassins creed games ever made. for the last few weeks before the date of this review, an update nobody expected to an older game had what i think were unintended bug of forcing a windowed mode which ruined the enjoyment of playing since fullscreen was replaced by a white window header which attracted the eye to the sky like nothing else.

today an update fixed this and fullscreen mode now works again. i have seen no other problems nor any patch notes released to explain what ubisoft were trying to do with the botched update (maybe something positive?) but at least they put people on it to fix the issue as fast as they could identify it. 

we could have hoped also for an apology and explanation, if there were patch notes then i have no idea where they post them - but at least the game is fixed. 

others report that they have lost save games - i know the different editions of this game stored the saves in differing locations, maybe people should try to find the older location and newer and see which place their saves were. the deluxe edition saves are incompatible with the old (now obsolete) standard edition saves anyway. my one save was fine so far as i can see.

some people also say that kenways fleet just gives them an infinite loading screen since the botched update and this one doesnt change it - but for me i dont think it stopped working, and it works now after the fullscreen fix patch.

this is why i recommend the game again.

Since I bought this game, I've been confused why the DLCs for the Gold Edition is not working. I've search the Reddit and Google which I found several issues similar to mine. The game was quite old and just around $10 when I bought it so I didn't mind it after I lost hope when I can't find any solution. Today, when I logged in, it just magically notified that I unlocked the Season Pass (meaning I can access the Aveline and Freedom Cry DLCs now). Note that most of the solutions I can find said I should have two CD keys, which I don't since this is a Gold Edition one.

So what I thought I did yesterday is that after I logged out of the game, I checked Freedom Cry and Liberation pages in Steam, add them to cart, 'cause I was planning to buy them for the next sale. Then that's it, when I returned to the game just now, the game notified me I unlocked the Season Pass.

[b]Worth it[/b] for the naval battling, the sea shanties, the scenery, and the few cool "assassin moments".
 
[b]Not worth it[/b] for the terrible pacing, story, mission design (the dreadful trailing sections), and bugs.

So if you really want to be a pirate, pillaging your way through the beautiful Caribbean Sea, while a bunch of drunken sailors sing about the ups and downs of this way of life, go for it. But know that there may be better games hidden on Steam to scratch this particular itch.
