So after 62 hours put into this game , I've finally called it quits . I wanted to add more hours , but sadly , this game is not starting up for me . But before I continue on , I'm gonna comment on the good things this game does .

First off , this is great Pirate game like Sid Meier . You get to plunder merchant ships sailing across the sea . There is whaling and harpooning of sharks to be done . There's also buried treasure that you can hunt down , and some deep sea diving once you get the diving bell .

Second , there's bar brawls you can do , there are animals to hunt , and a nice ship crew that you could interact with . 

Another thing you could do is , customize your ship as you go along . You could get different set of sails and wheels for your ship . Not only that , you can craft the look of your main character that you're playing as , and customize your own hideout and island to your liking .

After listing all the good experience in this game , and there's many good experiences I had , we now move on to the bad parts of the game .

First off , after I've put 62 hours into the game , and I was wanting to put in some more , the game doesn't want to start . This is disappointing since I wanted more pirate adventures , but I can't since the game doesn't want to start for me .

Second set of problems . The game has very clunky controls , and is sometimes not as responsive . An example of this , is when I'm trying to climb up the mast of the ship , and my character won't go up any further , or will not go where I want him to go .

Adding to the game's problems , is Kenway's Fleet . I was never able to access my fleet on the map . There are some items for your ship that could only be obtained through Kenway's Fleet . Sadly , there's no way of accessing that .

More problems to be listed . I have a set of throwing knives . Each time I throw my knives , the weapon slot automatically changes to throwing coins . This presents a problem , and I end up blowing my cover .

The stealth . The stealth in this game is terrible . You can't sneak up on enemies . You have to run and hide , run and hide . Whatever happened to creeping up on an NPC that you're targeting .

Missions are just no fun at all . I like my meetings with Edward Thatch , but I didn't get far into the game , because my game just won't start anymore .

Controls . During the mid of the battle , I would switch from my darts to pistols . Sometimes that game isn't as responsive , and the enemy would get a drop on me .

More complaints . So here I am trying to climb up a mast to cut off the flag of the ship . I'm aiming for one part of the mast to continue my climb . Unknown to me , is that my character is looking at a different direction . I press my controls to jump and climb my target , only to have my character do something else , and fall off the mast . This results in death or desynchronization .

One last complaint that I will list . I can't get to multiplayer . I can't even start the game after 62 hours of playtime . In fact , even my Ubisoft connect won't start up at times . With so many problems that this game has , I'll have to give it a two out of five stars .

The game was fun when it was working . It's not fun anymore when it doesn't even want to start up . Good thing I bought this game at eleven bucks . I suggest getting it on sale when it comes , and don't pay the full price of fifty dollars of this game .

Oh Black Flag... This is probably Ubisoft's Magnum Opus when it comes to the whole franchise. I mean... You're playing as a pirate and meeting some of history's notorious pirates, Blackbeard!, Mary Read/James Kidd!, Anne Bonny, Jack Calico, Charles Vane, not only that but most of the exploration you'll do is on the sea, I remember 3 had a small glimpse of naval exploration but this one turns it up to 11 and adds combat, you can sink other ships and loot em for resources. 

With that said, it's a highly recommended from me, as with the suits you have to actually hunt to get some of them, also for ship upgrades.

COMBAT SYSTEM

EXPLORATION
I'm not into exploration in the games, but this one has someting cool about it, with all the islands, chests etc. It does not stuff it in your face like something you NEED to do.

Let's say you are looking for a pirate game that allows you to do anything you can imagine being able to do in your pirate fantasy. This is the game for you. Yes, it's an Assassin's Creed game, but the "Assassins" part really only happens in the last 10% of the game. 
You can:
-sink, board and plunder ships
-sail anywhere and everywhere in a vast and beautiful open world set in the early 18th century Caribbean Sea.
-Dive and plunder the wrecks and caves lost in the ocean
-Play stealthily or agressively in dozens of sandbox areas with level design that allows for experimentation and different approaches
-outfit Edward with true drip
-look for buried treasure using treasure maps (yes, the X marks the spot)
-attack forts with your ship
-upgrade and develop your ship as well as your own fleet (the fleet thing is like a minigame)
-get drunk
-marvel at the amazing beauty
-cry at the end of the game
-and more.
This is a must buy for any fan of the pirate fantasy and in all truth, for any person.

Black Flag is in it's own special way the crowning jewel of the AC franchise.

Apart from some technical issues, it's overall the most "Great" game in the franchise. Great gameplay, great story, great world, great exploration, great soundtrack, etc, it really doesn't seem to have one weak bone in it's body.

I'd say it doesn't match some of the other game's high points, but that's really not a problem. You can't go wrong with this game, it was the most played game in the series by non-fans for a good ass reason.

No wonder Ubisoft though that making Assassin's Creed games "blank-simulators" like Valhalla was a smart decision, they just forgot to make them even remotely ok. Oh, and isn't this game soooo poopy ugly? Thank god they're remaking this PS1 looking ass game, amirite?

One of the best aspects of Black Flag is the immersive open-world exploration. You get to roam the vast Caribbean Sea, exploring islands, diving into underwater shipwrecks, and uncovering hidden treasures. The naval gameplay is a standout feature, allowing you to command your own pirate ship, engage in thrilling naval battles, and plunder enemy vessels.

The attention to detail in Black Flag is outstanding. The lush tropical environments, the bustling cities, and the authentic pirate atmosphere make you feel like you've truly stepped into the world of pirates and assassins. The gameplay seamlessly blends land-based exploration, ship combat, and stealthy assassinations, providing a diverse and engaging experience.

Just played this for the first time (as part of my playthrough of all of the AC games) and from what I've played so far, this really earns its reputation as one of the best Assassin's Creed games. There are refinements still to be made but Black Flag is a stunning return to form worthy of any gamer’s time. Fans that were bummed out by Assassin’s Creed III will most likely find Black Flag to be a welcoming return to what they love about the series, with a great story, amazingly crafted world and smart additions to the sailing that make it a refreshing part of the Assassin’s Creed formula.

"Alright, lads. I’ll give you Blackbeard’s honest opinion. You ask me, "Can this new captain promise you a life of prizes, plunder, and adventure?" Aye. Amongst all the gentlemen of fortune sailing these West Indies, he ranks amongst the most clever. There was a time when I thought myself the deadliest scourge of these seas. But this man, he's like a fearsome dog. Feeds off trouble and turmoil. I seen him clear the deck of a Spanish galleon like it were nothing. Fighting like a devil dressed as a man. And he’s the kind of man knows his way around every crack and crevice of these islands. So if it's fortune and adventure you seek, then Captain Edward Kenway’s your man. Only, don't meddle in his private affairs. For there's more mystery in that man than even I dare ask."

Edward Thatch (Blackbeard)

In the distant land of Zephyria, nestled amidst rolling hills and shimmering lakes, a sense of tranquility pervaded the air. The inhabitants of this idyllic realm lived harmoniously, their lives intertwined with the rhythms of nature. Each morning, as the sun's golden rays gently caressed the landscape, the village came alive with bustling activity. Farmers tilled the fertile soil, sowing the seeds of sustenance, while artisans meticulously crafted intricate pottery, their hands guided by generations of tradition. Children laughed and played in the meadows, their carefree spirits soaring like the birds that painted the azure sky. As twilight descended, the community gathered around a crackling bonfire, sharing tales of valor and adventure, their voices blending with the chorus of nocturnal creatures. Zephyria, a place where time seemed to stand still, where the beauty of simplicity unfolded with each passing day.

Edward Kenway is one of the best characters the franchise has introduced us to. Initially seeking a shallow goal of wealth and fortune Kenway finds himself intertwined in the struggle between Asssassin and Templar. Through trials and tribulations, love, loss, and struggle Kenway finds his way, devoting himself to an admiral cause for the good of the people. Black Flag is one of the greatest pirate games I've played and would recommend it to anyone who is a fan of piracy or Assassins creed.
THIS IS A ABSOLUTELY AMAZING GAME ITS SO VISUALLY BRILLIANT IT BELONGS IN A ART MUSEUM

Black Flag was the second AC game I've ever played, and it was a delightful surprise to see it take one of the least interesting parts of AC3 and turn it into something very enjoyable: ships, sailing, and naval combat. You're aboard a lot of the time in Black Flag, but be it on sea or land, the life of an assassin/pirate is always entertaining. It's still a game about assassins at heart, but if you only care about the piracy it's still pretty good. Edward Kenway is a pretty cool character and its nice to see his progression from a Jack Sparrow-esque pirate to a man who cares about more than just himself.

If you like AC or pirates at all, you'll enjoy this game. If you've never played an AC game in your life, know there's a reason this installment is considered the best in the series -- if you'll only ever play one, let it be this one.

Assassin's Creed 4 is basically good for one thing, and one thing only - the pirate stuff is pretty fun. It's what I spent most of my playtime doing, and it was worth the hype. It's a ton of fun.

Everything else... eh. The missions are overwhelmingly tailing missions where you stay hidden while following someone having a conversation. There's usually one good path to take, and most of the challenge is just executing the path correctly. Ubisoft's client remains a massive pain, and in a weird turn of events, this game doesn't have working cloud saves due to a bug they never bothered to fix. I had to log in to the client each time I launched the game, no matter how many times I asked it to remember me. There's also a bunch of weird (and mostly dead) live-service mechanics that remind me why live-service stuff sucks in single player games.

It's worth playing this game if you're really interested in some decent ship-to-ship pirate gameplay, but everything else just sort of falls really flat.

I had some persistent bug in my game where everything was washed out and over-saturated with fog. I could not figure out what was going on, and while it seems like other people out there had the same issue I had, the internet didn't seem to have a fix, nor could I figure out a solution. It killed my interest in playing this game because it felt like someone turned the fog setting all the way to the max. Every town was shrouded in fog and I could barely see.

Ahoy, me hearties! Gather round as I spin ye a tale of the high seas and treacherous adventures in me review of Assassin's Creed Black Flag, a game fit for the most daring buccaneers among us!

From the moment ye set foot on the deck of the Jackdaw, ye be transported to a world of plunder and piracy. The Caribbean be yer playground, filled with sprawling islands, crystal-clear waters, and the promise of untold riches. The attention to detail be commendable, mateys! The ship creaks, the waves crash, and the wind whistles through the sails, immersing ye in the life of a true swashbuckler.

As ye take control of Edward Kenway, a rogue pirate turned assassin, ye be embarking on a journey that'll have ye crossing paths with notorious scallywags like Blackbeard and Calico Jack. The storyline be as captivating as a siren's song, weaving history and fiction together in a seamless dance. Ye'll be caught up in political intrigue, naval battles, and the eternal struggle between the assassins and Templars.

The naval combat, me hearties, be a highlight of this fine game. As ye steer yer mighty vessel through storms and cannonfire, ye'll feel the wind in yer hair and the thrill of the chase. Ye'll plunder enemy ships, upgrade yer own, and engage in epic battles that'll have ye shouting "Arr!" in triumph. The ship-to-ship combat be as fierce as a kraken's fury, and the naval exploration be a joyous voyage of discovery.

But it ain't just about sailing the open seas, me hearties. The land be just as bountiful with its hidden treasures and lively towns to explore. Ye'll find yerself sneaking through jungles, scaling fortresses, and engaging in swashbuckling combat. The world be teeming with activities, from harpooning whales to searching for buried treasure. There be no shortage of adventure on land or sea!

The graphics be as vibrant as a parrot's feathers, me mateys. The sunsets be breathtaking, and the details on the ships befitting a captain's pride. The voice acting be top-notch, with the characters bringing life to the game's rich tapestry. And let's not forget the shanties, those infectious sea shanties that'll have ye tapping yer peg leg and belting out a tune!

Now, I must admit there be a few barnacles on this ship. The land-based missions can sometimes feel repetitive, and the controls can be a tad clunky at times. But fear not, me hearties, for these minor flaws be but a drop in the vast ocean that is Assassin's Creed Black Flag.

So, me fellow scallywags, if ye be yearning for a pirate's life, filled with adventure, plunder, and a touch of assassin's creed, then set sail with Black Flag. It be a game that'll make ye feel like the captain of yer own destiny, and I guarantee ye won't be walking the plank with this one. Yo-ho-ho and a bottle of rum, it's a pirate's life for me!

The assassin game that is actually a pirate game.  I loved playing Black Flag.  I think it's very unique among the Assassin's Creed games.  If you're a hardcore Assassin's Creed fan, this probably won't be your favorite one, but if you like being a pirate acrobat with flintlock pistols strapped all over your body piloting a fast brigantine and raiding the hell out of Spanish and English ships, this game is for you.  I do recommend.

IMO the best entry point into the AC series. Although previous games had fantastic stories, the game play for me was still too unpolished to truly enjoy. 

If people try earlier games and are put off I'd suggest watching ThePatientWolf's story summaries for the previous games to catch up on the greater plot and then continue on here.

[h1]8.9/10[/h1]

[b]Pros[/b]
     - Some of the best gameplay in the AC series to date
     - Overall solid story that ties itself well into the universe
     - Great open world and new ship combat to the series
     - Game feels like it's a great length, long enough to get immersed in the world, but not overstaying it's 
        welcome
     - Compelling characters and dialog, voice acting is great and so far these are my favorite historical 
        characters explored 
     - Good amount of side activities to keep you invested
     - Freedom Cry is a decent expansion on the game
     - Pirates

[b]Cons[/b]
     - Some bugs and technical issues
     - Avaline DLC feels tacked on
     - Graphics are definitely showing their age at this point
     - A lot seemingly unanswered in the "current" story timeline
     - The assassin story line is relatively complex and it feels like they don't dive deep enough into it

Overall the game is really solid, IMO it's the best AC to it's release date in the series. It seems to be the peak so far of all the gameplay, while also adding in naval combat which is honestly pretty great. The story is a fun advancement of what's already been and while it could have been a bit better in terms of the depth, it definitely get's the job done for what it's looking to do. It's also the most interesting setting for the series to it's release date as well. The pirate lines are just so interesting and all the characters are really cool to see in action.

If you're already this deep into the series you're likely going to get it anyway, but it's truly a worthy addition into the entire series and after this replay IMO it seems to be one of the strongest from Assassin's Creed on the whole. Absolutely worth a replay if it's been a while and 100% worth it if you're already into the universe and playing them all for the first time

When I initially approached Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag, I had reservations about the emphasis on ship missions and combat. However, I was pleasantly surprised to find myself quickly immersed in an enjoyable and engaging experience. From the very start, the game's gripping narrative seized my attention as it followed the extraordinary life of Edward Kenway, a pirate who inadvertently finds himself entwined in the secret world of assassins and templars.

The strength of Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag lies in its captivating story. From the opening moments, I felt a deep connection to Edward and his journey. The game masterfully explores themes of friendship and betrayal, showcasing the evolution of relationships from camaraderie among pirates to the inevitable conflicts that arise from personal ambitions. Even when faced with adversaries, the game delicately portrays the longing for those once considered friends, fostering a profound emotional resonance.

On a technical level, I encountered no issues while playing Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag. The game is impeccably optimized, offering a smooth and seamless gameplay experience. However, it is worth noting that a slight disappointment stemmed from the frame rate being capped at 60FPS, which prevented the game from fully exploiting the potential of higher refresh rate displays.

As someone progressing through the Assassin's Creed series, I wholeheartedly recommend Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag to fellow players exploring the franchise. Despite initial reservations regarding the prominence of ship-based missions, the game ultimately delivers a thrilling and captivating adventure. It beautifully captures the essence of the pirate era, demonstrating Ubisoft's attention to historical detail and narrative craftsmanship.

In conclusion, Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag is a remarkable addition to the series. Its engrossing storyline, impeccable optimization, and poignant portrayal of friendships and conflicts make it a must-play for fans and newcomers alike. Set sail with Edward Kenway and embark on an unforgettable journey through the treacherous seas, where the lines between loyalty and self-interest blur, leaving a lasting impact on the heart and mind.

When I was a kid, I played this game and enjoyed it, although I couldn't recall much about the story. Back then, I mostly spent my time sailing the boat, not fully engaging with all the other features it had to offer. However, as an adult, I've recently revisited the game, and I must say, I absolutely love it.

In this game, you assume the role of a pirate driven by the pursuit of wealth. Along the way, you unexpectedly become entangled in a web of intrigue. To accomplish a task, you disguise yourself as a member of a secretive order of assassins and rendezvous with a governor to deliver a package once owned by the assassin you're impersonating. As you delve deeper into this elaborate charade, you find yourself assuming the identity of a person you know nothing about—a member of a secret society of assassins, including a treacherous traitor. Ultimately, you become affiliated with the enigmatic Templar organization, and that's where the story truly takes off.

All in all, this game offers a captivating experience that keeps you hooked.
Assassins Creed

Assassin's Creed® IV Black Flag is a game that perfectly blends historical fiction, open-world exploration, naval combat, and immersive storytelling into one breathtaking experience. Developed by Ubisoft Montreal and released in 2013, Black Flag took players on a journey through the Golden Age of Piracy in the Caribbean, offering an unparalleled pirate adventure. From its captivating gameplay mechanics to its richly detailed world, this installment in the Assassin's Creed franchise stands out as a true gem.

    A Captivating Historical Setting:
    One of the standout features of Assassin's Creed® IV Black Flag is its setting. The game transports players to the Caribbean during the 18th century, immersing them in a beautifully recreated open-world environment filled with lush tropical landscapes, bustling cities, and treacherous seas. The attention to detail is remarkable, capturing the essence of the era and making players feel like genuine pirates.

    The Golden Age of Piracy:
    Black Flag's depiction of the Golden Age of Piracy is nothing short of exceptional. The game portrays the era's real-life historical figures, such as Blackbeard, Anne Bonny, and Calico Jack, with authenticity and adds a touch of fiction that seamlessly merges with the actual events. Players get to experience the excitement and danger of sailing the high seas, engaging in epic naval battles, exploring hidden coves, and discovering buried treasures.

    Innovative Naval Gameplay:
    One of the most significant additions to the Assassin's Creed franchise in Black Flag is its naval gameplay. Commanding your own ship, the Jackdaw, and engaging in thrilling ship-to-ship combat is an exhilarating experience. The attention to detail in ship handling, weather effects, and the sensation of being at sea is truly remarkable. The naval battles are strategic, intense, and a true highlight of the game.

    A Vast Open World:
    Black Flag boasts a massive open-world to explore, filled with diverse locations and activities. From bustling cities like Havana and Nassau to uncharted islands and underwater shipwrecks, there is always something new to discover. The seamless transition between land and sea adds a sense of freedom, allowing players to navigate the Caribbean on their terms and explore hidden secrets.

    Engaging Storyline:
    Black Flag weaves an engrossing tale that merges the Assassin's Creed lore with the pirate theme flawlessly. Players assume the role of Edward Kenway, a charming and complex protagonist who starts his journey as a pirate but gets entangled in the age-old battle between the Assassin Brotherhood and the Templar Order. The narrative is well-paced, filled with memorable characters, unexpected twists, and a satisfying conclusion.

    Varied Gameplay Mechanics:
    Assassin's Creed® IV Black Flag offers a vast array of gameplay mechanics that keep players engaged throughout their pirate odyssey. Whether it's engaging in stealthy assassinations, engaging in epic naval battles, hunting wildlife, looting ships, engaging in naval raids, or engaging in naval exploration, the game constantly presents new and exciting challenges, preventing monotony.

    Stunning Visuals and Immersive Soundtrack:
    Black Flag showcases breathtaking visuals that bring the Caribbean to life. From the vibrant colors of the tropical landscapes to the meticulously designed cities, the attention to detail is stunning. The game's dynamic weather system adds another layer of immersion, with stormy seas and breathtaking sunsets. Accompanied by a masterfully crafted soundtrack that captures the spirit of the era, the audio-visual experience is nothing short of exceptional.

Conclusion:
Assassin's Creed® IV Black Flag is a true masterpiece, offering a captivating blend of history, adventure, and exploration. Its seamless integration of naval gameplay, immersive storytelling, and a dynamic open world make it a standout entry in the Assassin's Creed series. The game's attention to detail in recreating the Golden Age of Piracy, its engaging storyline, and the sheer variety of gameplay mechanics make it an unforgettable experience.

Black Flag allows players to fully embrace the life of a pirate, from commanding a fearsome ship and engaging in epic naval battles to exploring uncharted islands and plundering hidden treasures. The naval gameplay mechanics are not only innovative but also executed with precision, making every encounter on the high seas an adrenaline-fueled adventure. The sense of freedom and exploration is unparalleled as you navigate the vast open world, discovering hidden secrets and engaging in various side activities.

The protagonist, Edward Kenway, is a compelling character with his own motivations and growth throughout the game. As players delve into his story, they witness his transformation from a selfish opportunist to a figure deeply involved in the conflict between the Assassins and Templars. The narrative takes players on a thrilling journey filled with political intrigue, personal struggles, and the exploration of complex themes.

Furthermore, the game's visuals are a true testament to the attention to detail and craftsmanship of the developers. The Caribbean setting comes alive with stunning landscapes, vibrant cities, and meticulously designed architecture. From the bustling streets of Havana to the dense jungles of the islands, every location feels distinct and immersive. The dynamic weather system adds another layer of realism, with thunderstorms, rolling waves, and breathtaking sunsets enhancing the overall visual experience.

Accompanying the stunning visuals is a remarkable soundtrack that captures the essence of the era. From rousing sea shanties to haunting melodies, the music adds depth and emotion to every moment, further immersing players in the world of pirates and adventure.

In conclusion, Assassin's Creed® IV Black Flag is a masterful game that excels in nearly every aspect. Its captivating historical setting, engaging storyline, innovative gameplay mechanics, stunning visuals, and immersive soundtrack combine to create an unforgettable experience. Whether you're a fan of the Assassin's Creed series or simply seeking a thrilling and immersive pirate adventure, Black Flag is an absolute must-play that will leave you yearning for more. Prepare to set sail and embark on a swashbuckling journey like no other.

Such a good game! I'm playing on an M1 Max MacBook Pro under Parallels Desktop, and it may be the smoothest game I've ever played. It ranks up there with Shadow of Mordor and Shadow of War (played under an Intel Mac under bootcamp) as the best games out there for the Mac. Like those two games, you kill a lot of Spanish, British and probably French (I haven't encountered them yet, however) soldiers. I'm 16 hours in and I've only played 14% of the game. But I scour each island as I go, so that takes a lot of time.

Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag plays/sails smooth as silk. The sailing map is HUGE, but there is enough fast travel mechanics that you can get to where you want to go quickly, or you can sail there in not too much time. 

Each island/city has its own character. Some are large, some are relatively tiny. Lots of side missions on each island. This allows you to get more upgrades by earning money by looting chests or fulfilling assassination contracts. But the contracts seem like they are grafted on to the overall story, which is pretty compelling.

Although, it is hard to know what upgrades are the best to use. Also, this is my first Assassin's Creed game, so I am not sure how the assassination contracts (or lack thereof) might be seen by longtime players. The contracts themselves are not to difficult to fulfill. But many of them offer bonuses for staying out of combat, and that makes them more challenging.

The crafting system is easy to use. I generally HATE crafting, but this doesn't require you to set your quests aside or keep track of multiple items. You can hunt and fish to find a good portion of the items you need.
I bought it because it was recommended as a pirate game, and it was on sale for $12.00. BEST MONEY EVER SPENT!! Worth at least twice that, IMO.

Never played AC before and it fills like a good way to enter in. Great story and atmosphere (Shanties!!!!). The gameplay is divided in 2 (Naval and Assassin stuff), the Assassin part is pretty well executed and is casual, but I feel like getting inside a bush and teleporting makes it a bit ez to escape certain situation. If you like Shadow of Mordor, then you will like the gameplay (its a bit less sophisticated). I wish the game had explained how to do certain combos. The Naval is also casual, but is built a bit like an rpg. You have to upgrade your ship to have a better chance of surviving in hard zones. 

I would rate it 7/10, mostly because there is a lot of filler (like useless collectibles), also this game feels like its a port, so you will have to deal with some annoying camera mouvements. Also, I wish some parts of the gameplay were more sophisticated. Enough content for 30-50 hours if you dont collect dumb chests, but even the collectibles that give you good stuff are also kinda a bit annoying sometimes. When the enemy ships are shooting, there is almost no sound. The smoke from you cannons is cool, but it blocks your view cause there is too much of it lol. Puzzles dont even require a braincell. The different factions are basically just reskins (UK,Portugal,Spain are the same just with different color). Basically the game shows its age with all of this, but it was still a fun experience. I wish some elements like the puzzles or the Kenway's fleet were more sophisticated than that (check out the gameplay on youtube and you will understand). 

The Aveline DLC has a terrible story writing, you just want to hate your annoying companion (good thing its short). 

Adewale DLC is a nice small addition, but buy the standalone version since Ubishit cant fix a simple sound bug. Basically ur machete and gun are silent when u use them. Standalone version doesnt have this bug.

I wish there was some strategic elements in this game like when you capture a fort you have to keep in mind the number of people in it as an example. I want some form of permanence like [spoiler] when the templars attacked the assassins' island, you could see the aftermath, but when you kill people during a fort raid they just respawn, same for the boarding [/spoiler].

[code]Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag’s unique focus on naval combat really sets it apart from previous entries in the franchise. However, a lot of technical problems really ruin what would otherwise be quite an enjoyable pirate experience[/code]

After naval combat was introduced in [i]Assassin’s Creed III[/i] (the best part of the entire game for many), Ubisoft made the right decision for once and doubled down on the entire thing in the sequel: [i]Black Flag[/i]. With the appropriate setting, pirates in the Caribbean of course, [i]Black Flag[/i] had a lot of potential to be a great game even for those who are not a fan of the typical [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] formula.

And even though I played through all mainline [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] up until that point, I actually found the first few hours of [i]Black Flag[/i] surprisingly refreshing. In the beginning, it’s really fun to sail the Caribbean Sea with your own pirate ship, discovering new locations and engaging with other enemy ships in combat to steal their cargo. You then turn your cargo into ship upgrades, which allow you to take on even bigger challenges (read: bigger ships) for bigger rewards.

During these times, [i]Black Flag[/i] feels less like an [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] games and more like an entertaining-albeit-simple pirate spectacle. Naval combat isn’t very complex, and your ship upgrades will play a bigger part in surviving a battle than your reaction skills at the end, but it’s simple fun the first few times and a great visual spectacle. This goes especially for ship battles fought during heavy tropical storms, with big waves, heavy rain and a lot of thunder & lightning making for incredible memorable battle experiences.

However, as the game goes on and especially during story missions, the usual [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] elements become more prevalent. You’ll spend more time on land than on water, visiting locations that unfortunately all look pretty similar to each other - even those not part of the Caribbean Sea. Once you’re on land, you also got the usual [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i]-mix of assassinating certain targets, tailing people, collecting various side stuff and climbing towers to unveil the map. Little has changed here, making it a typical case of “you’ll like it if you liked it before and you’ll dislike it if you disliked it before”.

In fact, even though naval combat plays such a big role in [i]Black Flag[/i], at the end, I was surprised just how many of the usual [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] strengths & weaknesses make a return: There’s a huge amount of content – but much of it feels like busy work or copy-pasted. Gameplay systems are easy to understand & use – but they lack depth & variety and thus get tiresome in the long run. And while the main story does have its moments, many characters remain underdeveloped, and the pacing is off. I do have to admit that I liked the Abstergo-elements of the story this time around, even if the ending was unsatisfyingly abrupt.

In the end, what was a fun pirate game in the beginning turned more into a usual [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] game along the way. We even got ship tailing missions, which is just going too far. But while the usual [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] mix might have its fair share of problems, it’s undeniable that it also has its charm and there’s nothing quite like it even to this day.

That said, I will have to spend the rest of the review detailing the numerous (!) technical problems I encountered while playing [i]Black Flag[/i]. These are also the main reason why I’m giving [i]Black Flag[/i] a negative review, as they’re heavily diminishing what would otherwise be an enjoyable pirate [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] experience. I have no idea if these problems are restricted to the Steam/PC version of the game, but if you want to play the game, you might be better off doing so on console.

The first issues I encountered concern the graphical settings of the game. For some reason, [i]Black Flag[/i] simply refused to offer a 1440p 60hz option for my main monitor. It did offer all other resolutions at 60hz, but not 1440p for some reason. If I changed this via the settings .ini file, the game simply ignored those changes. If I tried using other monitors, the 1440p 60hz option suddenly reappeared. It’s quite an odd problem I wasn’t able to solve (had to use a different resolution) and have never experienced with any other game before (even Cyberpunk 2077).

The next issue concerns game content. I originally bought the game back in 2019, first the standard edition and then the season pass afterwards. However, when I started [i]Black Flag[/i] for the first time just a few days ago and activated my key, I found out that I wasn’t able to access my season pass content. Everything I paid for didn’t show up, instead I just received ads for buying said content, adding insult to injury. I’ve spent the past few days contacting Ubisoft support about the issue, but so far, it has yet to be solved as well.

Then came what’s probably the biggest gripe I have concerning [i]Black Flag[/i] – after about 15h of playtime, I opened up the game only to find out that my save was suddenly corrupted. Even Ubisoft Connect with its cloud saves couldn’t help me out (it simply replaced my functioning save with the corrupt one). I have no idea what could’ve caused this, as the game never crashed on me or was forcefully exited, neither was the save data tempered with. I started the game normally only to discover I lost 15h (!) of playtime, with no way to get it back. Everything I did was gone. I highly recommend manually backing up your saves (Steam Cloud doesn’t work for this game), if you still fancy a playthrough of [i]Black Flag[/i] on Steam.

Lastly, there were some game breaking bugs I encountered while playing [i]Black Flag[/i]. I’m not talking about minor bugs like this [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Eb77v45Soqc]classic[/url] (which I also experienced) but actual gamebreakers that require a reload if you want to finish a mission. For example, one time my player character spawned inside (!) my pirate ship, with no way to experience the wooden prison. This would be somewhat entertaining if the checkpoints in [i]Black Flag[/i] weren’t so bad sometimes – especially during tailing missions you might lose quite a lot of time. 

Maybe I just had bad luck with all of these technical problems happening at once (not counting the many minor bugs like glitching NPCs, etc.) but especially losing a 15h save really turned my playthrough of [i]Black Flag[/i] into an experience I can’t really recommend – even if the underlying game would be recommendation-worthy otherwise. Considering [i]Black Flag[/i] is also available on modern consoles, these might be safer picks if you want to avoid some of these technical problems.

I'm torn about this one.
It's a good game, but it shows it's age.

The controls are clunky, it's locked to 60hz and the draw distance is abbysmal to the point where guards that are on the minimap doesn't show up in the world even though you're two feet away. Of course, as soon as you turn your back they pop in, exposing your otherwise perfect stealth mission.
Also; it's Ubisoft. The game made me log in to Ubisoft Connect every time I booted it up. Not once, but twice.
Running it as admin and starting UC before the game got this down to one login.
It also runs choppy as all h*ell. The workaround for this, I found, was CTRL-ALT-DELeting out of the game, pressing cancel and then going back in to the game again. This made it run at a mostly perfect 60hz. You have to do this every fresh bootup.

Other than that, and with a few mods (4K faces and some LOD fixes) it runs OK, but knowing Ubisoft they will [i] never [/i] fix any of these issues as they are all on you. 
Valhalla side rant follows in spoiler below:
[spoiler] In AC Valhalla I crashed after 15-60 min repeatedly unless I played in Offline Mode. 
I reported this on the forums along with hundreds of others on multiple threads and we all got the: [i] have you updated your drivers [/i] line. They refused to aknowledge that this was on them. We provided them with specs, crash reports and saves and they did [i] nothing [/i] for over 6 months. Even going so far as telling us that almost no one had this problem, even though we were several hundred just on the official forums. When we told them that going in to offline mode fixed it they went as far as saying: [i] We don't recommend doing that as it breaks a few of the features. [/i]
The features, ofcourse, being the "pay for more useless sh*t" options. The issue was even fixed with one update, that lasted about a week, before the next mandatory bug fix broke it again. [/spoiler]

Enough about Valhalla though; this game is pretty fun.
I thought I'd hate the ship battles, but I loved them.
I thought I'd love the sneaky stuff, but it was mostly bland with a few exceptions. There are also quite a few "timed" missions that can get really annoying and a lot of "one off" missions with mechanics that are never again usefull. These are parts of the game that you will have to go through to get to the good stuff. The peas with your steak if you will.

The story is very good.
You really want to know what happens with the MC.
If you skip the mostly useless stuff you have about a 30 hour game here while doing a reasonable amount of side stuff. 10-15 hours if you race through. My advice would be to skip the base building stuff though, as it mostly does nothing. Not even aesthetically. It's just there for the grind. Upgrade your gear and most importantly your ship as quick as possible.

The Abstergo stuff is tacked on and forgettable. Just skip through this as fast as you can. It makes some sense in the grand scheme of multiple games, but not really. It is an aside at best.

Learn to live with the janky controls. You will get stuck on a pebble and you will jump to your death for no good reason multiple times. It's what every legendary pirate does and I would bet a thousand pieces of eight that it's because of whatever the Animus equivalent to Denuvo is. 
Heck, thinking about it; maybe [b] I [/b] am an assassin and Denuvo are the templars.
[i] Bloody bullion, Ubisoft. [/i] You tried to tell us all along!

All in all I'd recommend this game if you like the pirate setting otherwise you can skip it.
No matter what; I'd wait for a sale.

What to say about this game that’s not been said already? It's a diamond of a game. The perfect balance of story, map exploration and side activities. Loved this game so much that I 100% the game (single player only, never cared for multiplayer). By the time I was done, the Jackdaw was able to take out the most powerful man-of-war ships in 2 hits. 1 golden mortar shot and 1 full elite cannon broadside. The Jackdaw after defeating the 4 legendary boss ships was the undisputed apex monster of the Caribbean. As for its Captain, he was in a league of his own. He was armed to the teeth with golden flintlock pistols, Officers Rapiers for blades, wore epic Mayan garments and was packed to the brim with bombs and darts. A one man army. He also had a fleet of ships conducting trade across the Atlantic. He knew the Caribbean like the back of his hand, having explored every nook and cranny of the seas.

If any of the above mentioned characteristics interest you, play this game and try to make your Edward the Master of the Caribbean. If you already played this game and did not achieve 100% completion, give it a try. The world the developers built has so many places of interest to explore. As basic advice, pace yourself if you try to 100% the game. Do a bit of story, do the side activities and repeat.

Unfortunately I was unable to achieve 100% completion on the Freedom Cry DLC. Adewale was a righteous liberator of slaves, but due to time limitations I was unable to make him into the apex assassin he deserved to become. 

An absolute gem of a game and the best Assassins Creed game I have played to date. Simply a 10/10 game.

This game was the sh@t when I was a kid and I loved playing it on the Xbox 360 back in 2014. However replaying the game again on steam I have to say that it was not as good as I once remembered. For starters the tailing missions are a pain (although an expected one) and the combat though visually appealing is pretty simple, you can easily pull of counters and tank gunshots making it possible to kill 10-15 enemies without even taking a single hit. It makes it easy to learn but as you keep playing it gets old FAST. The stealth in general does not work too well in this game leading you to depend on combat to get around. I'd say the only parts that lived up to my nostalgia is the killer soundtrack and naval combat, fighting off 2 frigates in the middle of a storm dodging waterspouts will always be fun. I CAN ONLY REALLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME TO CASUAL GAMERS, and I don't mean that in a bad way, because the repetitive objectives and missions can only entertain you for so long. So as long as you pace yourself with how much you play you can enjoy AC Black Flag.

[h1]The Ultimate Pirate Sandbox[/h1]

I would recomend this one even to a non-AC fan. It is a great pirate game.

- This one tells a story about a pirate who only cares for himself. He steals, murders and does many other bad things. Then he meets a crossdressing woman who tells him that is not a way to live. She want's him to sacrifice his life for a "a greater good". He refuses at first but when all the people he cares for die he realizes that being selfish really isn't the way, so he stops being a priate and becomes an ninja terrorist, so that now he can steal and murder with an excuse. 

- Appart from the usual conspiracy cr*p, Black Flag is actually a good enough character driven game. Of course it has some weak moments but those are mostly caused by the illogical creeds and fanaticism of the conspiring factions and the antiestablishment nonsense (and really bad written death of a really good characters). No, Ubisoft, pirates did not fly black flag as a sign of freedom? There is however very little of it. For the most of the game you trully are a pirate. You meet templars and assassins but you don't care for them. You just rob them.

- The gameplay did not really change much from AC3 appart from the fact that sailing levels are now a major part of the game. A bit polished, improved with some new features and really fun. The parcour is the more stable and responsive and the world is filled with actually interesting things to do. Not just tons of collectibles. It is also the first AC since Brotherhood with actuall colour and pretty world. The story is nicely paced, not forcing any urgency on the player, so you can experience everything on the pace that most fits you.

Bonus:
- Why is it every time someone in the game says "Jesus" they spell it "Jaysus" in subtitles? For a "multicultural team of various faiths and beliefs" there should be no problem to use the name with clear conscience.

Ubisoft has done an excellent job in characterizing plot and protagonists in Assassin's Creed 4: Black Flag, demonstrating through a consistently well paced and attractive affair that it has learned a lot from the stumbles of the recent past. Black Flag's adventure knows no downtime and literally leaves us breathless, catapulting us into the action from the very first moments of the game.
During the early stages of the game we learn about Edward Kenway, the new protagonist, initially unaware of the centuries-old rivalry between Templars and Assassins. It was precisely the neutrality of the protagonist that allowed the team to sketch a "lighter" personality: impetuous and impulsive, fascinated by the idea of easy riches rather than the pirates' ideals of freedom and equality, the one in Assassin's Creed 4 is one of the best characterized protagonists in the entire saga. Vaguely reminiscent of the bravado of the much-loved Ezio Auditore, Edward Kenway immediately strikes a chord in the player's heart, while the plot seamlessly alternates between moments of amusing lightheartedness and others that are decidedly more serious and profound. It is a multifaceted personality, enhanced by an assortment of secondary characters perfect for highlighting her, and embedded in a compelling coming-of-age story.
The struggle between the Templars and the Assassins, focused in this chapter on the quest for the Observatory (a place from which to control humanity), will reshape Edward's character to some extent, bringing him closer to the ideals of the modern hero in a gradual and convincing manner, without ever lapsing into triviality or easy moralizing. We will also observe the evolution of the plot itself, strengthened by a balanced screenplay that is always capable of teasing the right strings, which will engage the videographer while avoiding weighing him down emotionally.
Finally, the characterization of the "pirate background" is interesting. We will experience firsthand some of the most important events in what is called the Golden Age of Piracy, encountering famous buccaneers and privateers, discovering lesser-known events of that decade (which runs from 1715 to 1725), and generally encountering a setting exceptionally dense with references, details, and curiosities.

[b]Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag is the sixth game of the franchise, developed by Ubisoft Montreal and published by Ubisoft.

"Unfold mates, let's move!"; the main words of this title of Assassin's Creed. What is more special about this game than its precedents? Well, this location is a dream to reach it: palm trees, white beaches, exotic fauna and a clean, crystalline blue sea; This is Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag.

After all this time playing with Modern Assassins, it's time to see how Abstergo is doing. Recently opened, as a more concealed method of obtaining information about the Pieces of Eden and training soldiers, Abstergo Industries established Abstergo Enterntainment, a building where, from people's point of view, Modern Templars are creating games with help from test volunteers. The player is taking control of one of these testers in first person view. You have no name given, no reflection offered, but you are the protagonist, the one that many in the building are relying on, and you with the help from the Animus Omega, offered by Abstergo, you are living the memories of Edward Kenway, a sailor at first, father of the Templar Grandmaster Haytham Kenway and grandfather of the Colonial Assassin Connor Kenway, witnessing his maturing from a man who is only keen on gold and wealth to a responsible Assassin.

Set during the Golden Age of Piracy, 1715-1721, the story of the game is based on Edward's life in the Caribbean Islands and the conflict between Assassins and Templars, in which of course, he made his own invitation. His desire in becoming a pirate known in the Caribbean Sea and the duty to carry out his mission to the very end, which is to protect the great Temple of Eden from falling into the hands of the Templars, put Edward in certain choices that will define him for the rest of his life. Edward as a personality is a man who seems to know what he wants from his life, but the more the player approaches the end of the game, he starts asking questions about who he really must be.

The Caribbean Islands as surroundings are something entirely new to the old titles, because for the first time the location is not only a city or more cities but a whole sea full of islands, treasures and secrets waiting to be explored. With his own ship, the Jackdaw, the player through Edward can sail through the Caribbean Sea, accompanied by wind breezes and crew songs that offer a nice adrenaline to the exploration. Fauna and population give the life of this map through their presence in all the jungles, villages and great cities of the Caribbean: from Nassau Island full of pirates, to the city of Havana full of Spanish and South American civilisation.

Similar to his predecessor's engine, Assassin's Creed III, Black Flag has many additions in terms of stealth and combat. Additions of new tools, such as sleep arrows with which you put enemies asleep, or firecrackers that distract them to a desired point make stealth much easier and diversified for the player. Edward is equipped with 2 Hidden Blades, 2 swords and a maximum of 4 single-shot pistols that can use them in combat anytime, and the most special part of the 4 pistols is that Edward can use them all in a consecutive sequence, this movement being similar to a Peacemaker.
The combat moves remained the same, Connor's grandfather being able to parry, counter-attack, stun and disarm his enemies. A mini RPG system is introduced through the upgrades of Jackdaw and Edward. To become stronger, Jackdaw's weapons must be upgraded with materials that can be obtained by destroying or boarding Spanish and English ships. And Edward can dispose of an even greater arsenal by increasing efficiency and capacity of his stealth and combat gear.

At the end of the day, Black Flag delivers a world brimming with gorgeous places to go, amazing secrets to discover, nefarious pirates to stab and a world where you can make your own fun.

I've included my review for Assassin's Creed Freedom Cry below this one, as I received it as part of a bundle.

Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag Review:
Wow, what a game. Black Flag is what many consider the pinnacle of the Assassin's Creed franchise, and having played all previous games until this point, it is undeniable that it is superior to all previous in mechanics, story, and visual fidelity. The game itself has the most seamless movement of any Assassin's Creed game until this point in the franchise, fixing nearly all of the movement issues of the legacy titles, allowing you to really feel like there are no limits to the way you want to navigate. The ship combat is absolutely fantastic, taking a basic yet enjoyable system from Assassin's Creed 3, and refining it to a more complex but more enjoyable experience. While the game suffers from some issues regarding optimization performance wise, it still holds up as a beautiful game 10 years later.
Took me roughly 70 hours to 100%.

Assassin's Creed Freedom Cry Review:
A short tale about one of the main characters from Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag, it is what I would call a return to form of the classic Assassin's Creed style. With smaller missions encompassing a larger more narrative driven story, and less focus on collecting everything on all corners of the map, it really shines as its own title, and is in my opinion superior to Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag.
Took me roughly 4 hours to 100%.

AC4 is a Chronological prequel to AC3 and AC Rogue, and should definitely be played after AC3 and before AC Rogue, otherwise the present day story and events will be out of order. 

The smelly dumpster fire of PC gaming, aka Ubisoft Connect, is the only downside to this game - requiring you to login every time you launch the game, including going through 2FA if you have it enabled. According to Ubisoft, this is working as intended because apparently older Ubisoft games have always-online security flaws baked into the code that can't be patched out. Not only do you have to log in every time you launch AC4, but if you play with a controller for extended sessions, Ubisoft Connect will log you out for being idle (doesn't detect xbox series controllers apparently) and when you exit AC4 your saves won't sync until you launch the game and log in to Ubisoft Connect again. 

Aside from Ubisoft Connect being a sadistic troll of a clown show from Ubisoft, AC4 Black Flag is well worth playing. I give it a 13/10 score

Pretty good game. I like games with strong content and [i]Black Flag[/i] undoubtedly offers it. Interesting cut-scenes and well-represented characters, as well as voice-acting are great. Also I would like to praise the sea battles, which looked spectacular. I don't remember having experienced such sea battles in any other game (yet).
The downside, perhaps, is that the game progressed very slowly. The whole first half (about 10 hours) passed in the same rhythm and quite slowly. The second half, on the other hand, was very interesting, especially the story. Unfortunately the tasks you have to complete are very similar from start to finish and lose their charm after a few hours of play.
Another negative thing that often became frustrating was how difficult it actually was to control your character. I mean, this game is designed to be very flexible so you can do all these jumps and tricks, but the problem that comes with it is that the character is extremely sensitive to any button press, and so often happens that you want to run up the wall, but instead your character starts fighting with some soldiers on the way. And vice versa: if your current task tells you to kill someone, then in the middle of the fight your character decides to jump somewhere or do something else that can ruin your task. All this weirdness can cost you throughout the game even a few hours maybe. Especially when you have to start the task again because some nonsense happened.
But all in all definitely a highly recommended game. Especially for those who like the pirate theme. The beautiful tropical environment and, of course, history also have a positive effect, as most of the main characters are based on real pirates.
It's also worth mentioning that it's a very big game and even after completing the main story you can travel around for dozens of hours and discover new areas and complete side tasks. And on top of that you can spend a few hours in the Animus database, as it contains plenty of exciting reading.

This is gonna sound somewhat cliché, but as an Assassin's Creed game, Assassin's Creed 4 Black Flag does not work as one at all. As a pirate game? It's the best I've ever played. The combat is the simple counter and kill system, which is fine. If it ain't broke, don't fix it (even though I'm glad they did in future games). The parkour is alright. Since AC3, the removal of the free run combo buttons for just a single button has wacked out some of the controls, but everything is still intact. The story is very good as a pirate game. It has Edward going from a greedy man trying to get everything best for his family, to a man who stands under a code and responsibility. A rather respectable man. They could've done this without the Creed, but it's whatever. The reason why I keep saying it doesn't work as an AC game is because they literally keep all that shit to the last 2 sequences. It feels very rushed, like it was never meant to be an AC game, which I'd believe it if it wasn't. Last but not least, the naval combat. It's simple, but that's what makes it just fucking great. It's way easier than I remember it being, I was able to take out 3 of the 4 legendary ships by the end of the game. Speaking of that side content though, that's what took up most of my hours, admittedly. AC4 really just draws you in with all the side content unlike future AC games where side content is just really really optional. It's still one of my all time favorite games, but as an Assassin's Creed game, it's nothing special.

Probably my favourite game in the AC Series.

What stands to me out is our character, Edward Kennway.

Unlike most AC games, where the MC is always somehow connected to the Assasin Brotherhood, be it a parent or family member being part of it or has a connection to the ever going fight between assasins and templar, like in AC 3, Edward stands out.
 
We have not a lot of background information about, but is it really necessary ? 
What is there to know about a welsh man chasing a dream, being ready to go through hell, so that his live can be full of adventure, while managing to have wealth to spend for the ones he care. 
Theres no need  if he had a rough childhood, is trying to avenge his dead parent/s or trying to protect the love of his life.(btw these welsh are just built different sheesh)

There is no ulterior motive, no "i do it for the greater good" or dead parents, like most AC games start.

He wants to become rich, while living the adventures life or die trying.
In a way its actually a really basic MC motivation, kinda like Monkey D. Luffy


And while following his own set path, it just so happen that he comes across the battle between assassins and templars.
It is only after coming in contact with them, and on the way losing pretty much everyone of his friends, where he realise that he can have a much bigger effect on the world.

I think I never felt so much for a character in an AC game, close to it maybe ezio in revelation, but i definitely related to Edward more.

Gameplaywise theres only one thing i want to say:

When sea battles where hinted in AC3 i was so hyped to see how theyre gonna develop it, due to next game being pirate-themed.
And by god i love it so much. 
The excitement that i feel everytime when i managed to defeat a warship ( I FUCKING LOVE THE MUSIC THEY PLAY WHEN YOU DEFEAT SHIPS OR THE FORTS, ITS SO FUCKING EPIC)   and the peak being obviously the legendary ships, with each one having a certain gimmick to the fight. (btw against the duo ship fight you can techically make infinite money if you defeat one and lose on purpose, you still get the 10000R from the first ship)

After now playing it on pc and remembering all the fun i had when it first came out and i played it on the ps3, 
I can only recommend AC 4 Black Flag to everyone who has a love for a good old open world AC game.

Ubisoft is worse than Abstergo.

Easily the best AC title. And like, it's not even close. The blend of ship exploration, combat, and interaction with more or less classic AC gameplay is magnifique! Plus, they managed to successfully transition their entire narrative legacy into a new story line. Until this point, we followed Desmond as he navigated his Assassin lineage. But then they killed him! And in this game they introduce a faceless protagonist who explores Desmond's memories. It's the perfect way to continue the story.

At the same time, they spawned the idea that they, Ubisoft, were actually owned by Abstergo and were therefore Templars? That type of meta-narrative across, like, seven games is indescribable. 

And then there's the bulk of the narrative, which is Edward Kenway's story. And dude's a straight up pimp. Just like Ezio, we watch this cavalier, brave, and foolhardy boy turn into a decisive, cunning, and ruthless man. But unlike Ezio, he doesn't walk the Assassin's path until later in life. He just continues to greedily follow his whims as everyone around slowly dies or quits. It's devastating and tragic and like, from the Assassin's Creed franchise?

Hand to hand combat is fun. Sneaking is fun. Upgrading your ship and fighting the map corner bosses is satisfying. There's a few too many collectibles, but not too many.

A disclaimer. I also own this game for the Xbox 360 and have put in probably an equivalent amount of time. This is the peak of the series. I'll hear no counter arguments.

In AC I, we learn the assassin's creed through Altair, who has forgotten the values that make an assassin. In AC II, we learn the assassin's creed through Ezio who, initially arrogant, seeks vengeance on behalf of his kin and through hardship after hardship grows into the ideal assassin. In Black Flag, we learn the creed through Edward, a selfish, greedy pirate who sort of accidentally got caught in the conflict between the assassins and the templars. Just like Altair and Ezio's stories, personal conflict meets political conflict in Edward's but unlike theirs, Black Flag, to me, is a lot more personal. It's so easy to fall in love with Edward's character in this game.

Firstly, the tailing missions in this game are evil. There are way too many of them and they last for way too long, and just when you think it can't get worse, the game makes you tail ships. I enjoyed the traditional assassination missions, however. There were a lot of sequences I loved too, a lot of scenes which had gravity to them, which shaped Edward into the assassin he eventually becomes.[spoiler]It took the deaths of Blackbeard, Hornigold, Vane and Read for Edward to realise the dangers of the pirate life, a life of living for nothing, or worse, living for greed. Just when he decides to better himself, he realises it's too late as while he was wasting his life away at sea, his wife had died years ago, raising their child.[/spoiler]Black flag has the best written side characters in the series so far. Although longer than its predecessors, this game is the perfect length for its story. 

The map is huge, filled with vast negative space serving as the site of many chaotic ship battles and beautiful sea shanties. The setting of the Caribbean also plays well with Black Flag's simple yet adequate crafting system, as you plunder ships and scavenge through forests to hunt for materials. The remote forests and islands of the Caribbean is contrasted with its many bustling cities and villages. Kingston, Nassau and Havana are fun to walk through and even more fun to parkour through. However, every part of the map is as stunningly beautiful as the next. The map is so much more vibrant compared to its comparatively dull predecessors. There's so much to do in this vast world, there are so many islands, beaches, forests, villages, forts, templar hideouts and Mayan ruins to explore. You can take up assassination contracts for money, raid warehouses for materials, hunt animals, harpoon sharks and whales, and defeat the boss 'legendary ships' for even more rewards. On top of all of that, you can even dive underwater to explore caves and wrecks, and in perfect pirate fashion, search for treasure, on land and at sea, and there's just as much depth to Black Flag's naval combat system.

The way this game handles modern-day interesting. One issue I have with this is how it takes away from the special feeling of being important not just as the assassin you're living through, but in the modern-day as who you actually are. In this game, instead of being any character with any amount of depth to them, you're the most unremarkable and random researcher, so unremarkable in fact that you're unnamed.

Combat (with the exception of naval combat) is mid, stealth is mid, and while I truly appreciate how well-designed the map is, I can't help but prefer the traditional huge cities that my mind has correlated with assassin's creed. Personally, I much rather parkour on rooftops than on trees, and some of my favourite aspects of the AC games, Black Flag just didn't pay much attention to. In terms of story, characters and sheer quality, Black Flag is an amazing game, and while it's not quite what I look for when I play an AC game, I did have a lot of fun playing it.

[h1]IMHO[/h1]In my humble opinion, stands as the pinnacle of the Assassin's Creed franchise. A harmonious balance between expanding your base, navigating treacherous seas, engaging in naval battles, and indulging in the good old stealthy gameplay, all set in a breathtaking environment. The story, too, captivated my heart, making the overall experience a truly solid concept. [h1] [/h1] [h1]Atmosphere[/h1]This esteemed title in the world of gaming boasts an enchanting tale, absorbing gameplay, and a delightful mix of land and sea exploration, all seamlessly woven together to create a mesmerizing experience. The individual elements of Black Flag, remarkable in their own right, unite in a spectacular symphony of swashbuckling adventure and espionage.[h1] [/h1] [h1]Over View[/h1]I beseech you, fellow gamers, to grant Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag the admiration it so richly deserves. Do not let this extraordinary odyssey pass you by. Approach it with zeal and intrigue, and you shall be rewarded with a gaming experience that will linger in your memory long after the final curtain falls. So, hoist the Jolly Roger and embark upon the thrilling escapade that awaits you in Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag – you shall not regret it, hopefully.

Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag, developed by Ubisoft, is a fantastic entry in the series that breathes new life into the franchise. The game's open-world setting, compelling story, and engaging gameplay mechanics make it one of the best games in the series.

The game's setting, a Caribbean pirate world, is breathtaking, with stunning landscapes and beautiful vistas. The attention to detail in recreating this world is impressive, with a great deal of effort put into making the world feel alive and dynamic.

The gameplay mechanics in Black Flag are excellent, with a wide range of activities and missions to keep players engaged for hours. The game's naval combat is a particular highlight, with players able to command their pirate ship and engage in epic battles with other ships on the open sea.

Overall, Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag is a must-play for fans of the series and anyone looking for an engaging open-world adventure game. Its beautiful setting, compelling story, and engaging gameplay mechanics make it a standout entry in the franchise.

TL;DR: Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag is a fantastic entry in the series, with a breathtaking open-world setting, engaging story, and excellent gameplay mechanics. The naval combat is a particular highlight, and the attention to detail in recreating the Caribbean pirate world is impressive. It's a must-play for fans of the series and anyone looking for an engaging open-world adventure game.

My favorite AC game. Seamless exploration of the Caribbean--and it's a lot of fun! The story is very good, about a man who had to lose everything in order to find himself. The only two drawbacks are the modern-day storyline (I enjoy it but it's not even close to as interesting as the pirate setting) and the tailing missions. For an AC game it's a 10/10, but for a game in general it's a 9/10.

Sadly, I am a fan of Assassin's Creed and have enjoyed this game, but I can no longer recommend this or any game sold by UBIsoft due to major cloud infrastructure issues that are breaking my game saves. I have no idea which games will now have this issue, on top of the 4 that have it now, so I am losing all confidence in UBI. 

Not only are cloud saves breaking and causing games to crash (4 UBIsoft games so far, including Watch Dogs 3, Starlink, AC: Valhalla, and Odyssey, any computer, any network), but UBIsoft has had open tickets from me for over EIGHT MONTHS and the experience has been one of the worst customer service experiences Ive ever had with a game company. The end result of my ticket history is an UBI tech actually retaliating against me (I was frustrated and told them I was going to stop being an UBI customer) and putting my support account into "identity check" mode, forcing me to verify all my info again even though we were IN THE MIDDLE OF A CONVERSATION. They didnt like my comment about not being their customer, and the next thing that happened was my support account is locked. 

As such I am changing my reviews for ALL UBIsoft games still in my accounts - all 29 of them that I've had for over 15 years. A company that cannot properly host cloud saves and tries to pass the buck to customers and ABUSES customer time and patience like this is not a company Ill pay another penny to.

I used to think that this was the pinnacle of the series, but I don't think so anymore.

My main problem with this game is that I've spent 50 something hours with it, and it picked up pace only towards the latter sequences. There is just so much of upgrading that it takes me away from being an assassin, and makes me be a pirate. It's a great pirate game, albeit a little repetitive game. The world is massive and full of usual filler stuff, but if you take away the assassins and just go out there to explore, conquer outposts, and gather treasures, it makes you feel like a real pirate. But at the same time, it's a below average assassin game that doesn't know whether it wants to be a linear stealth game or an open world jungle and sea combat game for most of it's duration.

Don't get me wrong, it's still among the best AC games. But the title of Assassin's Creed isn't really deserved. I'd probably enjoy it way more if was a separate game from AC series. They should have taken the AC references out completely, and named it just Black Flag. 

This game suffers from a massive identity crisis, and frankly, it's the first one in the series to have this problem, which was later manifested in entries like Origins, Odyssey, and the incredibly dogshit Valhalla, which are trying to replicate the success of Witcher 3 without having any sort of understanding why Witcher 3 is so universally beloved.

First few sequences were fine. I don't remember at which point in story it happened for me, but about halfway through I just couldn't be fucking bothered anymore, and decided to finish this as fast as possible to get most out of the story. And you know you've failed at making a game when your players don't want to explore the side content and use the fast travel thing to finish the game ASAP, only to be dissappointed even by that. After that, I spent a good few hours just fooling around the world just because of how fun it was when there were no assassins in sight.

Ah yes, the story. Where do I even begin with that? All characters were greatly written, and then, halfway through the game, [spoiler] EVERYONE FUCKING DIES except for Edward, Anne, Adéwalé, and the assassin leader [/spoiler]. I couldn't even create any sort of connection to the templars, be it positive or negative, because they get like 25 minutes of screen time IN 50+ HOURS. And it's a shame, because even in the more boring later half of the game, there is character developement, there are interesting things happening, but by that time I was so done with the story that I wished I could just tick a box and play the rest in linear story mode. The story is good, but terrible at the same time, because again, this game suffers from a massive identity crisis, where it doesn't know if it wants to be a pirate game, or an AC game.

As for the pirate parts- the gameplay has bright moments when it's on foot, but on sea it's fucking boring, even when fast traveling. The ship combat gets repetitive after a while, boarding ships becomes a chore, managing your fleet is really annoying, and on top of it all, the most enjoyment I've got out of this game was WHEN I WASN´T EVEN FUCKING PLAYING I- WHEN I WAS IN THE ABSTERGO SEQUENCES OUTSIDE OF ANIMUS, EXPLORING THE OFFICES. This is the one game in the entire series that nailed these sections down flawlessly. They aren't too long, they have some great exploration in them, and they don't exhaust you (besides the horrendous FOV, but it's bearable). 
The point where I've actually started enjoying this game was when I've finished the story, and was free to explore the world and do whatever I liked. That was when I was fully allowed to be a pirate without the game trying to push linear gameplay down my throat.

I recommend this game to people who want a pirate game and can't wait for Skulls & Bones. As for AC fans, just finish the story ASAP and then never play this again.

Straight up; this game made me shanty centric. Then I got my entire friend group into shanties because I really went ham on the shanties. I have so many shanties in so many languages. I have learned Spanish because of shanties. I love shanties. This isn't even being entirely hyperbolic for the sake of comedy. I mean it. There is nothing better than just simply wanting to pour your heart out with the boys. I just love homie connections like that.

It's mostly a good game. The water looks great, sailing and naval combat is satisfying. I just wish developers would stop taking away control at every second turn and skip (or at the very least give the choice to skip) the repetitive and useless animations, slow menus, repetitive cutscenes, automated movements etc. It's the curse of the console I guess, or at least all these console ports suffer the worst from it (e.g. Tomb Raider), but it's just so annoying to have the game constantly leave you sitting there as nothing but a spectator. I want to [b]play[/b], not watch. The same applies to automated camera movement. It's [i]NEVER[/i] helpful, always messes up movement, has been there since the very first AC title and has always pissed me off. What do developers think this adds to their game? 
Ironically, the parts of the game that resemble the usual Assassin's Creed m.o. are the worst and most boring aspects in my opinion. The story isn't very interesting to me (which doesn't say much, as good gameplay is worth a hundred good stories for me, personally, and my patience for long, unskippable cutscenes galore is approaching zero), and the parts outside the Animus are more of the bad stuff. Slow, tedious, boring, uninteresting, and with that guy in your earpiece trying [i]way[/i] too hard to be witty.
Stealthing is so bugged and stealth missions are so randomly infuriating, it's as terrible as ever. Climbing is hit-or-miss as usual, but it feels like it's gotten worse compared to AC3 (constantly jumping on small crates as if they were a high ledge, not going where you want to go, small earthen mounds being impossible to climb etc.). But at least the naval combat is redeeming. I wish there were other single player titles focussing on that. It's what sets this game apart and makes it worth replaying.
Multiplayer is terrible and nothing but a tacked-on play of tag, [i]if[/i] it works at all.

GAMEPLAY:
 It is the sixth major installment in the Assassin's Creed series. Its historical timeframe precedes that of Assassin's Creed III, though its modern-day sequences succeed III's own. 

The plot is set in a fictional history of real-world events and follows the centuries-old struggle between the Assassins, who fight for peace with free will, and the Templars, who desire peace through control. The framing story is set in the 21st century and describes the player as an Abstergo agent. The main story is set in the 18th century Caribbean during the Golden Age of Piracy, and follows notorious Welsh pirate Edward Kenway, grandfather and father of Assassin's Creed III protagonist Ratonhnhaké:ton (Connor).

Unlike previous games, gameplay elements focus more on the ship-based exploration of the seamless open world map, while also retaining the series' third-person land-based exploration, melee combat, and stealth system. The game's setting spans the West Indies with the three main cities of Havana, Nassau, and Kingston, along with numerous islands, sunken ships, and forts. Players have the option to harpoon large sea animals and hunt land animals. For the first time in the series, naval exploration is a major part of an Assassin's Creed game, where Edward Kenway captains the Jackdaw, a brig he captures from a Spanish fleet in an early game mission.
