Black Flag is by far the best Assassin's Creed game, but it's still a very flawed game. Combat is mindless outside of ships, running is super janky, and most of the story missions are tedious. This game's main redeeming feature is the fact that it's a pretty fun pirate game sometimes. Sailing around plundering ships, taking forts, and discovering islands is fun, but what isn't fun are the uncharted collectibles scattered across the Caribbean. You can ignore them, and you'll never know the pain of spending 10 minutes on getting a single animus fragment. For me, though, I like to get all the things if I can, and I've been doing that. It sucks.

There is waaaaay too much fluff in this game. Some of it's fun to do, like treasure maps, plantation heists, legendary ships, and naval forts. Still, then you have assassination missions, naval contracts, Templar hunts, Mayan steles, shanties, viewpoints, messages, manuscripts, chests, and, worst of all, animus fragments. 

It's endless, and they're all the same. 

Some of this shit at least has good rewards. Shanties are each new songs for your crew to sing, which is nice when you're sailing 3 km to get a chest and animus fragment on the east coast of Florida, and lots of chests means lots of money. Some of the naval contracts are interesting too, but it's usually "find ship and sink it" or "get me x resource." Assassination missions are rarely that fun either. It's always "go place kill guy" only variety is the location. The best I've seen so far was a guy who took a fort that I'd already captured and bragged about it when I went to kill him. Otherwise, they are bland and forgettable. Templar Hunts are side quests, so they're about the same as any other story mission. They're hit or miss. Everything else is " go place get thing," and that's it, but there are many things. Steles are a super easy puzzle and a long unskippable animation. Manuscripts are glorified chests, shanties are annoying to catch, and messages have long, unskippable animations.

I fucking hate animus fragments, though, and they're everywhere. They're usually a climbing challenge, and climbing sucks. It's slow, janky, and tedious. It's why viewpoints kind of suck too, but at least they let you know where all the other bullshit is on the map so you can do your chores. Playing this game feels like work, and it canonically is work. I've been actively avoiding the story missions for a while now because I'm scared that I'm close to going back to the Abstergo part of this game. It's like a super long boring cutscene that you can't skip with even more bullshit to find and do. I haven't even unlocked the diving bell yet.

I played this game to completion when it came out on Xbox back in 2013 and restarted it a couple of times on pc, but never finished it again. I enjoyed it back then, but now I've sunk an extra 30+ hours into the game and see all its flaws glaring at me. About 90% of my sessions playing this game only ended when it crashed, so they were around 3 hours each. At least it saves every 10 seconds, so you never really lose any progress. Overall the game does have its moments, and depending on how you play, it may even be fun, but if you wanna get all the things, never play this game. You'll regret it. 

Now, if you excuse me, I'm going to go back to my chores. 

EDIT: shipwreck water levels are stressful and fuck ubisoft for not adding steam achievements so i could catalog my struggle. The story is also pretty solid.

Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag is honestly one of the best Assassin's game. I've 100% the story, side missions and colletibles except for burried treasures which I kinda found like a chore. The combat is addictive and the graphics is awesome to be 2013 game for sure! 

You can choose between a stealthy approach and kill from the bushes or as a force of nature and kill everyone in a 1v10 fight which both are addictive and fun! The game is an open world pirate game which does not force the storyline upon you and you are free to roam and collect treasure if you'd like or sink down enemy ships to plunder their resources for upgrades. I found myself endlessly sailing across the see collecting treasures and sink ships I see fit quite entertaining while hours went by. 

[b]Just a few things to note:[/b]
- There are some bugs in the game but not that a reload can't fix [i](reloads usually don't set you far back and it's quick to recover progress lost)[/i]
- Even though I've a quite decent+ PC [i](rtx 3080 and 32gb RAM)[/i] and played on absolute highest quality the game crashed on me "just" 3 times. Usually didn't loose too much progress opening my game again, so to me it was kinda "whatever"
- The button to sprint and the button for parkour/climb is the same, so sometimes when I just wanted to run past an obstacle I went climbing instead which can be annoying sometimes but nothing I can't just drop down from and walk around xD

[h1]ASSASSIN'S CREED IV BLACK FLAG[/h1]

Arrrrr! And my Assassin's Creed gaming spree has ended (until new AC: Unity and AC: Rogue releases that is) for now and I can honestly say that I haven't had that much fun since AC 2. Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag offers lots and lots of stuff to do. Just the seafaring on your Jackdaw ship while listening to the sea shanties of your crew truly immerse you into the pirate theme this game went into. And as a pirate themed game, I haven't played a realty good one ever since Sid Meier's Pirates Gold!... and that was close to ten years ago!

Naturally, this game has its ups and downs but compared to AC3, it is a huge step in the right direction. Black Flag has a bigger focus on "simply having fun", gameplay speaking. Storywise, the pirate-Animus setting delivers, while you progress your pirate career as Edward Kenway and seek help from other known pirates like Charles Vane, Blackbeard, Anne Bonny, James Kidd, etc. You have many lost treasures on maps to search in this game, which unlocks elite upgrades for your ship and I would say mandatory if you want to have a chance against the legendary Man-o-War battleships. You got the whaling minigame that opens up Edward's crafting abilities and unlocks better gear, similar to Far Cry 3. The Templar vs Assassin theme is still there in this game but not as omnipresent as previous AC games.

My biggest deception in this game was the pointless "modern setting". Walking around, finding sticky notes and hacking colleagues computers only to have a pseudo continuation from the events of AC 3. Another big irritant of Black Flag was the many many many eavesdropping and tailing missions. Way too annoying and very frustrating as you are forced to play these missions as how the developer has intended for you, which is don't be seen, don't do this/that... "oh you did! DESYNCH and repeat mission! ENJOY! :D"

Aside from these irritants, the rest could be pretty much discarded but I'll still elaborate on the Positives and Negatives.


[h1]POSITIVES:[/h1]
[b]+Killer visuals! A gorgeous, vibrant world full of reasons to go exploring!
+Outstanding naval combat. (Picks up from AC3 naval combat but improved in every ways).
+Progression systems are profoundly rewarding (crafting, upgrading Edward and the Jackdaw, etc).
+Terrific pirate story that depicts how they lived and also, shows you the pirates in a human light. 
+Seafaring and on-foot exploration complement each other in a perfect mix.
+Gameplay mechanics delivers but hopefully, they'll be more refined in the new AC games. Although the moves are more fluid compared to AC3. (Played with Xbox One controller).
+Decent soundtrack from composer Brian Tyler. Also the sea shanties arrrrrr good![/b]


[h1]NEGATIVES:[/h1]
[b]-I haven't experienced any bugs or gamecrashing glitches but read that Black Flag has nasty issues at launch, until it was properly patched that is! I did had a few glitches and were all fixed by reloading a checkpoint!
-Just too many eavesdropping and tailing missions... I mean c'mon, couldn't you have done something different here? I just hate those missions badly!
-Bland and boring modern setting. Now that Desmond Miles is out of the portrait, this new unknown guy you play as in the Abstergo Entertainment Montreal studios has little to offer in the main Templar vs Assassin everlasting confict. That setting felt forced and I do hope on the future AC games, the modern setting will be much more developed, just like the other AC games.
-I would've liked to see the other main countries in this game, like the French and the Dutch, who were colonizing the Americas of that time too and also, at war against Spain and England. More countries at war, the merrier! Might happen on AC Rogue, who knows!
-If the multiplayer is your reason to play AC games, you'll find nothing new here... same old same old and not my cup of tea![/b]


[h1]OVERALL:[/h1]
[b]Fantastic game! I really enjoyed this game which you have tons and tons of stuff to do. Ubisoft have redeemed themselves with Black Flag since AC3 was beyond disappointing in every possible way. Black Flag delivers and whether you're new to the Assassin's Creed franchise or not, this game takes a big pause in the main modern theme of Templar vs Assassin from previous games and enables you to just jump into this fun pirate theme and well, just have fun plundering other ships![/b]


[h1]RECOMMENDATION:[/h1]
[b]Yes, absolutely! AC fan or not, play this game... as long as you dig the pirate theme![/b]


[h1]AVELINE DLC:[/h1]
Short straightforward DLC that doesn't add much in Aveline de Grandpré's storyline. It picks up at the end of AC Liberation and whether you played or not that game doesn't matter for this DLC. You just start somewhere and after you've done climbing the side of a Fort, you have to liberate someone inside and the end... Very below-average! Sad because Aveline could have been a decent main character to play, aside from AC Liberation but is quite under-developed. Overall, if it comes with your Black Flag game, give it a shot since it is very short... 45 minutes max! If you only have Black Flag game, discard this DLC! You won't miss much! 


[h1]FREEDOM CRY DLC:[/h1]
You play as Edward Kenway's quartermaster, Adéwalé. This DLC picks up at the end of Black Flag. It doesn't give you any info about Edward's and Black Flag storyline so you can always play this DLC in any way you seek as it doesn't impede BF main plot. Adéwalé is a great character. His involvement into liberating the slaves of Port-au-Prince felt rewarding each time I got to massacre the slavers. You do have some seafaring missions as you do steal a ship and roam the West-Indies. You have about ten or so locations to explore. Freedom Cry has a good mix of side missions and main ones. The story is solely focused on liberating Port-au-Prince from the French slavers and there is little to no mention of the Templars. You have about a good ten hours of playtime in FC DLC. My main gripes are like Black Flag, way too many eavesdropping and tailing missions! I'd actually recommend this DLC if you get around to it. Freedom Cry is fun and straightforward while having the fun parts of Black Flag like seafaring, in the DLC. 


...

[i]...and now... awaiting UNITY![/i]
No repetitive quests. No cultist bs. Is an actual stealth game. And more importantly it takes far less to beat main story than Origins/Odyssey/Valhalla!
yes

Black Flag is still one of my personal favorites of the Assassins Creed games. The combat is pretty much the same as AC:3 so it can get a little repetitive, but that isn't where this game shines anyways. The naval combat and plundering are super fun and only make you want to grind to fully upgrade the Jackdaw. The story is, in my opinion, pretty good. It's no Origins or Valhalla, but for the time it was released it is amazing. I absolutely recommend this game to those who like the AC games or pirates, or both!

i Remember playing this game almost 10 years ago and having a good time, I saw it on sale and thought aye why not? Assassins Creed Black Flag is probably the best Assassin's Creed game and IS the best pirate game you can play. the jackdaw is really fun to play around with and upgrading the ship not only makes the numbers go up but gives nice visual upgrades to the ship. 

The land combat is typical assassins creed combat so if you like it or not you already know what you are getting yourself into. The ship combat is a ton of fun and i always get into fights with other ships simply because of how fun it is to take one down and board it, if you like challenge then the legendary ships will be a treat.

the story is decent, the characters are likeable and Edward is a fun protagonist but the pacing feels rushed and just when you're really getting into it the game shoves you into a modern day segment which i wish the series got rid of after the events of 3.

The world is also great, the crew singing shanties as you sail the seas makes exploring enjoyable and encountering bigger, more difficult ships makes me want to just sail around and see what the map has to offer. However ubisoft cannot help themselves and have placed so many collectables that it is overwhelming and at one point i just stopped caring, i say if you are someone who likes collectables only do the ones that give you actual rewards. 

In conclusion i think this game is a a lot of fun, sure it isn't perfect and there are a ton of glitches but if you just sit down and engross yourself in a fun pirate adventure then you wont be disappointed.

This review is from the perspective of a casual Assassin’s Creed fan. Having just watched a timeline video after, I had no idea there was an ancient alien race or a deeply connected story that spans across all the games. I had played Black Flag back in 2013 when I was in middle school, with it being the first M rated game. Up until then I had only had a Wii and was unable to run many of the AAA titles that were on the PS3 and Xbox 360. While I still enjoyed playing the game almost 10 years later, it has very obvious flaws that make it hard to recommend in 2023. Starting off with the positives. I thought the settings and characters were serviceable. The Caribbean is fun to look at and parkour around. While I can’t say that exploration is particularly engaging due to the cookie cutter collectibles, the vibe of being a pirate is engrossing and a strong motivator to keep playing. The parkour is also satisfying when it works, but I feel like often times, Edward is running up walls I didn’t want him to. Edward Kenway’s journey from a broken down family to drunk to eventual hero was rewarding. Seeing him go from a self absorbed and selfish man to one who is willing to give his life for the cause of the Assassins was the best part of the game. These moments really allow his personality to shine. Unfortunately the rest of the game is mediocre. Exploration is lazy with no real reason to collect collectibles. I’m not against collectibles, but I like when they are tied to a story or side mission, I do not like collecting for collecting sake.  Missions were insultingly mundane. Half of them felt like trailing missions which are horrendously boring. The rest were run of the mill infiltration missions that were easy due to the watered down combat and intrusive minimap. The game does not encourage exploration in a way that Fallout or RDR2 would. Where these games have a story either through a side mission or wonderfully crafted visual/environmental storytelling, Black Flag feels almost copy paste. I will say this game, despite being severely outdated and unimaginative from a gameplay perspective, makes for a fun “turn your brain off” type of game. It’s easy to pick up and play, especially when engaging with its well crafted ship combat. This is especially true on the Steam Deck, which I played on. You don’t have to think much about what to do or where to go because the minimap does everything for you. Lastly, while the story isn’t amazing and is held together by a great protagonist, after watching the timeline video, I can appreciate the expansive lore that is present in the Assassin’s Creed universe. While I can’t recommend this game in 2023, I look forward to trying Assassin’s Creed II, since I’m currently studying abroad in Firenze, where the game takes place. 4/10

What in Davy Jones’ locker did ye just bark at me, ye scurvy bilgerat? I’ll have ye know I be the meanest cutthroat on the seven seas, and I’ve led numerous raids on fishing villages, and taken over 300 ships. I be trained in hit-and-run pillaging and be the deadliest with a pistol of all the captains on the high seas. Ye be nothing to me but another source o’ swag. I’ll have yer guts for garters and keel haul ye like never been done before, hear me true. You think ye can hide behind your newfangled computing device? Think twice on that, scallywag. As we parley I be contacting my secret network o’ pirates across the sea and yer port is being tracked right now so ye better prepare for the typhoon, weevil. The kind o’ monsoon that’ll wipe ye off the map. You’re sharkbait, fool. I can sail anywhere, in any waters, and can kill ye in o’er seven hundred ways, and that be just with me hook and fist. Not only do I be top o’ the line with a cutlass, but I have an entire pirate fleet at my beck and call and I’ll damned sure use it all to wipe yer arse off o’ the world, ye dog. If only ye had had the foresight to know what devilish wrath your jibe was about to incur, ye might have belayed the comment. But ye couldn’t, ye didn’t, and now ye’ll pay the ultimate toll, you buffoon. I’ll shit fury all over ye and ye’ll drown in the depths o’ it. You’re fish food now, lad.

At this point in time the best pirate game ever, the combat is solid, the setting is amazing, the story is not that bad (specially if you like pirates, since you will encounter some famous ones) and in general it is a pretty good game.

At least it would be if that were all, but this is actually an Assasin's Creed game, and a very bad one at that, not as bad as III but well, if you ever played one of the most recents AC games you might know what im talking about: Suddenly breaking the flow of the story to be in Astergo so you can spy on them, tailing missions where the npcs are just a bit slower than you, so you have to be very careful; and, of course, bugs, because no AC game is completed without weird bugs.

Tl,dr: Best pirate game ever, bad AC game.

Pros
1. The vast majority of the naval aspect of the game 
2. Nice main music theme
3. Great setting and presentation
4. The final act of the main story
5. This game also contains an assassin's creed game


Cons
1. Main storyline was.... meh. 
2. In my opinion the parkour system is worse than in the previous entries. It feels more "super-heroic", unrealistic, weird camera angles still there on occasion, difficulty jumping diagonally, still no crouch button, not cohesive (the character jumps like he's spiderman and all of a sudden he cannot climb a particular rock to save his life - a rock that I can climb in real life and I'm not a super assassin mind you)
3. I was never a fan of the stealth system. Still bad, even worse. I don't like the way they used the eagle vision that allows you to x-ray people and see them walking behind the buildings. So the character is a fusion of Spiderman and Superman but he still can't climb the rock I mentioned above. Still, when you tail someone and the target goes a bit further, a countdown begins, even when it's perfectly clear where the target is or heading. Still the enemy AI acts weird in terms of when and how they spot you.
4. The combat system is the worse of the series so far. Still very easy and not rewarding at all, which makes the stealth mode a bit pointless because you can basically kill everyone. Enemies are very polite and sometimes await the animation to finish before attacking one at a time. Combat animations are as unrealistic as they can be. Your character sometimes takes 3-4 seconds to kill a single person because he delivers an excessive number of blows. There are times that the character slashes the chest, the head, the torso, the ears and still the enemy attacks again. That's allright though because as I said, the rest of the enemies are polite and await their turns.
5. I found the map to be a bit confusing at times
6. Present day. It's like the game is saying to you "You've had your fun, now do your chores or else you won't be allowed to play any more". You have to earn it I guess :Ρ

Summary
It's really simple. This is an assassin's creed game integrated inside a pirate game. If you like the pirate aspect of the game and also liked any previous entries in the assassin's creed franchise, you will probably like this game very much. It's very fun. The gameplay cons are not enough to destroy the game, because the game keeps you entertained. It's fun. It's a fun game. Have fun.  Unless you don't like the pirate stuff. In that case play the Ezio trilogy again.

Bonus Review - Assassin's Creed Rogue
-> This is supposed to be a new Assassin's Creed full game. In reality it is a black flag expansion with only minor additions to the gameplay but the setting is worse, the gameplay gets repetitive because there is quantity over quality, there are too many collectibles in such a degree that they just lose their value. The writing is bad, the dialogues are bad and the story doesn't make sense in a lot of parts.  Combine all the cons above with the black flag gameplay and you have a mediocre game at best. Skip it.

This game is astoundingly good. Like unbelievably amazing.

Everything was amazing. The characters were 9.5/10, the plot was 9/10, the soundtrack was 9/10, and most amazingly the setting (time and world building) was an easy 9.5/10 if not 10/10. I can literally only think of three complaints:
1. There were a LOT of tailing missions. The parkour/maneuverability mechanics were really good though, so they weren't terribly painful.
2. The plot took a little bit to get really interesting, but not very long, and once it kicked in it was amazing.
3. Obligatory 3 saying I wish there was more content (like outfits to unlock, templar hunts, etc.)

I will most probably return to this game at a later date, but seeing the ending (no spoilers) left me really happy and resolved the story with such a great conclusion that I need to step away for a bit.

Overall, a 9.25/10, would very highly recommend.

TL;DR - Loved this game to bits. You'll love the story, world exploration, and characters. It's the best pirate video game, period.

Assassin's Creed Black Flag is an action-adventure game developed by Ubisoft Montreal and published by Ubisoft. It is set in the Caribbean during the Golden Age of Piracy, and follows the story of pirate captain Edward Kenway as he becomes embroiled in the conflict between the Assassins and the Templars. The game features a vast open-world environment, with a variety of locations to explore, including cities, jungles, and seas. The game also offers a wealth of content, including ship-based naval battles, tombs to explore, and side missions to complete. The game's combat system has been improved, offering players a range of weapons and abilities to use in battle. The game also has a robust upgrade system, allowing players to upgrade their ship and equipment. Overall, Assassin's Creed Black Flag is a well-designed and enjoyable entry in the franchise, offering a rich and diverse experience for players.

[b]By far the best pirate game.[/b]

-The highlight of this game is the naval navigation and combat. It looks great and has a lot of strategic depth. All the different weapons and tools you have are very satisfying to use and you often end up in the middle of epic battles with multiple sides fighting each other.
-What makes the above even better are some of the best weather effects I've seen in a game with massive storms, waterspouts forming and huge waves coming towards you that will create many many memorable moments.
-In the more calm moments you are sailing and singing and visiting various islands for treasure and collectibles. The graphics still hold up with some beautiful areas.
-The story, characters, writing and voice acting are all fantastic, probably the best out of all the AC games. The cities are ok with Havana being the most interesting. The parkour is worse than the previous games but not too bad.
-The worst thing about Black Flag is that there are many missions that follow the eavesdrop/tail/assassinate with the walk --> cutscene --> walk --> cutscene formula like in the previous AC games and they are frustrating and repetitive.

Pirates!!!!
This is easily one of my top 10 favorite games of all time, I play it every summer! I own this on various platforms. Ever seen the TV Series "Black Sails"? The cast played this game on set before scenes, and in downtime!
That being said...

[h1] One Of The Best Pirate Games Ever! 🏴‍☠️ [/h1]

[i] First of all, I want to say that I played this game on the day of release on my console back then. Even then I fell in love with this game. Almost every aspect of this game is brilliant, which is very funny because it was made by Ubisoft, who can no longer make good games. I consider them degrading company. [/i] 😜

[b] But that doesn't mean, that there aren't any negative aspects. [/b]

[hr][/hr]

[h1] So let's start with the PROS. [/h1]

[b]1. Graphics.[/b] For 2013 they are very good. [i] Especially for game from Ubisoft.[/i] 😅 However, it is also worth noting that for the PC port, the graphics could have been slightly improved, but this is just a port, and not some kind of remaster. So I won't complain about it.

[b]2. Plot.[/b] Well, objectively speaking, it is not bad, but it won't set the world on fire either. It is quite simple, in some moments even clichéd, but it does its job quite well. Many people do not like the fact that the main character [u]is not a trained Assassin[/u], but [b] I'll disagree[/b]. Yes, for game series about ASSASSINS - it's pretty uncommon and ridiculous, but in my opinion this story shows one important detail that [u]ANYONE[/u] can be an assassin and you don't have to be super special to become one. 
And given that at the time of the release of the game, Assassins were mainly striving for somewhat [u]good goals[/u], then such a twist may encourage the player to various actions. Also, Edward Kenway is an ordinary person who wasn't interested to save the world etc., but simply strived to live the way he wants, so that he doesn't need anything. [u]He is not[/u] ready to help everyone he meets for free. He only does what suits him and what [u]HE[/u] wants. This is quite common for [u]ANY[/u] person, and thus this plot "twist" makes the main character more relatable. 
About the  other different plot twists and etc., I, perhaps, won't say anything. They seem to work, but not without drawbacks. [i]Although the previous games in the series did not have any mind-blowing twists too, so, again, I won't complain about it.[/i] 🤔

[b]3. Animations, effects, weather conditions, sea and surroundings.[/b] They are done with a bang. The storm is one of my favorite events in the [u]WHOLE[/u] game. It feels dangerous and tense. It interferes with maneuvering and attacking, doesn't allow the ship to be abandoned, and also creates an atmosphere. And the music, [i]( about which we will talk about in the 4th article )[/i], adds cinematic quality and additional tension to it. I would also like to note the architecture reflects that era of the 18th century really well.

[b]4. Music. [/b] It is beautifully composed. Each track in the game has a nicely done melody, and also perfectly complements different events. Battles, stealth missions, etc. I loved these soundtracks so much that [b]I even added them to my Apple music.[/b] 😎

[b]5. Battles, both on land and on water. [/b] Naval battles and boardings are done quite well, I would even say excellently. I can feel how powerful are cannons, how strong is the wind, how quick is my ship etc., All of that adds extra immersion in the game. The maneuverability of your ship and naval strategy also play an important role. All of that combined works perfectly and you can feel the action. Especially in battles against legendary ships or fleets of 5 Manowars and galleons. I feel the scale of the battle and its intensity. [b]As for the battles on land, there were some drawbacks here. I'll talk more about this in the cons category.[/b]

[b]6. Side quests. [/b] Well, there are also some [u]drawbacks[/u] here, but I would like to note that most of the missions and activities from the secondary category are done quite well. They are interesting and have various awards. [b]For example Whale hunting is one of my favorite gameplay elements.[/b] And Templar hunts are [u]the best side quests[/u]. They are interesting, not so boring, as others and also, there aren't billions of them, which doesn't make them tiresome.

[h1]Now, let's talk about the CONS. [/h1]

[b]1. Console port. [/b] Because of this, most aspects in the game are lame. Graphics suffer, inconvenience of controls, as well as optimization. The game has the stupidest limit of 60 frames. Because of this, I still [i]( not only me )[/i] had critical frames drops. [u]ON MY $5,000+ PC[/u]. [spoiler]( Ye, idc what you will say about it. Name it however you want, bragging or smth, again, idc)[/spoiler] There are occasional frame drops. I have seen these drops more than once just over time in the game. [u]ITS UNPREDICTABLE[/u]. [b]This pisses me off.[/b] But, its not that bad. They are not [u]THAT MUCH[/u] critcal and most of the times I needed to wait a little for FPS to stabilize. 
[i]Also, this silly integration with the Ubisoft launcher also sometimes gets in the way for me.[/i]

[b]2. Parkour. [/b] In Unity, it is done very well, but in this game and previous ones it is very inconvenient, unpredictable and stupid sometimes. [b]But still, it's pretty good.[/b]

[b]3. Combat on land and stealth. [/b] [i]Let's return to this topic.[/i] Although the animations are cool and badass, this doesn't prevent the gameplay from being rather boring. Press the left mouse button million times and occasionally do not forget to press "e". [u]THAT'S IT[/u]. Nothing more is required from you. Terrible AI makes things even worse. The NPCs are so dumb it's not even funny anymore. Stealth aspect becomes really goofy and suffers from this combat system. There is [u]NO[/u] intended punishment for the fact that you completed the mission "loudly". Of course, there will be more enemies, but that's not a big of a deal, because it is enough to occasionally press "e" and you are invulnerable even against [u]100[/u] people.

[b]4. Bugs. [/b] [i]I wont talk about it so much[/i]. Animation bugs, not loading missions or disappearing NPCs, etc. There aren't much of them, but they still are [u]annoying[/u]. [b]But, to be fair, I will say that this was also in the version for consoles.[/b]

[b]5. Side quests and and how monotonous they are. [/b] Go there, kill that one, collect all the fragments etc. They are very simple and tedious. 
[u]BTW[/u] It is very annoying that in order to complete the game 100%, you have to swim through [u]ALL[/u] small islands just to collect [u]ONE[/u] animus fragment or [u]ONE[/u] chest. And game doesn't provide anything to help you out in this situation. Game will park your ship [u]10000[/u] miles away from island and wont give even a boat, [u]THAT PLAYER LITERALLY HAVE AND USES IN SEA HUNTING[/u].

[i] I guess that's all I would like to say. [/i]

[hr][/hr]

[b] Let's sum it up then! [/b]

[b] I think that the game is just great, [u]even[/u] almost the [u]best[/u] in the series! It has interesting plot and gameplay and also its very [u]badass[/u]😎. However, it also has downsides. The monotony of content and poor combat system can sometimes get player bored quickly. [/b]

[h1] My rating is 7 or 8/10. Definetely a must-try. ☠ [/h1]

They were not lying when they said that Black Flag is THE pirate game. ubisoft is developing skulls and bones, true, but until that comes out, black flag will always reign supreme in the pirating experience (bar things like sea of thieves, where the playstyle is different). Played through for the first time in 2023. The game holds up very well, Definitely a classic.

Pros:
-Sailing the seas, ship battles, and especially boarding are super fun! Great loop
-Treasure hunts!
-Sea shanties!
-Great OST
-Great sound design
-Pretty good story
-You can take out an army once you learn to use all your tools
-Whaling boat hunts are a nice distraction
-Difficulty is just right for a casual game

Meh:
-Graphics aren't bad, but  aren't great. Beginning to show its age.
-Even on an RTX 3080 I was getting some stuttering occasionally. More annoying than anything.

Cons:
-Felt like it was pretty slow to start. I was about to uninstall around the two hour mark, but I pushed through. Shortly after, there  was a fort battle and some of the story started getting more interesting. Give it time, your patience will be rewarded.
-The fleet management mini-game gets old fast
-You will learn to hate sharks, eels, jellyfish, and sea urchins
-Aveline DLC was way too short, not even an hour. 
-The legendary ship El Impoluto defies all logic and reason and is hands down the worst fight in the game. Luckily it is side content and in no way required for anything. I suggest you find the YouTube walkthrough from EZ BLAZE. Do exactly as instructed and you will get through it without shattering your controller/keyboard/mouse.
-The big one for me, controls are on the edge of feeling dated. I died many times because the controls did something unexpected or were unresponsive. This is compounded by what seems like shifting timing windows to do a counter attack. Sometimes I hit it immediately and still get pounded by a brute with a boarding ax. Sometimes I hit with timing that should have been way too late and I roll to safety or deflect a blow. Coming from a newer AC game like Odyssey or Valhalla, it is a little jarring.

Final Verdict:
-Do you like Assassin's Creed? Do you like pirates? Do you like ships? Do you like an interesting story? If you answered yes to any of the above, buy it! But get it on sale. Not that it isn't worth full price, but it goes on sale constantly. Your patience will be rewarded.

This is a STRONG maybe. This game is lots of fun, but for whatever reason, it runs extremely poorly on my computer. I have an i9 13900k CPU, 32g of DDR5 6200mhz ram, and a 3080. I also run it on an NVME drive.

Nothing about my computer should have a difficult time with this 9 year old (at the time of writing) game. And yet, it starts to stutter, then it full on freezes. Alt-tabbing out and back in will let it run smooth again, for a moment, then it'll freeze again. I've tried multiple fixes from online and they work for one session, then they don't work again.

The current fix I'm using is to go into task manager, and set affinity to less cores. Disabling some seems to make it run smoothly. For now... Again, each fix I try is only temporary, so who knows if I'll run out of fixes.

As for the actual game, it's a lot of fun, sailing around, pirating, assassinating targets. All a lot of fun. Just a shame about the performance. 

If you play the game and start having these issues, I'd recommend refunding it, as trying to fix them is one hell of a fruitless journey. 

Beware, and good luck.

The game features a vast open-world environment to explore, a wide variety of missions and activities, and a rich historical setting that immerses players in the world of pirates and assassins.

One of the main strengths of the game is its open-world environment, which is beautifully designed and offers a vast range of activities for players to engage in. From exploring the Caribbean sea and its many islands, to engaging in naval battles, to hunting for treasure, there is always something to do and discover.

The game also features a compelling story that follows the life of Edward Kenway, a pirate-turned-assassin, as he navigates the treacherous waters of the Caribbean. The story is well-written and engaging, and players will find themselves fully invested in the game's characters and their struggles.

Another highlight of the game is the combat system, which is fast-paced and satisfying. Players can use a variety of weapons and techniques to take down their enemies, and the game's free-running mechanics allow for smooth and fluid movement throughout the world.

Overall, Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag is a fantastic game that offers a wealth of content and a rich, immersive experience. The game's open-world environment, engaging story, and satisfying combat make it a must-play for fans of the series and newcomers alike.

It's early 2013 and the Assassin's Creed machine at Ubisoft is in full swing. In 2007, the publisher took a chance with a new title, establishing the ongoing, endless war between the Assassins and the Templar Order. Two years later, they refined the concepts started in the first game, creating Assassin's Creed II. That game moved from the Holy Land to Renaissance Italy, and traded out the dour Altair for the charming Ezio Auditore da Firenze.

The jump to the sequel firmed up the game's framing story: these adventures of Altair and Ezio were experienced through the genetic memory of their ancestor, Desmond Miles. Most of the game took place in the past, but you were actually Desmond reliving those lives in the near-future of our modern day, via a device called the Animus.

Assassin's Creed II was also the beginning of Ubisoft settling into annual release pace with the franchise. ACII was followed by Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood, a title that continued Ezio's story, perfected the formula, and still stands as one of the high points in the franchise. 2011 saw the release of Assassin's Creed: Revelations, which was a rough end to Ezio's life. While ACII and AC:B felt fresh and innovative, Revelations was a bit of a retread and new mechanics like hideout sieges, didn't feel like they fit within the series. The franchise didn't completely fall over, but the momentum was slowed.

2012 moved from Ezio's tale to a pair of adventures in early colonial America: Assassin's Creed III and Assassin's Creed III: Liberation. While the latter was a spin-off title built for the PlayStation Vita, the former represented the first real sequel in three years. Ezio was replaced with Connor, a half-English, half-Mohawk warrior with ties to both the Assassins and Templars. Ubisoft moved to the new AnvilNext engine for the game: Connor could climb trees and sail in the Atlantic in a pair of series' firsts. ACIII also saw the end of Desmond's tale in an ignoble demise. Unfortunately, it was an uneven experience; it wasn't horrible, but it didn't live up to the pedigree of Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood for some.

A year later, the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 were on the way out, being replaced that year by the PlayStation 4 and Xbox One. It's worth stepping back for a second to realize that Ubisoft had released five Assassin's Creed games within the same generation. Assassin's Creed, Assassin's Creed II, Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood, Assassin's Creed: Revelations, and Assassin's Creed III all launched on the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360. (A PC release wasn't always a given, usually quite delayed when it did happen.)

Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag was a trailblazer though. It was launching on the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 like its predecessors, but it would also see a PlayStation 4 and Xbox One release a month later. For the first time, Ubisoft had the chance to bridge the gap between consoles.

Black Flag was still an Assassin's Creed game, but it left the land-based shenanigans behind for a high seas adventure. Edward Kenway—the grandfather of Assassin's Creed III's Connor—wasn't a hero or even a member of the Assassin Brotherhood, he was a pirate that stole the outfit for personal gain. Edward hobnobbed through the Caribbean during the Golden of Age of Piracy, counting Blackbeard, Mary Read, Anne Bonny, and Charles Vane as friends and contemporaries. He had that same cocksure swagger present in Ezio's first outing.

There's a moment when Black Flag falls into place for me. Edward is doing the Assassin thing, climbing buildings, running through alleys, and shanking guards with his Hidden Blade. But then, you decide it's time for a change in scenery. Edward goes sprinting down to where his ship, the Jackdaw, is waiting. Your boots land on the deck and you just begin sailing. It's a seamless experience, jumping from land to the high seas.

Assassin's Creed III featured on-ship segments, but they were separate from the main game. Here, both ideas are joined in a single core, and it just works. You were always free to go wherever in Assassin's Creed: that's part of the idea of the open-world. But this jump from terra firma to the deep blue sea, it feels freeing. There's a sense of exploration and freedom borne of the fictional idea of pirates: a concept forged by classic pulp serials and television shows like Captain Blood (featuring Errol Flynn), Sinbad the Sailor, Treasure Island, Captain Kidd, and The Buccaneers.

Black Flag offers up that feeling in a way that honestly no other game has before or since. It's a great Assassin's Creed game, but at points you can see the traditional Assassin's Creed side straining under the weight of years of development. Assassination and stealth were solid and strong, but instant fail tracking missions, glitches, and the lack of an easy way to get down from high places without killing yourself were all missteps. To be clear, these were issues carried forward from the best games in the series, they just continued to haunt the franchise.

None of that matters though, because the stuff on land worked well enough, the stuff on the high sea was sublime, and the gulf between the two was non-existent. Nothing was holding you back. To use part of the series' catchphrase: everything is permitted. Go find some unexplored islands. Go destroy and pillage some ships. Take up an assassination contract that'll see you chasing one target from land to sea. Swing from your mast by a ropeline and dive into the crystal clear ocean.

That "crystal clear" was also a big part of Black Flag's charm. The game looked good on the last generation of consoles, but jump to PlayStation 4 and Xbox One offered such a vibrant and beautiful world to explore. The detail put into the wood, canvas, and ropes of the Jackdaw and other ships. The waves and sea spray as your ship cut through the ocean, or the massive waves of a vicious storm. Of particular joy to me is just sitting in the mix between ocean and land: on the beaches there was water lapping at your feet, the gorgeous shallows a few feet in one direction and jungle plants waving in the breeze in the other. And beyond that, the signs of civilization.

Black Flag stands above the best of the series is because it carries forward what Assassin's Creed II and Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood did well, while also forging new ground for the franchise. Edward Kenway is as charming as Ezio in his own way and his journey from opportunist to heroic outlaw is a good one. Stealth and climbing remains as solid as it was in the past entries. The Caribbean offered Ubisoft a chance at a bit more color than the darker American Revolution, and moving to the next generation of consoles meant it looked amazing. Black Flag was even so good that it may have ruined the franchise for some folks; those who simply want another pirate game, instead of one involving the assassins.

And it still holds up. I may miss parkour down (introduced in Unity), but Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag is still a high point in my PlayStation 4 library. For me, it's the best in the series, followed closely by Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood. Assassin's Creed Origins has the chance to repeat the feat, coming from the same creative director as Black Flag and showing players the beginning of the Assassin Brotherhood.

Phenominal game, brought me back to Assassins Creed. I plan one 100% my save file and maybe doing a couple challenge runs. Pros:
-The sea Shanties actually had some kind of reason for existence, which was nice.
-Being able to fasttravel between any viewpoint was Awesome, so helpful oh my god.
-Convoy concept from AC III was simplified in this version, which was nice.

Cons:
-Storyline felt drawn out way too far, they waited a lot longer than I think they shld've to have edward finally redeem himself, made it hard to root for him. All the other games were about the same concept, a ego-tistical butthead of a an entitled man who learns wisdom and self-awareness, and yet this one, I never liked the protag bc he spent almost the entire game being a selfish jerk.
-Abstergo moments were very underwhelming without your character having any kind of voice. Just let us pick a freaking gender and give them something. Super intense moments meant nothing when you just silently walk away from them without so much as a gasp.
-The metaness of Abstergo making games about the templars and assassins and revealing both orders to the world was absolutely not my vibe. It made everything feel really cheap.
-only the fanciest reward outfits had any purpose, the rest were all cosmetic, as were the art pieces, and the ships appearance. No effect on gameplay. Plus the fancy outfits didn't even have HOODS which all the animations include hoods, so he kept pulling up Nothing.
-There were just too many collectibles. I had ZERO interest in doing anything with them. just hundreds and hundreds of them, and they didn't MEan anything. What a waste of programming. :/
-Tutorials and explanations felt really drawn out, not showing up until way past the point where you already would've likely explored them or started doing the puzzles involved in them just bc they were on your minimap. 
-Rewards for completing challenges were pretty much useless. Multiplayer stuff and cheats that turn off game progression. Held Zero appeal to me.
-Inconsistencies with storylines and lore in the game. Plus half the black NPCs were voiced by white people Very Very obviously? You couldn't hire any black people to voice some NPC's?  [spoiler] Plus there was the part where they put a message on the television in the bunkers saying to look out for shaun and rebecca....with pictures...while shaun is WORKING in the lobby. and when they board the ship with slaves and edward and vane get stranded they use THAT ship. so where the hell did all the slaves go?[/spoiler]. 
-In the freedom cry dlc, my freaking machete didn't make noise. Just the machete. Bizarre glitch, for the character's MAIN weapon, thank u ubisoft.

Summary: Interesting, not a bad game at all, recommend for people who like the series and who are cool with ship battles and stuff, but still definitely has its flaws. Also, if you DO get this game, whatever you do, please don't use the Physx Particles, they screw your framerate over so bad. Just turn 'em off, helped me loads.

Great, if slightly dated, game. Dated as in the hand-to-hand combat is utterly trivial if you know where your E and Left Mouse Buttons are located and the parkour is... adequate, if somewhat janky, difficult to control, and imprecise, at times. Definitely less polished than some of the more recent games (I.E. Unity and Syndicate). The graphics, however, hold up pretty well, even eight years later.
The ship boarding is really fun and a good way to get money.
The story is pretty good, and Edward is a great protagonist. He goes through a great deal of character growth, which is always nice to see.
The Community Challenges are no longer active, so it is, as far as I'm aware, impossible to get one outfit (Explorer), one set of pistols and swords (Captain's Wheellock Pistols and Persian Scimitars respectively), and a few appearance items for the Jackdaw, but neither of the weapons have advantages over anything you can get normally, and while I do really like the Explorer outfit, I guess I can live without it... not that I have much of a choice there :/
It used to be that if you bought the Gold Edition, you wouldn't get Adewale's game, Freedom Cry, but that seems to have been "fixed", since it isn't said that Freedom Cry is included in that pack anymore. Whatever works, I guess ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
Overall, my favorite AC game, though my perspective might be slightly stilted because it's, I think, the first Assassin's Creed I played to completion, and I don't care for the newer RPG-style games.
I reckon it's the best mix of modern enough to not feel extremely clunky, while not being an MMO.
P.S.: You can pet dogs, cats, pigs, goats, cows, and possibly some other domesticated animals that I'm either forgetting or don't know about, which is the best feature in any game, bar none. 10/10, would recommend, if only to pet animals.
My first game that has completely cleared the level. The gameplay of naval battles is very novel. Sailing around the world on a sailboat is very playable.

Assassin's Creed: Black Flag is a beautifully crafted game that transports players to the Golden Age of Piracy in the Caribbean. The open world is vast and filled with plenty of things to do, from naval battles to treasure hunting and much more. The graphics are stunning and the gameplay is smooth and engaging.

However, there is one major flaw that really stands out for me: the complete lack of Somali pirates in the game. As someone who is interested in the history of piracy, I was disappointed to see that such a significant group of pirates was completely absent from the game.

Somali pirates have been active in the waters off the coast of East Africa for centuries, and they have played a major role in shaping the history of piracy in the region. It's a shame that they were not included in Assassin's Creed: Black Flag, as it would have added another layer of depth and authenticity to the game.

Overall, while Assassin's Creed: Black Flag is a great game, the absence of Somali pirates is a noticeable omission that detracts from the overall experience. It's a shame that such a significant group of pirates was not included, as it could have added so much to the game.

Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag is about a Pirate named, "Edward Kenway", who has this BIG dream about living a life of fortune, and sailing the high sea's and making money, just enough to care for himself and Caroline.   See, Caroline didn't care about having a fortune, she just wanted to live a happy life with Edward, but Edward didn't see it as living happily with nothing, instead he hates living poor, and not having funds enough to actually feel as if he's got something good.  

Edward was supposed to promise Caroline that he'd only be gone for a year, two at most, but Caroline asks him, more like needs him to, "Promise", only a year, PROMISE!  Edward from that point forwards didn't exactly promise, he just starred with nothing to say.  Later Edward would be found sailing the high sea's, but he's caught in a battle between Ships, his men are dying, everything is falling apart.  An Assassin by the name of, "Duncan Walpole", infiltrates Edwards crew and kills the Captain, but before the Assassin could kill Edward, they're both knocked off the Ship and into the raging waters.  

Upon surviving the storm, Edward notices the Assassin is next to him alive as well.  The Assassin offers to pay Edward in hopes that he'll let him go, but Edward being a greedy Pirate, asks Duncan, "You don't happen to have that coin on you now, do you?"  Duncan stands up with his gun pointed at Edward in hopes that he'll kill Edward, but Duncan has no bullets.  In a panic, Duncan throws his gun and runs.  

Edward chasing after Duncan, finally kills the Assassin and takes his clothing, and retrieves a letter from the Governor.  Edward takes up this letter and heads for the location the Assassin was heading, to collect Sir, Duncan's reward.

A few things I didn't like about Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag, are the Tailing missions.  Gotta be honest, Ubisoft went WAY over board with these tailing missions, about every sequence had them.  Good gosh, so many tailing missions, I'm about to lose my mind!

Stealth and Combat were tedious, in a way you can say fighting Multiple enemies at once and your parry timing being slightly off, you'll get hit.  I've had a lot of times where I went to Parry, Edward wouldn't parry so I'd just die because the game decided NOT to give me a warning.  As for the Stealth, not easy when every enemy has eyes in the back of their head,  plus the snipers are annoying too.

Collecting useless items that has no use!  Seriously Ubisoft?  You really had to add pointless time wasters to your game to make it longer? Ugh!  No one wants to go around collecting pointless Animus Shards, or Sea Shanties, or even low money chests.

What I did like though, is the Story and the characters.  You get attached to James Kid aka Mary, and the entire crew.  It was sad to see them go, especially Thatch, he was a good one!

Ship Battles were very fun, which is probably the most liked thing about AC 4.

The very end once Edward is finished with all of his missions, Revenges, you see he has a flash back to his partners in crime, and the one at the very beginning you saved from the Soldier's, he was just a Humble Merchant, and yet he got caught up in Edwards ways and later you find out, not in the game, but somewhat in game, he died.

If you like Pirates and Sailing the high Sea's, get this.

I had a great time playing Assassin's Creed Black Flag! It's an oldie but a goodie! The story was engaging, the characters were entertaining, and the open world was huge and full of interesting activities. I especially enjoyed the parkour aspects of the game, as it made for some truly thrilling moments. Plus, there were plenty of side quests to keep me occupied.

My favorite part of the game was the stealth elements. Sneaking around, taking out targets without being detected, and using the environment to your advantage was a lot of fun. I also liked the combat system, which was challenging but not too difficult.

The graphics weren't the best, but they were still pretty good. The soundtrack was also great, and the voice acting was top-notch.

Overall, Assassin's Creed Black Flag was a great game and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an "old-school" open world adventure.

Lets get the elephant outa' the room. This game is a masterpiece, hands down.

It’s a smart, sprawling sequel that’s very free and fun while trimming most of the fat that bogged down Assassin’s Creed III’s ambitious but uneven adventure.
Sailing across the massive expanse of The Caribbean, exploring gorgeous and unique islands, and getting yourself into all sorts of swashbuckling trouble provide some of the most rewarding and memorable stretches of gameplay I’ve experienced all year. Even after putting in more hours well after finishing the story, I’m still discovering new islands to explore and tombs to raid.
Tropical locales and the amazing water effects on the open seas. Minimal loading and maximum draw distances that seem to go on for miles. The way the camera zooms out when your ship reaches its maximum speed, and the sunset turning blood-orange, is simply amazing. 

Black Flag learns from AC 3’s initial 10 hours of banal hand-holding by immediately throwing you into the action. After a lean and exhilarating opening mission that places you in the blood-soaked boots of Connor’s much livelier and more likable grandfather Edward Kenway, the world blossoms and allows you to explore its vast uncharted waters. The size of the world is staggering, and the fact that it's absolutely brimming with fun and rewarding activities made me want to get lost as possible as I traveled from point A to point B.
When you ignore the main mission prompt and simply set out in search of your own fun, Black Flag is at its best. It treats you like an adult, and allows you to explore its gorgeous and activity-filled world to your heart’s content. Want to discover every nook and cranny of Kingston’s sprawling expanse in search of Templar secrets? Or would you rather buy a small fishing boat and hunt for all manner of deadly sea creatures, using your spoils to upgrade your character? Maybe you just want to sail to a remote island, climb to the top of a mountain, and gaze in awe at the world around you. Black Flag is all about embracing freedom and carving your own path through the world.

Also, the world’s vast scope invites a handful of hiccups. For instance, the body of a guard who’s holding a necessary key might disappear if you leave the area, meaning that you have to restart a mission. Black Flag is peppered with these sorts of annoyances, and though they certainly aren't deal-breakers, they had a tendency to pull me out of the experience a bit too often.
Ubisoft wisely avoids the morose spaghetti bowl that Assassin’s Creed’s plot lines have become in favor of a much lighter tale that embraces the adventuresome spirit of classic pirate stories. I loved the fact that Edward is so unlike his Assassin relatives, and much more interested in the pursuit of money than the opaque goals of some secret cabal. It's a refreshing change of pace from a series that in 2013 had started to take itself a bit too seriously.

Black Flag also tends to repeat some of the Assassin's Creed series’ favorite mistakes, like forcing you to tail a prospective victim at a safe distance for minutes on end while you’re given an exposition dump. It’s mighty annoying that I had to spend 10 minutes listening to rarely memorable dialogue before I could make the kill.

I would like to talk about the story in every detail, but I must restrain myself from spoiling it. Unfortunately the story is just too good to explain to somebody who hasn't played the game, so I urge everyone to experience it for themselves.

Black Flag is a mixed bag. Let me break it down for you. 

The Good: 
Playing as a self-serving pirate that gets caught up in affairs bigger than himself was an enjoyable introduction to the wider story of Assassin’s Creed. The pirate simulator portion of the game is really fun and IMO the best reason to consider playing it. The score is excellent, the in-universe music is lively, and the shanties are catchy. The polished visuals have aged well and really sell the Caribbean experience. 

The Meh:
The good parts of the open world overstay their welcome by the end due to Ubisoft’s signature runtime padding with copy-pasted content and pointless collectibles. Most rewards, while cool, don’t feel worth it by the time you get to them. 

The Egregious: 
Poor performance even on a modern card far exceeding the games recommended specs (due to forced double buffering compounding other poor decisions. This issue was trivially fixable). An artificial framerate cap of 60 that cannot be disabled through any means.  No widescreen support. Crashes on startup on Nvidia graphics cards. Poor support for mouse and keyboard: Menus are almost impossible to navigate, and the keybindings are nonsensical. The game essentially requires a controller or 3 hands to play. Controls are sluggish and have a mind of their own. Pressing a key when an enemy/object is highlighted often does nothing or interacts with something other than what is highlighted. This is annoying when trying to open a chest but a huge problem when you fail an assassination because of it. You don’t control Kenway as much as suggest a general course of action. You push in a direction and hold the parkour button, and the game decides what the character does. This makes precision jumping and movement impossible and leads to the feeling that success or failure in parkour sections is an RNG coin-toss instead of being based on player knowledge or skill. The stealth tailing missions in a boat that handles like… well a boat, are indeed atrocious. 

Sassy Creedo: Pirate Edition is a solid pirate simulator let down by shoddy controls that mar the gameplay and true incompetence in porting from consoles. On many occasions during my playthrough I almost didn't bother continuing, so take that as a warning.

This will be at least my second time writing a review for this game as I believe the last one must have gotten deleted by Ubisoft?

Anywho, as usual, you have to use the godawful Ubisoft launcher which, as usual, signs me out every single time I exit out of the game so I have re-sign in every time. So that's annoying.

However my biggest gripe, and why I have it a dislike, is that it has no cloud saves. I didn't realize this, and even though I do have almost 18 hrs on record, that was on a previous laptop which I don't have anymore. So all of that progress is lost. From what I understand, this is an easy thing to enable with Steam which Ubisoft just chooses not to do for some reason. Plus, even if they do want do to that, why not have a cloud save system in their own crappy launcher to remedy it?

Anyway, the game is fun, but I can't give it a Like if I can't even finish the game as I don't want to put 18 hours into it AGAIN, plus the time it would take to finish it.

I wasn't sure if I wanted to post a review because I love AC4, to me it's the last good AC game. The reason for me not recommending the game itself is because of Ubisoft. I saw another review on here where a player's save data was lost and people were bashing them for a negative review. Same thing happened to me and it's Ubisoft's fault, but I decided I got a clean slate to play it through again. Except that now I can't play the game. Shortly into the game there's a required mission to access your fleet which requires connection to Uplay, unfortunately the game doesn't connect and you cannot progress past that mission. This has been a problem since at least September and all of the official replies in the forums have been "we're currently looking into it". 

Again I love the game, but it's too broken and Ubisoft doesn't seem to care to actually fix it. And if someone bashes saying that if I love the game I should recommend it, I'm not going to recommend a game that you can't get your money's worth because it's broken.

TL:DR Great game, but cannot progress storyline do to Ubisoft not fixing the game

AC4 pioneered naval combat in the franchise after the baby steps taken in AC3. The game's biggest strong suits are naval combat and the sense of wonder at exploring the open world. It is a mediocre AC game in terms of story (particularly the modern day portions) BUT it is simply the BEST pirate game ever made and expectations should be based upon this premise. If you want to do cool pirate stuff, no game has ever been better, if you want to deep dive into AC lore... not so much.

An important note: despite the Adewale dlc Freedom Cry being included with purchase and showed as "owned" in the library it is broken, and doesn't appear in game so it can not be launched. Ubisoft support has been no help with this issue.

TL;DR 
Pirate's Creed = refreshing and fun 
Assassin’s Creed = stagnant and boring 

By the third Ezio game I was suffering AssCreed fatigue and I quickly gave up on it. I’d played the two previous games in fairly quick succession but the similarities in Revelations were glaringly obvious by that point and I just couldn’t bring myself to continue. Even the lure of the wonderful architecture and the likeable protagonist couldn’t draw me back to yet another game with repetitive side missions, numerous pointless collectables and stylish but shallow combat. 

Also, tailing missions. Fuck tailing missions.

AssCreed III never really appealed to me because of the historical setting and I only played a little of it. That game had a dull protagonist and a dull setting; with the architecture of 18th century America not matching up to what Europe had to offer at the time. This diluted the parkour, the one gameplay mechanic that might have kept me playing for longer.

This is all a big preamble to me saying that Assassin’s Creed IV bought some of the fun back to the franchise for me, by making pirate ships a new core mechanic. The sailing and naval combat are a big part of the game and it’s good, arcadey fun. It also helps that the protagonist is fairly likeable, in a roguish kind of way (ala Ezio). 

Anything outside of the ‘being a pirate’ stuff is the same old Ass Creed (worse in some cases) and it gets boring quickly, but the piracy setting and gameplay additions are enough for a recommendation.

On a final note, fuck U Uplay.

Assassin's Creed combined with PIrates of the Caribbean: that's the best way to describe this absolute banger. Having loved the naval battles in AC3, I enjoyed the way this new system was explored. I was curious to know about the connection between Haytham and his father, Edward, the main character of this game, but unfortunately I had to wait until the very end so I could find some easter-egg-esque mention of the two of them together. Hopefully, future games expand on this. As the first main-series game after the "Desmond Trilogy", one can see that the direction Ubisoft is taking with future games seems to be a good one, and this game reflects the vision that Ubisoft wishes to work towards of trying to incorporate a higher degree of multiplayer-esque gameplay, with UPlay, based gameplay features. 

The visuals, characters, and world-building were spectacular, as were the set pieces throughout the story. The story felt a bit rushed at the end but it also did a very good job of providing some much-needed exposition into the modern-day conflict between the Assassins and Templars, albeit in a very armchair-viewer sort of way. However, the introduction of new variables from the First Civilisation into the mix seems to spice up the possibilities future games could explore. The music was top notch as usual, perfectly reflecting the vibe of the pirate's life, and the sea shanties are the best part about this all that I absolutely adore. I could sail for miles with the rush of the sea and the sound of sea shanties in my ears.

While I'm not sure about the value of its replayability, aside from post-game cruising over the waves, this is a game that I will definitely recommend for those that have been introduced to the "new" AC games and wishing to play the precursors, or "The Ones That Came Before". Heh.

Easy review, if you like Assassin's creed games, and have played at least one of the previous installations (1, 2, Brotherhood, Revelations, 3), then it's a no-brainer. The same if you like pirates A LOT; then you most likely will enjoy this game, since it's pretty much 50% pirate shenanigans, 30% assassin/stealth stuff, and 20% weird sci-fi stuff. Yeah, it's a pretty weird combo, but that's part of its charm. 

The only negative thing I could say is that it does feel a bit more buggy than any of the previous Assassin's Creed games, but still quite easy playable, with only a minor nuisance here and there. Oh, and you HAVE to install Uplay, so that is most definitely another con, though not the actual game's fault.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

I have always been a big fan of pirate themed games. I started with Sid Meier's Pirates! ages ago, played it a ton, after that I played many others, like Cutthroats, Seadogs, PoTC etc. Oh boy is sailing and taking down ships fun in this game! The attention to detail, how your first mate watches the sails, the singing of the crew, the motion of the ocean. It's not Sailing simulator 2000, but it's great fun. 
This was my first Assassin's Creed game, so I was unfamiliar with the mechanics and the backstory. The assassin's mechanics, well, they are not for me. I somewhat got the hang of it, but it did lead to many frustrating moments. When I wanted to do something and my pirate decided to do something else.
This happened a lot, perhaps I'm just bad. That's fine.

So, the sailing is great fun, ship battles are as well, boarding, shooting and manoeuvring, well done really. The rest of the game though. It's basically collecting a lot of things, chests, collectibles you can put on display in your hideout and upgrading. The upgrades you do need. As far as the rest goes, it depends on  how much you enjoy doing that kind of thing. For me the novelty quickly wore off. Once you get the mission table unlocked you can send ships to do missions that give you way better cash than any chest will give.

The main story is very straightforward, cliche and Hollywood inspired. The main protagonist doesn't have a lot of backstory and I never really cared much for him. I guess this is not a story driven game, that's fine. Just don't expect too much of the story.
If you love sailing and plundering, this game is definately worth a try. Other than that it's mostly collecting stuff. There are other side activities but they don't feel very rewarding or interesting. They mostly revolve around killing certain targets for rewards. There is no added value beyond that. 

I had a great time, mostly because of my love for the pirate theme, other than that, don't expect too much. I'd say a 7 out of 10.

Black Flag was one of those games I skipped because believe it or not I didn't like the idea of an Open World Assassin's Creed game and prefer the sandbox Assassin's Creed games (My how the tables have turned lol). So after purchasing the game on sale I must say: Whether it be full price or not. This game is worth it!

The story, the characters, the places and ship to ship battles are all sooo good! With that said, it's batshit bonkers that Skull & Bones can't simply follow this formula! Instead of following this formula, Ubisoft in their wisdom decided to do a Sea of Thieves clone but waayyyy more boring. But that's not what I'm here to discuss. 

The only two things I can say negatively about the game is the "Modern Setting" it's just sooo boring and nothing really exciting happens. In addition there is a lot of technical issues at the tail end of the game that I encountered so be aware at all times.

Other than that - the gameplay is the same as was seen in the first AC game, the Ezio trilogy, AC III, etc. As a reminder this is not the fluid traversing assassin's creed games we see today it's all set on where to climb, how to kill, etc. There's no real freedom in movement or combat; so it's stiff and boy it shows if you play Valhalla, Origins, Odyssey, Unity, Syndicate and then go back and play the older titles the two sets are night and day. 

If you can bare with the older gameplay mechanics, the story is worth it and definitely a great AC game in that generation of AC games.

In 2022 AC: Black Flag seems somewhat dated compared to the new AC games. Especially the boating sections /battles. AC: Odyssey does the boat battles and travel almost perfectly. AC: Black Flag is still a fun AC game and it's all about pirates, sailing and exploring.. but all the newer AC games in my opinion are better. This is your classic AC formula, fighting, stealth missions, and upgrades that honestly don't even matter. You can use a level 1 weapon and complete the game. Stealth requires you to watch the repeated enemy movement patterns and plan your mission into the bushes. The story line is your typical AC game story, pirates and the secrets of the assassin. Lots of fun but not AS fun as newer AC games.
