To be honest, it contains less bugs than other games produced by the Ubisoft. But it's a game published in 2013, and there's no sign that these bugs can ever be fixed. Plus, it's annoying that I have to input password to Ubi connect EVERY TIME when I play the game. What is the problem with Ubi engineers?

I wish there were a more neutral option for rating because while the naval gameplay and the Edward Kenway narrative is delightful, the mission structure and control scheme is frustrating, to say the least. I actually only recently finished this after a many year hiatus due to these problems. I also just lost interest in AC. Later iterations have revealed how limited Black Flag's parkour and stealth systems are, and Edward Kenway feels sluggish to control. Ezio and Arnault feel more nimble by comparison and unity introducing a dedicated crouch mechanic makes stealth much more fluid and dynamic feeling.

The game is at its best when upgrading the ship and presenting you with the freedom to roam the high seas, upgrade your Jackdaw and explore the islands. Its stealth is subpar for the series; I find AC2, Brotherhood, Revelations and Unity have more fluid movement that doesn't feel as cumbersome to wield. Unity made the right call with having free run up and down options rather than bound to a single button, as I am constantly finding in Black Flag trying to hop down a short jump somewhat awkward as you make a totally unnecessary leap off a 2 foot tall box. 

This game has a monstrous amount of tailing missions and it gets repetitive, especially when it's not always clear what the prescribed pathway should be and some missions I had to resolve through trial and error. It's not difficult, per se, but having to reload and learn from your mistakes like that in a game that is narrative focused kind of kills the momentum; I ended up rage quitting for quite some time because I hate redoing things. The AC series in general suffers from a paradox between the freedom an option world purportedly presents, while the missions are jarringly linear in the sense that the game doesn't really want you to experiment in many instances. The later games resolve this, but aren't without their flaws either.

I do prefer the newer hitbox combat from Origins onward, because the older games tend to feel like glorified quicktime events. I've never really cared about feeling overpowered or underpowered. Ubisoft games predicate themselves as power fantasies anyways. As long as it feels fun, its fine. The berserk darts are so overpowered but it's kind of hilarious. Same with the smoke bombs which let you chain a million kills together.

I'm not enamored by Black Flag like so many else. It lives and breathes by its naval gameplay. You know a system is good when you can lose almost a whole night of sleep just derping around with the system, similar to the parkour of Unity or Dying Light 2, where the joy of movement and traversal is enough to keep you playing. The naval combat is challenging but fun. Your ship turns slowly especially depending on the winds, and there are some fortresses you assault while trying to battle rogue waves as well; it's not too overdone and having the option to upgrade your boat gives the system some flexibility. I didn't find the naval stuff unfair except maybe one instance where there were 4 twisters that somehow magically magnetized themselves to my ship while I was attacking a fortress.

Remove the naval gameplay and the AC portion of the game is rather underwhelming. Someone did a reddit post tallying up which games had the most tailing missions and Black Flag was near the top of the pack.

This version of Black Flag is bound to 60 fps as well. Ironically, Unity gets better performance than this and the tendency for visual assets to just pop in break the immersion a bit.

The FOV is way too close to Edward. I feel like Ezio's was zoomed out a bit more so visibility can be an issue. Another camera problem is the way it resets whenever you disable an alarm bell or pick up a body; it's jarring to have the camera suddenly reset for these scripted animations. These things do not break the game or make it difficult per se, but they make it less fun to play.
good character

If you've waited this long to try it out on PC - you are a bit late...

No doubt, Black Flag has a lot to offer new and old audiences, but I do feel that its age is finally catching up to it. And by that, I mean Ubisoft would rather kill off older games than maintain people's ability to play them.

https://www.ubisoft.com/en-gb/help/gameplay/article/decommissioning-of-online-services-for-older-ubisoft-games-october-2022-update/000102396

While not on the list *yet*, it would appear this will be a recurring procedure that will eventually take down gamers' ability to use many features. Features like link cross-accounts/platforms and online play will no longer be possible, nor will players be able to access *ANY* DLC for the game - regardless if you've already paid for it or not.

Eventually, this game will crumble on PC until Ubisoft decides to HD remaster it and will again milk all those wanting to play it again.

Outside of this, the game has still aged to a point where it's lost its shine. My primary complaint is that having jumped into it so late, much of what made this game special has already been employed in so many other games. The pirating ship portions are still pretty unique, but they already felt shallow and too on the rails. The campaign and missions play just like any of the previous AC games and fail to offer anything new outside of pirating - which is a fun, but limited experience only truly enjoyed outside of the restrictions of the campaign.

What it does offer is a fun backdrop and setting in which you can play an Assassin's Creed game in. Not being a huge fan of the Assassin's Creed series, this is the most fun I've had in one. That all said, what does it really matter if the publisher/developer is trashing the game anyway?

Have fun while you can!

What a beautiful game that still holds up years later. For completionists, this game can be an absolute SLOG with long sails between tons of "animus fragments," message-in-a-bottle collectibles, buried treasures, templar keys, and Mayan Stele, the primary story is solid, fun, and intriguing.  I wish there were a little LESS wide open space some times, but I understand the need to always go bigger with each iteration of the game. Once you get all the "fast travel" and sync points done, it does become a lot easier. The Fleet minigames are kind of lame -- I wish there was a quicker way to do the battles / send your ships, but it is what it is. It's certainly better than Revelations tower defense minigame.

The game has a lot of side activities that keeps a player indulged.

This is a great game. I think it is one of the best assassin' creed.
Story is very good. Edward is one of my favourite main. This game focus on pirates. Assassin is not primary.  The missions are almost non-repetitive and less boring. Even side quests. In Unity there are countless repetitive, boring and unnecessary tasks. 

In game system:
- Edward is not wanted, only Jackdaw is. 
- The naval battle is very interesting, especially the legendary ship. 
-  Very powerful gun and one shot any enemy (except 1 boss need to shoot 3 times but i can use 4 shots per reload xD). 
- Whale hunting and treasure maps are fun.

Limit:
- Many missions still make it difficult for players and often error like sequence 10 memory 1. I only got 99% sync because of it -_-.
- Edward sword dance is very beautiful but dame is very small and takes a lot of time to kill the enemy.
- Kenney fleet is poor and very slow. I think it is necessary to reduce the time of missions by 1/2 or 1/3.
- The villain is very weak and has been caught by edward many times. The last mission is very easy, the boss is almost waiting for you to kill.
- If you don't listen to English well, many missions you don't have time to read sub because you have to move to eavesdrop in a very narrow circle and many guards. I missed some interesting conversation.

I will update review for DLC after.

I've been a fan of the series since the beginning.
The original was alright (for it's time) and AC2 and Brotherhood were great improvements on the formula by correcting mistakes and expanding the gameplay. AC3 was confusing and boring for the most part so getting Black Flag seemed like a gamble at first.

Fortunately Black Flag is fantastic!
A pirate adventure that surprisingly doesn't portray everything on cliches with an almost ground to earth setting and inhabitants. You explore a miniaturized version of the Carribean that looks and plays great. The sword fighting is loose but servicable and the Naval Battles are challenging and exciting. It's the best AC game in my opinion.

Best Assassin's Creed game from my knowledge, I've played through AC Unity, Odyssey, Origins and I've already 100% completed this game on PS4. And even though I've already 100% completed this game 5 years ago, I'm psyched to do it again. Overall this game has the best parkour and free-running (compared to Unity because Odyssey and Origins got rid of one of the main components of AC) and the best flashiness with insta-kill after parrying which makes you feel bad ass. The story is enjoyable and sailing pirate ships while singing along to sea shanties is one of the best game experiences I've ever been apart of. I would also recommend this game over Unity due to Unity removing key features like whistling and grabbing enemies as human shields. To conclude my rant, I have 200-ish games on my steam account and I've played many games on XBOX 360 and PS4 and this is in my top 3 games of all time.

Black Flag has beautiful graphics, especially for the sea and the story so far has been very entertaining. I love the sea shanties and everything else about the game. The performance of the game is a different matter altogether. 

I cannot recommend this game on PC purely because of random FPS drops and freezing issues. It took me 4 hours (yes my game time), to find a setting that wasn't causing the picture to freeze for 30 seconds every 5 minutes or so, no matter what graphics settings I chose in game, the frames also drop from 60 to anywhere down to 29 for no apparent reason. Seriously no reason, if I cap the FPS to 30 however I STILL experience an annoying fps drops (anywhere from 11-30 fps). It makes no sense. 

I should be able to run the game on max settings. Tinkering with the nvidia control panel settings helped stop the random freezes and made the frame rate a little bit more stable and smoother, giving me 40+ to 60 FPS, now I just have to put up with a little screen tearing, which isn't actually that bad or frequent. 

I would not recommend playing this or any other Assassin's Creed on PC. If you want to play any Assassin's Creed I would recommend investing in a current gen console. 

Syndicate also had an abominable FPS drop of sometimes 40+ frames on any settings, even if I force the FPS to stay at 30 or 60, again I get consistent drops, the only upside of that game was that it didn't freeze up for 30 seconds every few minutes.

Edited because of developer response: You really think I tried none of those in the four hours of trying to get it to be playable? I tried everything. There was nothing running in the background (since I don't leave any running while gaming) and I tried every compatibility mode available to me.

[b]PROS:[/b]
+ fantastic pirate story
+ naval exploration & combat
+ Man O' War & Legendary ship battles
+ present day story & additonal lore
+ beautiful visuals and environment
+ really cool soundtrack (+ sea shanties!)
+ great UI
+ Wolfpack multiplayer mode

[b]CONS:[/b]
- uPlay
- confusing editions and DLC management
- couple of ship/NPC spawn glitches
- many unskippable cutscenes
- computer hacking mini-games & board games
- all other multiplayer modes

[b]Special review section for Ubisoft games:[/b]
[u]Should you play?[/u] DEFINITELY
[u]Should you BUY???[/u] YES, BUT ON A SALE

[b]Comment:[/b]
Far less of an assassin game, more of a pirate game. Stealth is needed much much less here, except for some mission contraints. That is good for people who wanted more of an action game. Inspiration comes from the naval missions in AC3 and this is basically the core gameplay element for AC4. However, unlike AC3, this game is a sunny with a vast world to explore. You have a hideout too but I barely ever went there, your ship is your real home. Right from the start you can pickup collectibles, loot chests and do side missions. Each of these tasks is neatly accounted for in the stats and visible for each area. This makes picking up all the stuff really seemless and that is a big plus. Checklists are still present but under a really neat UI. They are also varied enough to not feel repetitive. That is except for boarding ships due to the unskippable cutscenes. You can fast travel in both the world map and the town/island map (viewpoints are used here). However, ship travel is just so much fun I rarely ever used the world map to fast travel. This time around you are not a good guy, not really, you are an opportunistic pirate that murders all the time. And it works, there is no need to save lives and Edward Kenway is still likeable in his own way. The story is great and I got plunged into the world easily and for a long time. It is a shame that a lot of the "current world" story is hidden behind bad hacking mini-games. They are not hard, just annoying and they waste time. These could easily just have been skipped and the lore given to the player right away. And not only that, after finishing the game I was left with a 32/33 counter (got all the files though). Turns out it can bug out if you do these during the sequences, so just do them all AFTER you finish the campaign. For multiplayer I can say it stays the same as in AC3 - it's mostly not good. Wolfpack is somewhat fun, and they also added Infection and Chest defense into it, but while the former is okay the latter is terrible. General multiplayer is just waiting in queues and overall not much fun anyway. Ubisoft was dishing out various editions and DLC ever since they made uPlay but this time around you need a chart to know what you have and want. You see some nitpicking but that is because the game is fantastic so it is easier to find the little things that could be better. So don't get discouraged by the flaws, they are minor and I really had a blast playing this game while time just flew by. The epic feeling of hard naval battles is something I have not experienced in any other game yet. Definitely recommended!

[b]P.S.:[/b] To activate the Deluxe Edition and Season Pass content, take each of the CD-keys Steam shows you, go to uPlay and then to Activate a key, restart the game and you should see DLC info pop up. [u]Deluxe Edition DLCs:[/u] Aveline (new character missions), Illustrious Pirates Pack (missions + items). [u]Season Pass DLCs:[/u] Kraken Ship Pack (ship items), Freedom Cry (new campaign), Illustrious Pirates Pack (missions + items), Crusader & Florentine Pack (weapons + items), Death Vessel Pack (ship items), Guild of Rogues (multiplayer characters). [b]If you are in the US there is a Gold Edition that has both Deluxe and Season Pass DLCs.[/b] [u]uPlay unlockable DLCs:[/u] Edward The Legend Outfit (skin), The Blades of Toledo Pack (weapons), The Vengeful Daughter Pack (multiplayer outfit + ship items). [u]Not obtainable community challenge items:[/u] Explorer outfit, Captain's wheellock pistols, Persian scimitars, Black and Red sails, El Impoluto's figurehead, El Impoluto's wheel. [u]Not purchasable:[/u] Edward Kenway: The Assassin Pirate figurine (Haytham Kenway's overcoat, Edward Kenway's Unique Swords, Aquila sails), Blackbeard: The Legendary Pirate figurine (Royal Fortune sails, Queen Anne sails, The Benjamin sails). For the complete list of content for this game go [url=http://assassinscreed.wikia.com/wiki/Assassin's_Creed_IV:_Black_Flag_downloadable_content]HERE[/url]

[b]*Note:[/b] If you buy the Season Pass the DLCs that you can install but the store page will not show as owned are - Freedom Cry, Illustrious Pirates Pack and Guild of Rogues.

This is a prime example of the sort of masterpieces Ubisoft was capable of making before the past couple years. This is easily one of the best Assassin's Creed games and possibly one of my favorite games of all time. Everything about it is good, the graphics, the animations, the story, the combat, the ship battles, and the side activities all have their own things that make it enjoyable, even the sailing is fun because of the wind, storms, and sea shanties. Edward is also my favorite assassin, his character arc is unmatched and despite the game being mainly about pirates he still makes it feel like Assassin's Creed at its core. I'd highly recommend this to anybody who enjoys the older games in the series.

[h1]THERE ARE LIKE 40 OF THESE GAMES[/h1]

When it comes to Assassin's Creed, so far I’ve really only played through the first game in the series way back in 2008 on the PS Triple. The gameplay was pretty average, a lot of runny, jumpy, stabby actions. I remember hating that storywise everything ended up just being inside some sort of simulation, instead of you actually being in whatever world your adventure takes place in. I was also disappointed that Assassin's Creed Man looked so cool in his assassin gear, but when you returned to the real world you just looked like Adam Sandler in a hoodie. 

XBOX Live Games With Gold has thrown several more Assassin’s Creed games my way over the years, but I could only ever bring myself to play any of them for 20 minutes before flaking out. The gameplay appeared to be the exact same in every game, however the 2D Assassin’s Creed games played differently and those games were pretty decent.

I honestly am not sure who is buying these yearly Assassin’s Creed releases. I imagine they are the type of people who’s idea of a good time is watching Late Night with Seth Meyers with a large glass of lukewarm fluoride filled tap water, and laughing at every single punchline. In fact, if you are a woman visiting your date’s house for the first time, and they have a bookshelf with every single Assassin’s Creed game on it, RUN……run for your life, your odds of being turned into a skin suit are great.

[h1]I JUST WANT TO BE A PIRATE[/h1]

The reason I got this game wasn’t for the standard Assassin’s Creed runny, jumpy, stabby gameplay, but it was to get lost inside of a world where I get to be a pirate, and it does a pretty good job of that. Graphically the game looks great, the world is very beautiful to look at as you sail your ship through the crystal blue seas from island to island. It sounds great too, your crew will play instruments and sing sea shanties which help even more to make it feel like you’re a real pirate. I also had a blast (pun intended) exchanging cannon fire with enemy ships, and then when the time was right, boarding and taking it over.

[h1]PROS[/h1]

-Atmosphere.
-Graphics.
-Sound.
-Sea battles.

[h1]CONS[/h1]

-Have to log into a Ubisoft account every time you start up the game.
-The Assassin’s Creedness of it all can be tiresome at times. 

[h1]OVERALL THOUGHTS[/h1]

This game would be great if it weren't an Assassin's Creed Game. The controls are frustrating trash 100% of the time. I'm constantly annoyed just doing the most basic movement. Assassin's Creed feels a constant need to control your options, you decisions, and you movement possibilities. It feels like moving through rotten sludge. Want to climb a mast? Good luck, unless you're perfectly positioned. Otherwise, you're dead. Trying to move forward over a slight rise in the terrain? Nope. Edward will struggle endlessly unless you stop, change direction, and then start moving again. This should not feel like controlling an old school Resident Evil game, but that's what it's like. This game is terribly designed, Assassin's Creed sucks, and you're wrong for liking them.

Best AC around!

Black Flag is the Best AC game ever! The way naval battles and sea exploration is integrated into the regular gameplay mechanics with seamless transitions is the best feature is this package.

The golden age of piracy is an interesting period of time to visit and interact with the likes of famous characters of the time like Ben Hornigold, Woods Rogers, Charles Vane, Black beard, and all the historical figures. If we are to rate the AC games based on the historic period, black flag is the least interesting of them all, the 3rd crusade and the American Revolutionary War are way richer and more exciting to explore.

What makes AC4 the best AC game is fun, is the most fun game in the franchise ever. You get to do tons of stuff in this open world and there is polish and details everywhere. Some reviews stated that they didn't like the main missions or the main story but for me, it was exciting: Dropping in the middle of the Templar plot and sabotaging their plans, and finding out about the assassins and the secrets that the Caribbean islands hold was a nice trip.

I always recommend playing older AC games on PC as the console counterparts are way inferior in graphics and performance. This was solved since Valhalla, and I'm pretty sure future AC games like mirage will solid perform on consoles, but older AC games have a brutal difference between PC and consoles

I'm not sure what to say, this review is a love letter, to Assassin's Creed 4, Black Flag.

This game, is the best in the franchise. It's also, one of the best game's I have ever played, it has intense combat that requires cunning and quick reactions, a small selection of swords that feel good for 3 different kinds of play. The mashing of Attack and Parry is one of the best mechanics this game has to offer. The gun play is beautiful, and the stealth is masterfully done. The parkour is quick, functional and very cinematic. The exploration of different areas and finding the Mayan Stelaes and treasure is a grand treat that we have gotten to enjoy. 

I have played this game to 100%, and I say it was well worth the 66 hours I've played. You can bet that I will end up playing it again too, just like how I have when I was a kid on Xbox.

This game features the best character development and story out of any other Assassin's Creed game, Edward Kenway starts out as a greedy pirate, having wants of a better life for him and his wife Caroline. So he joins a Privateer gig, and eventually becomes a pirate.

The selling point of this game for me is Edward Kenway's Evolution from Selfish, Egotistical and Cold heartedness, all the way to Empathic, Understanding of the damage he has done, Caring and even a Father. 
This game is truly a masterpiece, the influence the Assassin's and Mary have on Edward's development, watching the death of Blackbeard, and even being forced to kill off one of his own friends, Rackham tore down the hard man we once knew, and began the reconstruction of a man that is more emotionally vulnerable and aware.

The character interactions are beautiful to watch, and the ending scene was the single, most beautiful scene in video game history, the single most perfect Epilogue that helps Edward and Us, Reminisce and understand the moral and theme of the story, which was love and freedom.

[h1] Great Pirate game, Average Assassin's Creed Game [/h1]

There is no doubt this is one of the most memorable and beloved entries into the series. It is by no accident, Ship to ship combat on the open seas, looting and plundering, sea shanties, it succeeds in being a great pirate game.
However upon a recent replay I've realized that it is lacking in being an Assassin's Creed Game. The story is average compared to other entries. Not that all entries had the best narratives, but this entry doesn't really explore deep themes and concepts that the series has been known to have. The story is about a man who learns to fight for something bigger than himself. It's a real shame because there are interesting ideas and strong subjects in the game, but the game doesn't go beyond these things being just setting/background/etc.

That being said, it's still a fun game worth playing, but it is important to understand that it's a pirate game before it's an Assassin's Creed Game.

Wondering if this game is still worth $40, nine years later? Well other than...

- Parkouring, Freerunning, and Climbing Systems
- Swashbuckling Ship Battle Combat
- Sword Fighting
- Shooting
- Finding Treasure with Treasure Maps
- Upgrading Your Very Own Pirate Ship
- Building Your Own Pirate Crew
- Build Your Own Fleet of Ships
- Open World Exploring the High Seas
- Wanted Level and Bounty System While Sailing
- Becoming Friends with Black Beard
- Taking Over Forts
- Hunting Land Animals to Upgrade Equipment and Armour 
- Harpooning Whales and Sharks to get the best Upgrades 
- Exploring Underwater Shipwrecks for Fortune
- Stealth Mechanics
- Assassination Contracts
- Decently Meaningful and Fun Side Collectables 
- Light Puzzle Solving Side Activities
- Brilliant Thematic Musical Score
- Engaging Story About Humility and Greed
- And is Still Arguably the Best Assassin's Creed to Date

...nah, it's not worth $40 at all. In fact it's still worth $60.

[i]Leave her, Johnny, leave her
Tomorrow ye will get your pay
And it's time for us to leave her[/i]

For those of you who don't know, the "Her" being left is not a woman, but the ship. This shanty was traditionally sung when the ship was at port after it had docked in the final spell at the pumps.

It's a very refreshing game, if you play or have played the previous AC, which is a good thing. Even, if the game itself has mostly drifted away from the theme of resolving the entire game plot with your hidden blade.

The exploration genuinly feels like a open world. The navy combat is pretty good, the RPG is different compared to older titles. The story is meh and just there to move confusing plots forward. I'd say that if some people like the theme of a sort of secret assasin with a nagging to blow stuff up mixed in the bag, then it's worth it.

9/10 amazing game
This is my favorite game in the series.I heard that the reviews about the game were bad,so I entered the game with low expectations,but I liked this game.

There's something about the sea in fiction that that has a hold on me. There's the exploration, obviously, discovering new lands and giving smallpox to the natives, but more than that, I think it's that it welcomes loneliness. You're away from the pressures of society and the potential benefits of community, but it's okay because there's meaning in it. Travelling, exploring, murdering, pillaging or kidnapping, it's okay to relax, enjoy it and watch the hours glide by because you're doing it for a reason. And because you're sharing in the feeling with your crew. Even celebrating it.

This is what I love the most about Black Flag. Everything about the sailing is perfectly designed to revel in these qualities. 

Firstly, you're in the Caribbean, which is beautifully rendered with vegetation and castles and strongholds of the time - very pretty to look at. Secondly, there's no soundtrack while you're out of combat, only sea shanties sung by your crew (which, of course, slap). The creak and list of the ship, the lapping waves, the sails rippling in the wind, it's an almost sensory experience. 

And of course, being a pirate, spotting juicy merchant or British navy ships ripe for the pillaging injects a steady stream of action between the objectives of travelling across the Caribbean. Without cutscenes, pursuits transition naturally from spotting to pursuing to attacking to boarding to Batman-Arkham-stabbing and counter-stabbing your way through the crew. The ship-to-ship combat is really satisfying. Seeing the trajectory of the cannons before you shoot, then every damn cannonball hit home, the giant chunks torn out of the healthbar - the contrast between that and maneuvering to protect yourself in more intense combat makes your focus swing back and forth in a very holistic way. As for boarding, the game provides a lot of variety to make yourself feel cool when you do it. Maybe you can run across a fallen mast, maybe you can swing across on a loose rope, jump from one railing to another, OR climb all the way up the rigging, jump across to the top of the other ship's sail, kill the chap in the crow's nest and then jump-stab the captain from 10 metres up. In some missions, this also translates to stealth for even more variety. 

And you want to take all these missions, too, side-quests and all. Upgrades for the Jackdaw, your ship, are both expensive and useful. The different resources needed - money, leather, sugar, crew, etc. - also mean you have to pick your targets a bit more carefully. An extra bit of thought makes it much more engaging. One little thing I appreciate about this is that there's a hard cap on the amount of resources you can have at one time, which ensures that there's a nice flow of pillaging and returning to port for upgrades. Essentially you can't mindlessly grind until combat loses its lustre. 

So all of this is enough to make the game worth getting, but I must talk about the bad stuff. Firstly, the game does that narrative in the present day-thing that gleefully wastes your time before you can get to the sailing. It's mostly out of obligation, though, the Assassin/Templar thing is mostly ignored so that you can interact with historical figures like Blackbeard and Bart Roberts in a historical sight-seeing tour. It's a bit trite, but it's fun for what it is. 

Also, tailing missions. Fuck tailing missions, man, all my homies hate tailing missions. Let's grind our freeform pirate adventure all about disobeying the rules to a halt and have the player meekly follow instructions that don't incooperate the open world at all. Pretty as the settlements are, the quests there aren't particularly great. But you have to stop to get new shanties.

None of this is a dealbreaker, though, especially if you don't frequent Assassin's creed games. I certainly don't. Buy it. Play it. Have fun.

Might as well be called pirate simulator, plunder your way through an extensive map with your upgradeable and trusty ship; plenty of islands to explore, plenty of ships and galleons and the likes to plunder and destroy or send to your fleet to bring you riches from the world over. 

At it's core it's still an AC game with all the templars and assassins and all that boring stuff,but it is the best one imo. 

Gameplay is solid,you will still jump to or from places that you don't want to and the combat is really easy,when underwater,the sharks are really annoying, but you will fight and jump and climb your way through the world with relative ease.

I really loved the protagonist, voiced and mocapped by Matt Ryan aka John Constantine, great performance. 

The graphics are really good, the game is very pretty, has amazing sunsets and the underwater parts are gorgeous. A good looking game all around. 

The music is stellar, from the sea shanties singed by your crew to the amazing ost composed by Brian Tyler, I listen to it all the time.

~SPOILER FREE REVIEW~

The best pirate game I have ever played.. Not an Exaggeration.. EVER PLAYED.

Here is my unbiased review:

Story - I loved the story of how Edward Kenway (the main protagonist), was a privateer first, then he turns into a pirate and then he becomes one with the brotherhood of Assassin's.  NOTHING ELSE IS WORTH SAYING BECAUSE I DON'T WANNA SPOIL IT.  The story is really well paced, some pretty sick moments got me like OHHHHHHHHHHHH YEA and if any story pulls those moments out well, then yes yes yes I recommend playing it.

Gameplay - Assassin's Creed Shenanigans.. Hide in a bush kill some dude tail a dude blah blah blah you know the drill. What's interesting is that the mechanics have kinda changed coz in the previous games you couldn't crouch. In this game, they made it so u can crouch.......only in waist high bushes or grasses. Yea that's fun right? XD BUT WAIT! NAVAL F&KING COMBAT!!! YES PLEASE! IT WAS SO DAMN GOOD I LOVED EVERY BIT OF IT. 

AI - This game has some really really blind AI.. I can kill a guard like less than 5 ft away from their very eyes and they don't notice. Like DUDE! SERIOUSLY? I JUST KILLED UR FRIEND IN FRONT OF YOU XD. Anyways, coming to the detection ranges, the snipers have the most (duh) but they are so damn annoying coz 90% of the time, you just will be running on trees or rooftops coz that's easier. Stealth is pretty fun too, although the brutes or fat guards are just annoying.. Pro strat, save up, get the best pistols in the game and when you fight a brute, just shoot him once, he drops, and you stab him with the hidden blade. eZ kill.

Bugs - A few bugs which I can say existed. The first being, when boarding a ship, Edward would Glitch out and he would get stuck in an awkward position while holding the wheel. No button prompts can help. Just replay the last checkpoint. Edward constantly just not jumping for the tree branch which should be grab-able but he chooses to just not jump there no matter the controls. I have tested this out and he would grab it atleast 6/10 times. He would just get stuck on random objects but this was very rare.

Music - SEA SHANTIES? HELL YEA

Characters - Really really good and well made

Combat - Simple, Counter and kill (Hidden Blades OP) and if you have the type of ppl who block every attack, break defense and kill rinse and repeat. 

Final Verdict - 9/10 - AMAZING 

PLAY THIS GAME. YOU WON'T BE DISAPPOINTED 

THANKS FOR READING MY REVIEW :)

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

best ac game since the original trilogy, as per usual everything out of the animus is lame, but the real game is a great pirate adventure game. Good, but not great story, and pretty by the books combat, but the game really shines in its ship warfare, upgrades and side activities(mostly). This is basically a pirate sim but you have assassin blades so your a pirate assassin kinda. Theres a lot of piratey stuff to do in the world to keep you busy like hunting on land/sea, diving for treasure/ship upgrades, getting into bar fights, playing dice, looting hideouts. collecting sheet music for your crew to sing, upgrading your weapons, changing your ship and outfit decor etc. The negatives would be that its feels like a copy paste of 3's combat, and very little variety in combat tools. A few of the side activities, and almost all side quests feel like busy work, and most of the time you just dont care. Like i said though the main plot can hold you over and there are some touching scenes, well voice acted too. The main draw is really the seamless ship to ship, and boarding combat, taking down big ships and boarding them never gets old(until 50 or so hours in lol), and the dynamic weather can make ship battles even more intense, as you battle the seas and your foes. This is easily a masterpiece for its time(2013) and by far my favorite ubisoft game, of which i like very few lmao. 8/10 (Great game)

I bought this on Ubisofts launcher, it redirects me to install it on steam, then when installed and I press play it opens Ubisofts launcher and runs it from there and I have to enter my ubisoft password everytime. What the heck? Ok whatever the game is super high rated should be good eh? No. Two Words: Unskippable Cutscenes. My god, I just want to play the game as a pirate not take a 20 minute tour of Abstergo as a faceless animus operator. Fine, finally get control of the character again to be put in yet another unskippable battle tutorial that ends with 30+ guards chasing after me making me have to use 4 smoke bombs to finally escape (why the heck are they shooting at me over a fist fight?). Decide to do some free roam and check out the assassin contracts, make a good bit of money and buy a sword set for 6500. Realize after my purchase that I had a free set from apparently owning a DLC that was much better, so I restarted the game completely as 6500 seems like a lot to just waste so early and there's NO MANUAL SAVE FEATURE so whatever you do is permenant.  

Try my best to rush past all the starting stuff again and skip doing the contracts to just start the next mission where I have to follow behind two guards without being detected and this is where I quit the game and uninstalled it. I felt like I had zero control over my guy, he would just randomly latch onto walls even though I didn't tell him to, and when the guards started sprinting I hit shift to chase after, rounded a corner straight into a hidden lift and boom my guy goes flying up to the roof, try to get down but he's just so incapable of normal movement I'm stuck latching onto things even if I hit E to drop. Finally drop and he immediately dives into a hay stack even though I didn't tell him to and I fail the mission. I give AC: Odyssey a 10/10 as a brilliant game that I invested 200+ hours in having a blast, so I thought I'd go back and try the earlier games. HUGE mistake on my part this was so unbelievably frustrating for me and so early in the game. I'm learning from my mistake over RDR2 and I'm going give this one a pass.

[h1]Sum-Up[/h1]
[h3]In-depth analysis further down.[/h3]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🟩 [b]Pros[/b][/th]
[th]🟥 [b]Cons[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
- Varied gameplay that doesn’t get stale thanks to a great number of different activities, each with its own pacing and features.

- Well-designed and surprisingly fun sailing / naval combat mechanics, that still manage to impress today.

- Most collectibles and side missions are worth doing: each has a unique final reward for 100% completion.

- Great amounts of interesting lore to discover in the form of messages, files and logs.
[/td]
[td]
- Underwhelming storyline encompassed by (mostly) mediocre characters and a narrative pace that feels rushed on many occasions.

- Flawed, low-challenge ground combat where Edward is always overpowered, and becomes even more so as you progress.

- Low variety of enemy archetypes: you’ll be fighting the same fodder most of the time; even notable targets feel generic, rarely have unique mechanics.

- Picking collectibles at sea is tremendously tedious due to the fact you have to manually stop, disembark, get them and go back on foot every single time.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🟨 [b]Bugs & Issues[/b][/th]
[th]🔧 [b]Specs[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
- May crash on startup. Set ‘Run as Admin’ and WinXP SP3 Compatibility to fix.
- In rare cases, quests may not proceed as intended. Reload checkpoint to fix.
- Random stuttering if PhysX particles are enabled, regardless of hardware. Disable to fix.
[/td]
[td]
- 3900X
- 2080Ti
- 32GB RAM
- SSD
- 1440p
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[td][b]Content & Replay Value:[/b][/td]
[td]It took me 46 hours to complete AC4, taking considerable extra time to complete all locations, side missions and gather most collectibles / upgrades. Given that all content is linear, I see no reason to replay once completed.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][b]Is it worth buying?[/b][/td]
[td]Yes, on sale. The standard price of 40€ is fair, but considering its age and less-than-stellar quality, I advise waiting for a discount.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][h3]Verdict: Decent[/h3]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2548409603]Rating Chart Here[/url][/td]
[td]A decent entry in the AC franchise that has gameplay variety as its main strength, yet doesn’t shine as it could due to an underwhelming story and multiple design blunders.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2856857260

[h1]In-Depth[/h1]
[h3]Premise & Setting[/h3]
Abstergo Industries, one of the world’s leading tech giants, developed a way to extract memories from DNA samples, then render them in a simulation. As their employee, you'll be tasked with peering into the past of Edward Kenway, and collecting as much material as possible to produce a new ‘interactive experience’...at least that’s the official version.

The vast majority of the action takes place in the 1700s Caribbean. After a ruinous shipwreck, Kenway encounters a mysterious man carrying a message with the promise of a grand reward from a local governor. Posing as the courier, Edward soon gets entangled in the millennia-long feud between Templars and Assassins, the former looking for a powerful device known as ‘The Observatory’.

Despite such an intriguing premise, the story of AC4 is rarely exciting. Most of the side characters around Edward, not to mention the man himself, simply prove bland most of the time. Events and discussions, be them pirate-y business or more esoteric ones, do not convey that feeling of mystery and excitement in a story about ‘lost technologies’ as this one should.

[h3]Exploration & Stealth[/h3]
While on foot, you’ll be able to freely move around the cities, forts and outposts, choosing what activities to pursue and being able to leave at any time, except during main missions. There’s a strong emphasis on parkour, free-climbing and using the verticality of locations to gain an edge. The world is peppered with collectibles, chests, upgrade plans and lore files that will contribute money and resources to your pirating efforts. The well-known ‘Ubisoft towers’ are of course present, revealing all points of interest in a large area after reaching their summit. Collecting these bits isn’t the most exciting activity, but is worthwhile and gives a needed break from the action.

Stealth in this AC entry isn’t as strongly-pushed as in some others. It’s the usual system that sees Edward use thick bushes or crowds to become undetectable from enemies, move bodies, and instantly kill any unaware foe thanks to the iconic concealed blades (or even unarmed if you want to go non-lethal). How does a random pirate know about secret Assassin techniques you ask? Beats me.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2858351754

[h3]Ground & Naval Combat[/h3]
Combat on foot will put blades, guns and several gadgets at your disposal. Each blade set has different stats like damage, speed etc. but honestly this won’t matter much, and I saw no sensible difference between many. Guns work in the same way, but this time around the damage stat matters. Fights are melee-focused, with Edward being able to take on crowds of enemies that will mostly attack one at a time, and have some specific abilities depending on their class (Brutes, for instance, can counter-attack and throw grenades); ranged enemies are dangerous, but you can use nearby ones as a human shield if timed right.

The biggest flaws of combat in AC4 are how overpowered counters are, allowing you to remain unscathed as long as your timing is right, and how tremendously broken smoke bombs and guns result, allowing you to respectively stun all enemies in a large area or instantly kill anyone with a headshot (even bosses). These things aren’t even hard to come by, refills are common and cheap. It never felt, at any point, like it was a dangerous situation.

Naval combat will put you at the helm of the Jackdaw, outfitted with cannons, chain shots and explosive barrels to lay waste on your enemies. Other ships can be freely attacked and plundered, board them after inflicting enough damage to get 100% of their loot, or sink them for 50% - in both cases, that will be used as resources to upgrade your ship. Naval combat is fun, feels dynamic, and has a weather system with storms etc. that still can rival today’s titles. Boarded ships may also be captured and added to your personal fleet, used in a specific minigame.

[h3]Quests & Events[/h3]
Each city and outpost will always have a number of contracts to undertake, mostly assassination or naval expeditions with a variety of objectives, like escorting or destroying specific ships. There are also dynamic events, mostly at sea, such as storms that disable fast travel and spawn dangerous anomalies like tsunamis, royal convoys that house great riches but are well-guarded, or rare animals to hunt like the mythical White Whale. Legendary ships are the ultimate test of your seamanship, and you’ll need all the best upgrades to defeat them… only to receive a lot of money you won’t have a use for anymore.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2859572582

[h3]Progression & Upgrades[/h3]
Progression in AC4 is represented by the quality of your gear, both on the Jackdaw and on Edward himself. As you rack up money and materials from pillaging, hunting, assassinating and looting you’ll afford better guns, improved machinery for your ship, and will be able to craft improvements with the pelts of hunted beasts that will extend your maximum health, inventory capacity or the effectiveness of some accessories. Some of these things may only be acquired after completing each ‘set’ of missions or collectibles, but are usually worth the effort as they bring special effects or perks that ‘normal’ gear doesn’t usually have.

Перевод:

Очень многосторонни развитая игра, в которой можно  делать очень многое например  владеть собственным кораблем,  делать рейды на британские, и испанские конвои,  забирать у них добычу метал, сахар, древесину, ткани, и улучшать либо свой карабыль, либо флот.
В игре можно исследовать открытый мир, который  полн загадок, и тайн, племен Мая. Собирать камни с помощью которых можно открывать новые костюмы.
Есть собственное убежище, которое можно улучшать.
У героя появились новые собственные улучшения  оружия, и прочей амуниции, герой  может иметь до  четырех   мушкетов и две сабли, также имеется трубка с ядом, и снотворным  она открывается после прохождения  сюжетных миссий .
Сюжет игры классный,   но как по мне слишком затянут.
Музыка подходит к каждому фрагменту локаций,  иногда очень даже в тему .
В остальном игра  осталась прежней, множество контрактов на убийство, своя культура в данном случае пиратов, и сборы сундуков.
Понравилось несколько миссий на броню Тамплиера. Красиво проработанные, Рона, и девушка из племени Таино.

good acting

I have very mixed feelings about this game. When I started playing it in 2013, I got so distracted by constant looting of ships along the way to the missions, and then multilayer, that I didn't finish the campaign and abandoned it some time later on one fourth of the way in. 
In 2022 I saw a video on YouTube about this game which reignited my interest, and, so I decided to buy it and finish the campaign. And so I did.
The campaign was mixed in the quality of storytelling and there were some high highs and low lows. Two times it actually made me feel genuinely sad for the characters, so there's that. The parts that I hated the most were when they were constantly pulling me out of the "simulation" and I had to walk around in an office building and hack into different things using repetitive methods designed for a three year old with development issues. Leave me alone, I wanna role play as a cool pirate-assassin, not an office plankton goddammit!
The gameplay is very repetitive and the difficulty is virtually nonexistent. Once you learn how to counter attacks, it gets very easy to destroy large groups of enemies even with your bare fists. A lot of times an enemy will just wait for you to stab his mate on the ground while having a perfect opportunity to slash you from behind. Stealth is optional and is implemented very poorly. Tailing missions, when you stalk someone while following them are the worst most gear grinding crap that I have ever encountered in a video game. Most side activities are also copy pasted, albeit in different locations. 
The exploration part is also very repetitive. The same goes for ship combat which was the most fun part of this game for me, but got increasingly bland and dull as I defeated all four legendary ships and upgraded mine to a maximum. I would say, if you want even a little bit of challenge in this game, do not buy health upgrades for Edward and only the first level upgrades for your ship. This will make the game more balanced and fun. 
Oh, and also Uplay. My external keyboard stopped working properly when I downloaded this trash software and I wasted a lot of time getting it to work every time I booted up my PC, until one day it just kinda fixed itself. I found a thread on the online forum where a lot of people experience the same problem and the only solution that Ubisoft gives is to "upgrade your hardware so that it has USB 3". How about you fix your hot trash of a software instead, ya bunch of lazy scallops. 
The best thing about this whole ordeal is my newly rediscovered love for sea shanties mateys!
LOOOOOOOOWLAAAAAANDS, LOOOOOWLAAAAAAAANDS AWAAAY ME JOOOHN!!!

What in Davy Jones’ locker did ye just bark at me, ye scurvy bilgerat? I’ll have ye know I be the meanest cutthroat on the seven seas, and I’ve led numerous raids on fishing villages, and taken over 300 ships. I be trained in hit-and-run pillaging and be the deadliest with a pistol of all the captains on the high seas. Ye be nothing to me but another source o’ swag. I’ll have yer guts for garters and keel haul ye like never been done before, hear me true. You think ye can hide behind your newfangled computing device? Think twice on that, scallywag. As we parley I be contacting my secret network o’ pirates across the sea and yer port is being tracked right now so ye better prepare for the typhoon, weevil. The kind o’ monsoon that’ll wipe ye off the map. You’re sharkbait, fool. I can sail anywhere, in any waters, and can kill ye in o’er seven hundred ways, and that be just with me hook and fist. Not only do I be top o’ the line with a cutlass, but I have an entire pirate fleet at my beck and call and I’ll damned sure use it all to wipe yer arse off o’ the world, ye dog. If only ye had had the foresight to know what devilish wrath your jibe was about to incur, ye might have belayed the comment. But ye couldn’t, ye didn’t, and now ye’ll pay the ultimate toll, you buffoon. I’ll shit fury all over ye and ye’ll drown in the depths o’ it. You’re fish food now, lad.

You want a history that start with hope? Followed by ambition? Maybe greed? Blood and scars earned through fierce battles? Friendships and betrayal product of a dream with many different points of view? A tale of redemption and learning? Look no further than AC4: Black Flag.

Its been a while since I last gave an AC game a perfect score, but now after finally playing I understand the love of the players for this one. It had all the potential, great story, great characters and much more in a single game.
Where Ezio developed during the course of three games, Ubisoft did some magic and put all the same amount of effort in only for this and I can say I've been impressed! Now to continue the AC marathon!

This is the best Assassin's Creed Game. The Ezio Trilogy of games are the best "Assassin's Creed" of Assassins's Creed games. 

Gameplay both on land and at sea is fun and addicting. Naval combat is a pure joy with nearly infinite replay value. The tropical setting of the Caribbean is graphically pleasing on the eye, with the water effects still holding up 9 years later. If you're not content with 30fps, it's rather easy to set it to 60. Simply go in to the Assassin4 file, change the refresh rate number to 63, then go into Nvidia control panel, and set the frame limit to 60. Make sure to turn Vysnc in game off, but on in control panel for zero tearing, without being locked to 30fps.

TLDR:
Honestly my recommendation is to just buy Origins or Odyssey. Both are vast improvements IMO. (They're also later in the series so I guess that's to be expected!)

Good: 
Graphics
Large open world

Bad:
Gameplay
Controls (seriously, why must 'E' be used for everything? Try to open a crate and the game thinks your hiding and whistles. Useful...)
Too many tail / follow missions
Too great an emphasis on stealth

Longer version:
This is where steam needs a 'meh' recommendation. The game isn't bad, so to mark it as not recommended is unfair, but at the same time I don't really feel it's a must have. The game has been in my library since 2017, and it's taken me 4 attempts to just get enthused enough to get through the intro / training missions.

The mission design is not overly creative I feel, and there is far too much emphasis on following / tailing and stealth than I care for. It's just not my play style. One could argue that it's a game about assassins, and fair point, but this isn't a simulator.

I've reached the mission where I need to locate James Kidd, and I'm not sure I'll progress further. The few attempts I've had at it so far I haven't enjoyed, I just find myself asking 'why?' Roaming the world instigating naval battles is genuinely the most fun part of the game for. Unfortunately though you need to progress further in the story to unlock more stuff.

Gameplay – Pirate, ship, loot, fight, a massive open world, very good all round.
Soundtrack – 9/10
Windows – 10
Difficulty – Moderate.
Grind – Optional.
Story – Assasino ubi at its best.
Price – Sale.
Bugs – Few frozen games.
Rating - 9/10

Great game locked behind a garbage launcher. Password required simulator 2022. Don’t bother if you want to play on the Deck, you’ll need to enter your password EVERY SINGLE TIME you launch the game. Also requires you to be online to launch and Steam won’t refund it. I’ll be avoiding anything Ubisoft related going forward.

UPDATE: I'm changing my review a bit to add that it is possible to get into the settings of the Ubisoft launcher on the first run and change to offline mode. You have to get past the first login first. I had to uninstall and reinstall the game to do this.  This allows the launcher to at least bypass the login screen on the Steam Deck on every launch. It would be nice if they just removed the Ubisoft Launcher altogether though.

Great old school pirate vibes and a good "Assassins Creed" experience. Lots to do and explore, it's not open world but the locations and sections are big with many places to venture to. The islands and the tropical settings are cool & unique with great colors and water. The graphics are "good" but this game is old so don't expect to be blown away. But overall the game does a good job of immersing you into the nomadic & chaotic life of a pirate who happens to become an assassin.
